title: 1441 Yangtze flood
summary: The 1441 Yangtze flood was a significant natural disaster that occurred in the late autumn during the Ming dynasty. It affected the area around Nanjing, China, causing repeated breaches of the Yangtze River's banks. The flood posed a major emergency for Nanjing and its surrounding region, as well as the northern capital Beijing, which relied on grain shipments from the Yangtze valley. The southern entrance to the Grand Canal at Yangzhou near Nanjing was closed due to heavy flooding.

title: 2013 Eastern China smog
summary: The 2013 Eastern China smog was a severe air pollution episode that occurred in December 2013, affecting East China and surrounding provinces. The smog was caused by a combination of industrial emissions and slow-moving air masses, resulting in extremely high levels of PM 2.5 particulate matter, averaging over 150 micrograms per cubic meter in some areas. This led to reduced visibility and major disruptions in transportation, daily activities, and air quality, with airports, highways, and schools being closed. The smog was particularly severe in Shanghai, where the Air Quality Index crossed 300 on December 2. The pollution was attributed to coal burning, which increased during the winter months as residents burned more coal for warmth.

title: Addor Capital
summary:
Addor Capital is a Chinese investment firm founded in February 2014 by the Jiangsu High-Tech Investment Group (Govtor Group), a state-owned investment company. The firm invests in various industries including technology, manufacturing, energy, and healthcare. Initially facing difficulties due to limited management fees and visibility, Addor gained a key milestone in July 2016 by winning a mandate from the China SME Development Fund, allowing it to fundraise 4.5 billion yuan within a month.

Addor has expanded its business, setting up entities in Beijing and Hong Kong to establish M&A and private equity businesses. In 2020, the firm partnered with several Chinese companies to establish a $146 million fund for emerging technology startups. Addor is headquartered in Nanjing with additional offices in other Chinese cities, including Beijing, Shanghai, and Guangzhou.

title: Aiguo Dai
summary: Aiguo Dai is a Chinese-American atmospheric scientist and professor at the University at Albany, SUNY. He joined the National Center for Atmospheric Research in 1999 as a project scientist and became an associate professor at the University at Albany in 2012. Dai is a highly cited researcher, focusing on climate variability and projecting future climate change, including global water cycle changes and droughts. His research has predicted severe drought in heavily populated areas by 2100 and attributed the global warming hiatus to the Interdecadal Pacific Oscillation.

title: An Zhisheng
summary: An Zhisheng is a Chinese geographer and politician born on February 25, 1941. He specializes in quaternary geology, air particle pollution control, and global change. An Zhisheng is a member of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, The World Academy of Sciences (TWAS), and Foreign Associate of the National Academy of Sciences. He is a researcher at the Institute of Earth Environment, Chinese Academy of Sciences and has served as Vice Chairman of International Union for Quaternary Research (INQUA) from 1999 to 2007. An Zhisheng has also held various academic and administrative positions, including director of the Institute of Earth Environment. He is an editor of Quaternary Science Reviews and a member of the Chinese Communist Party.

title: Anthony Kuhn
summary: Anthony Kuhn is the National Public Radio correspondent in Seoul, South Korea. He previously served as an NPR correspondent in China, Southeast Asia, and London. Kuhn holds a degree in French Literature from Washington University in St. Louis and a graduate certificate in Chinese Studies from the Johns Hopkins University-Nanjing University Center for Chinese and American Studies. He has reported on stories throughout China and the broader region, gaining national attention in China for his fluent Mandarin skills. Kuhn is the son of late Harvard professor and sinologist Philip A. Kuhn, and he has worked as NPR's correspondent in Beijing for a decade.

title: Archdiocese of Nanjing
summary: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Nanjing is a diocese of the Catholic Church in China. It was established as the Apostolic Vicariate of Nanjing in 1659 and promoted to a diocese in 1690. The diocese's territory was reduced in 1696 and demoted to an apostolic vicariate several times, with name changes occurring in 1856, 1921, and 1922. The archdiocese was elevated to a metropolitan archdiocese in 1946, with the suffragan sees of Haimen, Shanghai, Suzhou, and Xuzhou. The archdiocese's motherchurch is the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception, also known as the Shigu Road church.

title: Baima, Nanjing
summary: Baima is a town in Lishui District, Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It has administrative control over six residential communities and four villages as of 2020. Baima is located in Jiangsu province, China. The town falls under the administration of Lishui District in Nanjing city.

title: Bank of Jiangsu
summary: Bank of Jiangsu (BOJ) is a Chinese joint-stock commercial bank founded in 2007 and headquartered in Nanjing, Jiangsu. It was formed from the combination of 10 city commercial banks in Jiangsu and officially commenced operations on January 24, 2007. BOJ was considered one of China's best performing local commercial banks in 2015, posting a net profit of 9.5 billion yuan. The bank held its initial public offering (IPO) on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in August 2016, raising 7.24 billion yuan. BOJ was named a Systemically Important Financial Institution by the People's Bank of China and the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission in 2021.

title: Bank of Nanjing
summary: Bank of Nanjing (NJBK) is a Chinese joint-stock commercial bank founded in 1996 and headquartered in Nanjing, Jiangsu. It was previously known as Nanjing City Commercial Bank (NCCB), which was formed through a merger of 40 urban credit cooperatives in Nanjing. BNP Paribas is the bank's largest single shareholder, having acquired a 19.2% stake in NCCB in 2005 and later diluted its stake to 12.7%. NJBK became a listed company on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in July 2007 after its initial public offering. In September 2021, the bank was added to China's list of systemically important financial institutions.

title: Battle of Nanjing (1853)
summary: The Battle of Nanjing (1853) was a pivotal event in the Taiping Rebellion. It began after the fall of Wuhan on March 8, 1853, and ended with the Taiping forces capturing Nanjing on March 19, 1853. The remaining Qing garrison surrendered but was executed by the Taiping forces. A force of over 750,000 Taiping troops besieged Nanjing for thirteen days before breaching the city walls. The Taiping forces then captured the Imperial City, defended by over 30,000 Manchu bannermen families. Following the capture of Nanjing, Taiping forces murdered approximately 30,000 family members of the Manchu soldiers.

title: Beiji Ge
summary: Beiji Ge, also known as Qintian Mountain, is a hill located in Nanjing, east of the Gulou District. During the Ming Dynasty, a meteorology measure device was installed on the mountain. In 1927, Zhu Kezhen established China's first modern meteorological institute on the hill. This marked the beginning of China's modern meteorological research. The site is significant in the history of Chinese meteorology.

title: Benjamin Gung
summary: Benjamin W. Gung is a Chinese American organic chemist and academic, born on July 15, 1953. He is an emeritus Professor of Chemistry at Miami University and has concentrated his research on organic synthesis, including the total synthesis of natural products and nonbonding interactions involving aromatic rings. Gung has synthesized various natural products, and his work is ranked among the top 2 percent of researchers worldwide according to a Stanford University study. He received his bachelor's degree from Nanjing University in 1982 and completed his graduate studies at Kansas State University, where he earned his Ph.D. in 1987. Gung has supervised students and held various roles, including reviewer for NSF-Career Applications and Co-PI on an NSF-DUE project. He has published over 100 journal articles in the field of organic chemistry, focusing on stereochemistry, non-covalent molecular interactions, and computational chemistry.

title: Bernhard Arp Sindberg
summary: Bernhard Arp Sindberg was born on 19 February 1911 in Aarhus, Denmark. He traveled extensively throughout his youth and witnessed the Nanjing Massacre in China, where he helped Chinese refugees by allowing them to stay at a concrete factory where he worked as a security guard. Sindberg's efforts are estimated to have saved between 6,000 and 20,000 Chinese people from a cruel fate. He has been honored for his actions, including being given the title "A friend of China." Sindberg's experiences in China were documented through his photos, letters, and personal accounts.

title: Bi Jilong
summary: Bi Jilong was a Chinese diplomat born in 1914. He was the second Chinese Under-Secretary-General of the United Nations. Bi's family had a background in diplomacy, with his father serving as an embassy staff member and editor of Eastern Times in Shanghai. His maternal grandfather was the Consul of the Qing Dynasty to Singapore. Bi attended Yangzhou High School and graduated from National Central University, later working for various agencies of the Nationalist government.

title: Bin Chen
summary: Bin Chen is a Chinese-born American materials scientist working at the NASA Ames Research Center and as an adjunct professor at the University of California, Santa Cruz. She earned a B.S. in Chemistry from Nanjing University and a Ph.D. in Chemistry from Pennsylvania State University. Chen's research focuses on materials synthesis and applications for sustainable energy and ultra-sensitive detection techniques, including hybrid nanocomposite materials for energy harvesting and storage devices. She has conducted over $3 million worth of federal projects with NASA, DARPA, and DTRA. Chen has received recognition for her work, including the NASA TGER award and publication in notable journals such as Technology Review by MIT.

title: Bin Liu
summary: Bin Liu is a chemist and Professor at the National University of Singapore. Her research focuses on polymer chemistry and organic functional materials, particularly in the areas of conjugated polymers, biocompatible luminogens, and nanomaterials. Liu was appointed Vice President of Research and Technology in 2019 and awarded the 2021 Royal Society of Chemistry Centenary Prize for her work. She has also developed machine learning algorithms to accelerate materials design, predicting the properties of molecular structures and screening millions of molecules. Liu has commercialized her technology through a spin-out company, Luminicell, and has worked on projects including high-efficiency solar cells and biomedicine applications.

title: Bu Yu
summary: Bu Yu is a Chinese politician born in September 1965, from Xiangshui, Jiangsu. He joined the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) in June 1986 and held various positions, including chief editor of the Nanjing Daily, deputy director of the Nanjing Daily Newspaper Group, and CCP Deputy Committee Secretary. Bu Yu received the 13th Changjiang Taofen Award in 2014 and served as dean of the School of Journalism and Communication at Nanjing University. He held several positions in Jiangsu Provincial government, including CCP Committee Secretary and director of the Press Office. In July 2020, Bu Yu was elected as the new Chairman of Jiangsu Provincial Television Association.

title: C.banner
summary: C.banner is a Chinese fashion conglomerate based in Nanjing. The company initially sold footwear but has expanded to own brands such as Hamleys, MIO, and United Nude. C.banner is the second largest mid to premium retailer for women's casual and formal wear in China. In 2018, C.banner was set to acquire a 51% stake in Britain's House of Fraser department stores group, but ultimately withdrew from the deal. This led to further administration for the House of Fraser stores.

title: Cai Changgui
summary: Cai Changgui is a Chinese goalball player born on 15 April 1983. He won a gold medal at the 2008 Summer Paralympics and also competed in the 2012 Summer Paralympics. Cai lost his eyesight at age 10 due to a medical accident involving an injection. He is married to goalball player Wang Shasha, who is also blind, and they live in Hangzhou with their black Labrador guide dog named Sanhao.

title: Caoqiao Mosque
summary: The Caoqiao Mosque, also known as the Grass Bridge Mosque, is a mosque located in Nanjing City's Qinhuai District, Jiangsu province, China. Constructed during the Qianlong Emperor's rule (1735-1796) of the Qing dynasty, it has undergone several reconstructions and removals since then. The mosque features traditional Chinese architecture with a main prayer hall, teaching room, wudu, and wing room. It serves as the headquarters of the Chinese Hui Religion Association, established in 1912. The mosque is accessible on foot from Zhangfuyuan Station of the Nanjing Metro.

title: Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception (Nanjing)
summary: The Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception, also known as Shigu Road Cathedral, is a late 19th-century church in Nanjing. Located at 112 Shigu Road, it serves as the cathedral of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Nanking. The church was first built in 1870 during the Qing dynasty and rebuilt by the Chinese government in 1928 after being severely damaged during the Northern Expedition War. It has served as the cathedral for the Archdiocese of Nanjing since the 1930s and is listed as a Jiangsu Provincial Historic Site. The church was restored in 1928 and has retained its original appearance since then, despite being damaged during the Cultural Revolution.

title: Central Guoshu Institute
summary: The Central Guoshu Institute was a martial arts academy established in Nanjing by the Kuomintang government of the Republic of China in March 1928. It was created by Zhang Zhijiang under the sponsorship of elite government officials, with the goal of propagating Chinese martial arts. The institute played a crucial role in the transmission of traditional Chinese martial arts into the 20th century, hosting national competitions and examinations that attracted top martial artists from China. The institute's first national martial arts competition, a lei tai tournament, was held in Beijing in April 1928 and attracted 400 of the best martial artists in China. The institute also hosted another national examination in Nanjing in October 1928, which was regarded as one of the most significant historic gatherings of Chinese martial arts masters.

title: Chang Ch'i-yun
summary: Chang Ch'i-yun was a Chinese historian, geographer, educator, and politician. Born on 29 September 1901, he graduated from the Division of History and Geography of National Nanjing Higher Normal School. Chang worked as an editor for The Commercial Press, taught at several universities including National Central University and Zhejiang University, and gave lectures at Harvard University in 1943. He served as Minister of Education from 1954 to 1958 and founded the Chinese Culture University in 1962. Chang died on 26 August 1985 in Taipei, Taiwan.

title: Chang Cheh
summary: Chang Cheh was a Chinese filmmaker, screenwriter, lyricist, and producer active in the 1960s to 1980s. Born on February 10, 1923, he directed over 90 films in Greater China, primarily with the Shaw Brothers Studio in Hong Kong. Chang is known for his action films, particularly wuxia and kung fu movies filled with violence. He frequently collaborated with actors David Chiang, Ti Lung, and the Venom Mob, as well as writer Ni Kuang. Chang's work was influenced by directors such as Akira Kurosawa, Sergio Leone, and Sam Peckinpah. He is often referred to as the "Godfather of Hong Kong cinema" for his significant contributions to the industry.

title: Chang Liyi
summary: Chang Liyi, also known as Jack Chang, was a pilot in the Republic of China Air Force with the rank of major. Born on 7 November 1929 in Nanjing, he was a member of the CIA-trained Black Cat Squadron that flew U-2 reconnaissance aircraft to spy on China's nuclear program. On 10 January 1965, Chang was shot down over Baotou, Inner Mongolia, while on a mission to take infrared photographs of atomic bomb production facilities. He was captured and held in detention until late 1969, when he was released and sent back to his hometown on the mainland. After being given permission to leave China in 1982, Chang lived in the United States with his family until Taiwan allowed him entry in 1990.

title: Changlu Temple
summary: The Changlu Temple is a Chan Buddhist temple located in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It has a history dating back to 527 during the Liang dynasty and was repeatedly destroyed and rebuilt over 10 times. The original temple was submerged in the Yangtze River by the 12th-century Song dynasty due to rising water, and a new temple was built in 1185 further north. The temple has been rebuilt several times after being burned down during wars, including the Jin-Song Wars and the Taiping Rebellion. The last pre-modern temple was destroyed by the 1954 Yangtze River floods, and a new temple was built in 2010 about 5 km away from the former site.

title: Chaotian Palace
summary: The Chaotian Palace, also known as the Nanjing Municipal Museum, is a historic palace complex located in Nanjing, China. Built during the Ming dynasty as an imperial palace, it is now a museum showcasing over 100,000 cultural relics. The complex spans an area of 70,000 square meters and features a traditional Chinese architectural style characteristic of the Ming and Qing dynasties. Originally named Ziji Palace, it was rebuilt as Chaotian Palace by the Hongwu Emperor in the late 14th century. The palace suffered damage during the Taiping Rebellion and was rebuilt from 1866 to 1870. Today, it is considered the highest grade, largest scale, and most complete preservation of ancient buildings in Jiangnan area.

title: Charles Henry Riggs
summary: Charles Henry Riggs was an American Presbyterian missionary and agricultural engineer born on February 6, 1892, in Aintab, Turkey. He obtained his Bachelor of Science in Agriculture from Ohio State University in 1914 and later earned a Master of Science in Agricultural Engineering from Cornell University in 1932. Riggs worked as Professor of Agricultural Engineering at the University of Nanking from 1932 to 1946, and during World War II, he served as the Housing Commissioner for the International Committee for the Nanking Safety Zone. He was tasked with relocating refugees and overseeing the transportation system in refugee camps during the Nanjing Massacre. Riggs left China in 1951 due to the Korean War and died on March 13, 1953.

title: Chen Chung-hwan
summary: Chen Chung-hwan was a scholar of ancient Greek and Western philosophy. Born in 1905, he graduated from the Department of Philosophy at National Southeastern University (later Nanjing University) in 1929. Chen then studied at the University of London and Berlin University, receiving his doctorate in 1940. He taught at various universities in China before emigrating to the United States, where he taught at several institutions including Emory University and the University of Texas at Austin. Chen retired in the early 1980s and died in Oxnard, California in 1992.

title: Chen Deming
summary: Chen Deming is a Chinese former politician born in Shanghai in 1949. He received degrees from the Hopkins-Nanjing Center and Nanjing University Business School, and joined the Chinese Communist Party in 1974. Chen held various positions including Mayor of Suzhou, Governor of Shaanxi, and Minister of Commerce from 2007 to 2013. He was appointed to the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress in 2007 and served as President of Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits. In 2013, Chen led a delegation to Taiwan for an 8-day visit and in 2014, he visited Taiwan again for the 10th round of cross-strait negotiation.

title: Chen Fenghuai
summary: Chen Feng Huai was a Chinese botanist born on 16 May 1900. He studied at Jinling University and later at the Royal Botanical Garden of Edinburgh in the 1930s. Chen contributed significantly to the construction and administration of botanical gardens in China, serving as director and co-founder of several notable gardens including the Lushan Botanical Garden, Zhongshan Botanical Garden in Nanjing, Wuhan Botanical Garden and the South China Botanical Garden. He held a position at Nanchang University after returning to China. Chen Feng Huai died on 13 April 1993 and was buried at the Lushan Botanical Garden.

title: Chen Guangbiao
summary: Chen Guangbiao is a Chinese recycling entrepreneur and philanthropist born in July 1968 in Sihong County, Jiangsu Province. He is the founder and chairman of Jiangsu Huangpu Renewable Resources Limited Company. Chen's net worth was estimated to be around US$810 million in 2013, although estimates varied between US$400-750 million in subsequent years. He gained international attention for his rescue efforts following the 2008 Sichuan earthquake and was recognized as one of Asia's leading philanthropists by Forbes Asia in 2008 and 2009. Chen attempted to buy The New York Times in January 2014 but was unsuccessful. He has also been known for his publicity stunts and philanthropic efforts, although some have questioned the authenticity of his charitable work.

title: Chen Miaodeng
summary: Chen Miaodeng was an imperial consort during the Chinese Liu Song dynasty of the Southern dynasties period. Born around 449, she was a concubine of Emperor Ming (Liu Yu) and held the rank of Guifei, a title created by Emperor Ming to honor her. Chen Miaodeng was discovered by Emperor Xiaowu when she was around 12-13 years old, and after being passed between several men, including Emperor Ming's younger brother Liu Yu the Prince of Xiangdong and his attendant Li Dao'er, she gave birth to Emperor Ming's oldest son Liu Yu in 463. After Emperor Ming became emperor, he created her son crown prince and gave her the title of Guifei. Following Emperor Ming's death in 472, Chen Miaodeng was honored as "Consort Dowager" but not empress dowager.

title: Chen Qianping
summary: Chen Qianping is a Chinese historian born in February 1955 in Nanjing, Jiangsu. He is currently a professor and doctoral supervisor at Nanjing University, where he earned his doctor's degree in history in March 2002. Chen is a member of the Academic Advisory Committee of the Chinese Academy of History and has ancestral ties to Jiangdu.

title: Chen Si
summary: Chen Si is a Chinese man born in 1968 in Suqian, Jiangsu province. He has intervened in at least 469 suicide attempts on the Nanjing Yangtze River Bridge since 2003, saving numerous lives. Chen patrols the bridge on foot and by motorbike, identifying individuals who appear depressed or under psychological pressure. He then approaches them to talk and find solutions to their problems, often involving external help such as contacting creditors. Chen's activities have received media attention both in China and abroad, earning him the nickname "Angel of Nanjing." A documentary film about his work, Angel of Nanjing, was released in 2015 and won over 13 awards.

title: Chen Yin (6th century)
summary: Chen Yin was a crown prince of the Chinese Chen dynasty, born on April 16, 573. He was the first son of Emperor Shubao and was raised by his adoptive mother, Crown Princess Shen Wuhua. Chen Yin was created the Duke of Yongkang in 578 and became crown prince after Emperor Xuan's death in 582. However, he was deposed by his father in 588 due to accusations made against him and replaced as crown prince with Chen Yuan. The Chen dynasty ended in 589 when the Sui dynasty captured Jiankang, and Chen Yin followed his father to Chang'an where he died, although the exact year of his death is unknown.

title: Chen Zhi (sinologist)
summary:
Chen Zhi is a Chinese scholar and researcher in classical Chinese Studies. Born in 1964 in Beijing, he graduated from Peking University with a B.A. in history and later received his Ph.D. in Chinese Studies from the University of Wisconsin–Madison in 1999.

Chen is a Fellow of the Hong Kong Academy of the Humanities and Director of the Jao Tsung-I Academy of Sinology at Hong Kong Baptist University. His research focuses on classical studies, early Chinese culture and history, historical writings, traditional Chinese poetry, and excavated documents.

Chen has held various administrative roles in universities, including Head of the Department of Chinese at Hong Kong Baptist University and Founding Acting Director of Jao Tsung-I Academy of Sinology. He served as President at Hong Kong Chu Hai College from 2022 to 2024 and became the third President of Beijing Normal University-Hong Kong Baptist University United International College in April 2024.

title: Chen Zhiming
summary: Chen Zhiming is a Chinese mathematician born in July 1965 in Suzhou, Jiangsu. He graduated from Nanjing University in 1986 and received his master's degree in mathematics from the Institute of Mathematics, Chinese Academy of Sciences in 1989. Chen earned his doctor's degree from the University of Augsburg, Germany in 1992 and returned to China as a researcher at the Institute of Mathematics, Chinese Academy of Sciences in 1994. He was elected a member of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2017 and became a Fellow of the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics in 2022.

title: Cheng Xiang Zhai
summary: ChengXiang Zhai is a computer scientist and the Donald Biggar Willett Professor in Engineering at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. He received his BS, MS, and PhD in Computer Science from Nanjing University before pursuing a second PhD at Carnegie Mellon University. Zhai obtained his MS in computational linguistics and PhD in Language and Information Technologies from Carnegie Mellon University. He has held various positions at the UIUC Department of Computer Science, including Assistant Professor, Associate Professor, and Professor. Zhai also holds joint appointments with the Carl R. Woese Institute for Genomic Biology, Department of Statistics, and School of Information Sciences at UIUC.

title: Chia-Shun Yih
summary: Chia-Shun Yih was a Chinese-American engineer and academic. Born on July 25, 1918, in Guiyang, China, he studied civil engineering at National Central University and later earned his PhD from the University of Iowa in 1948. Yih made significant contributions to fluid mechanics and was a professor at the University of Michigan for most of his career. He was also a skilled linguist, mastering multiple languages including English, German, and French. Yih held memberships in the National Academy of Engineering, Academia Sinica, and the American Physical Society. He died on April 25, 1997, due to heart failure while traveling over Japan.

title: Chiang Yee
summary: Chiang Yee (1903-1977) was a Chinese poet, author, painter, and calligrapher known as "The Silent Traveller". Born in Jiujiang, China, he studied chemistry at Nanjing University and later taught in middle schools. He served as a magistrate of three counties before departing for England in 1933 to study economics at the London School of Economics. Chiang taught Chinese at the University of London and worked at the Wellcome Museum of Anatomy and Pathology, where he wrote a series of well-received books entitled "The Silent Traveller in...". He was nominated for the 1973 Nobel Prize in Literature.

title: Chien-Shiung Wu
summary: Chien-Shiung Wu was a Chinese-American particle and experimental physicist born on May 31, 1912, in Liuhe, Taicang, Jiangsu province, China. She made significant contributions to nuclear and particle physics, including working on the Manhattan Project and developing a process for separating uranium isotopes. Wu is best known for conducting the Wu experiment, which proved that parity is not conserved and led to her colleagues Tsung-Dao Lee and Chen-Ning Yang winning the 1957 Nobel Prize in Physics. Wu was awarded the inaugural Wolf Prize in Physics in 1978 and is often referred to as the "First Lady of Physics," the "Chinese Marie Curie," or the "Queen of Nuclear Research." She was a pioneer in experimental physics and an inspiration to many, particularly women in science.

title: Chien-Shiung Wu College
summary: Chien-Shiung Wu College is a college at Southeast University in Nanjing, named after Chien-Shiung Wu, an alumna of National Central University. The college is part of Southeast University and has connections with Chien-Shiung Wu. It offers four tracks for its students, allowing them to choose a major subject from the beginning of their third year. The college is affiliated with Southeast University, which also has ties to Chien-Shiung Wu.

title: Chien-Ying Chang
summary: Chien-Ying Chang was a Chinese-born painter who settled in Britain in 1946. Born on May 25, 1913, she studied art at Nanjing University from 1931 to 1935 and later attended the Slade School of Art in London from 1947 to 1950. Influenced by Xu Beihong, she helped found the China Institute of Fine Arts in Chongqing and was influenced by Western painting techniques. Chang's work combined traditional Chinese techniques with British landscapes, often using rice paper and delicate brush strokes. She exhibited her work at various galleries in Britain and was known for her prints of birds and landscapes, as well as her costume design work for films such as The Inn of the Sixth Happiness. Chang passed away in January 2004, after living in Britain for nearly six decades.

title: China National Highway 328
summary:
China National Highway 328 (G328) is a highway in Jiangsu, China. It runs from Nanjing to Nantong and spans 300 kilometres (190 mi) in length. The highway passes through Liuhe Town and Yangzhou before reaching Nantong. 

China National Highway 112 is a highway that runs around Beijing. Prior to 2013, China recognized National Highway 228 as the Taiwan Ring, but this designation is not recognized by the Republic of China (Taiwan).

title: China Pharmaceutical University
summary: China Pharmaceutical University (CPU) is a public university in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. Founded in 1968 through mergers between the National College of Pharmacy and other smaller universities, it is affiliated with the Ministry of Education and co-sponsored by the Ministry of Education and the Province of Jiangsu. The university is part of Project 211 and the Double First-Class Construction, with a strong focus on pharmacy, traditional Chinese medicine, biology, and related fields. CPU has six schools, four independent departments, and five key labs and centers at state or provincial levels. It has 530 faculty members, including two academicians, and has undertaken over 70 research projects financed by the State Key Programs Foundation.

title: Chinyee
summary: Chinyee was a Chinese-American Abstract Expressionist painter born in Nanjing, China in 1929. She emigrated to the United States and studied at the College of Mount Saint Vincent, later earning her MFA from New York University. Chinyee's work was featured in several exhibitions, including Asian Traditions, Modern Expressions: Asian American Artists and Abstraction, 1945-1970 at the Zimmerli Art Museum in 1997, and A Lyrical Journey, Chinyee's 50-Year Retrospective at the Shanghai Art Museum in 2007. She also worked with the United Nations, serving overseas missions in various countries. Chinyee had her first solo show at the Mi Chou Gallery in 1965 and passed away on June 2, 2023.

title: Choh Hao Li
summary: Choh Hao Li was a Chinese-born American biochemist born on April 21, 1913. He discovered human pituitary growth hormone consists of a chain of 256 amino acids in 1966 and successfully synthesized it in 1970. Li was a professor at the University of California, Berkeley, and served as Director of the Hormone Research Laboratory from 1950 to 1967. He isolated several protein hormones, including adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) and melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH), and identified their amino acid chains. Li's research contributed significantly to the field of protein chemistry, with over 1,000 published papers and numerous honors received. He was elected to several academies, including Academia Sinica, Republic of China, and dedicated his career to studying pituitary-gland hormones.

title: Christ's Church, Mochou Road
summary: Christ's Church, Mochou Road is a Protestant church located in Qinhuai District, Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It originated from the former Oratory founded by the Presbyterian Mission Agency in the 19th century and was later established as the Hanzhong Church by the Church of Christ in China in 1927. Renovations to the main building began in 1936 and were completed in 1942. The church was closed during the Cultural Revolution but reopened to the public in 1981. It has been classified as a municipal and provincial cultural relic preservation organ since 1992 and 2002, respectively.

title: Christ's Church, Nanjing
summary: The Christ's Church, Nanjing is a Protestant church located on Jiangsu Road in Gulou District, Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It originated from the "Lingguang Church" founded by Zhao Shuying in 1941. In 1946, the Chinese Christian Spiritual Seminary rented the location as its school site after moving back to Nanjing from Chongqing. The church was closed during the Cultural Revolution but reopened in 1982. It relocated to its current site on Jiangsu Road in December 1999.

title: Christian Kröger
summary: Christian Jakob Kröger was a German engineer born on February 5, 1903, in Altona, Hamburg, Germany. He worked for the German-owned Carlowitz & Co. in China and served as treasurer of the International Committee for the Nanking Safety Zone during the Nanjing Massacre in 1937. Kröger documented Japanese atrocities, including pillaging of German assets and the massacre itself, in his report "Days and Nights of the Nanking Crucifixion." He was one of the first foreigners to leave Nanjing after the massacre, informing international press about the events. Kröger received a letter of gratitude from the German ambassador to China for his humanitarian work in Nanjing. After World War II, he worked for Krupp in Cairo and Munich until his death on March 21, 1993.

title: Chung-Yao Chao
summary: Chung-Yao Chao was a Chinese theoretical physicist born on June 27, 1902. He studied at Nanjing Higher Normal School and later earned a PhD in physics from California Institute of Technology under Robert Andrews Millikan's supervision in 1930. Chao was the first to experimentally identify positrons through electron-positron annihilation in 1930, but did not realize their significance. His research laid the foundation for Carl David Anderson's discovery of positrons in 1932, which earned Anderson the 1936 Nobel Prize for Physics. Chao joined the physics faculty of Tsinghua University in Beijing after returning to China and died on May 28, 1998.

title: Cindy Yu
summary:
Cindy Yu is a British-Chinese journalist. Born in Nanjing, China, she moved to the United Kingdom at age 10 and later studied philosophy, politics, and economics at the University of Oxford. She then pursued a master's degree in contemporary Chinese studies.

Yu worked as a store manager for Lidl before starting an internship at The Spectator, where she became the broadcast editor and began hosting her podcast Chinese Whispers in 2020. The podcast focuses on Chinese politics, society, and culture.

Yu joined The Times in May 2022 as a columnist and contributing editor. She frequently comments on China-related issues at the BBC World Service, RTÉ, and Sky News.

title: City Wall of Nanjing
summary: The City Wall of Nanjing is a massive fortification built during the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644) under the orders of the Hongwu Emperor. Constructed over 21 years with the labor of 200,000 workers, it covers an area of approximately 55 square kilometers and required the movement of around 7 million cubic meters of earth. The wall was designed to consolidate the emperor's sovereignty, defend against coastal pirates, and expand strategic food reserves. Its unique design prioritized military defenses due to the city's location at the foot of a mountain and its natural moat, the Yangtze River. The wall features 18 gates, with only two original gates still standing: Zhonghua Gate and Heping Gate.

title: City Wall of Nanjing
summary: The City Wall of Nanjing is a massive fortification built during the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644) under the orders of the Hongwu Emperor. Constructed over 21 years with the labor of 200,000 workers, it covers an area of approximately 55 square kilometers and required the movement of around 7 million cubic meters of earth. The wall was designed to consolidate the emperor's sovereignty, defend against coastal pirates, and expand strategic food reserves. Its unique design prioritized military defenses due to the city's location at the foot of a mountain and its natural moat, the Yangtze River. The wall features 18 gates, with only two original gates still standing: Zhonghua Gate and Heping Gate.

title: Clifford Sharp Trimmer
summary: Clifford Sharp Trimmer was an American doctor born on February 5, 1891, in Middle Valley, New Jersey. He earned his M.D. from the University of Pennsylvania in 1918 and served as an internist at Gulou Hospital in China. Trimmer was a member of the International Committee for the Nanking Safety Zone during the Nanjing Massacre in 1937 and remained at Gulou Hospital providing patient care. He was detained by the Japanese during World War II, released in 1943, and later worked as a US Navy port doctor. Trimmer retired from medicine in 1959 and died on January 8, 1974, in Montclair, New Jersey.

title: Cola Podshivoloff
summary: Cola Podshivoloff, also known as Nicolai Podshivoloff or Gao Liang, was a Russian engineer born on February 1, 1912, in Chita, Russia. He moved to Shanghai in 1930 and later to Nanjing in 1936 to work for the East Asia Trading Company. During the Nanjing Massacre, Podshivoloff joined the International Red Cross Committee of Nanking and helped safeguard Chinese refugees from the Imperial Japanese Army. He was a key member in setting up the Nanking Safety Zone, which protected thousands of refugees and injured soldiers. Podshivoloff was later accused of being a Japanese secret agent but was exonerated in 1947.

title: Consort Chen (Sui dynasty)
summary: Consort Chen was a daughter of Emperor Xuan of Chen and an imperial concubine to Emperor Wen of Sui, the founder of the Sui dynasty. Born in 577 as Princess Ningyuan, she was a native of Chang'an and the daughter of Emperor Xuan's concubine Consort Shi. After her father's death in 582, Princess Ningyuan and her family were taken to the Sui capital Chang'an. She was later honored as Lady Xuanhua and became a consort of Emperor Wen, but he never had relations with her while Empress Dugu was alive. Consort Chen reported a rape incident involving Emperor Wen's son Yang Guang, which led to Emperor Wen seeking to replace Yang Guang as crown prince. After Emperor Wen's death in 605, Consort Chen became one of Yang Guang's concubines.

title: Consort Chen Farong
summary: Chen Farong, also known as Chen Zaohua or Consort Chen, was an imperial consort of the Chinese Liu Song dynasty. She held the rank of Zhaohua, the sixth highest rank for imperial consorts, during her time as a concubine of Emperor Ming. Chen was from the Liu Song capital Jiankang and was regarded as the mother of Emperor Shun, born in 469. However, historical accounts suggest that Emperor Ming was impotent and that Emperor Shun's true biological father may have been Emperor Ming's brother Liu Xiufan. After the fall of the Liu Song dynasty in 479, Consort Chen was honored as the Princess Dowager of Ruyin.

title: Dai Yuanben
summary: Dai Yuanben was a Chinese physicist born on July 31, 1928, in Nanjing, Jiangsu. He was a member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference from 1973 to 1988. Dai studied at National Central University, graduating in 1952 and later pursuing postgraduate work at the Institute of Mathematics under Zhang Zongsui. He held various positions, including associate research fellow and research fellow at the Chinese Academy of Sciences, before transferring to the Institute of Theoretical Physics in 1978. Dai Yuanben died on September 26, 2020, at the age of 92 in Beijing.

title: Dan D. Yang
summary: Dan D. Yang is the founder of VINCI Education, a learning platform based on brain science and technology integration for early and primary education. Born in China to an entrepreneurial family, Yang holds a bachelor's degree in physics from Nanjing University (1982) and master's and doctor degrees from Paris-Sud 11 University in France. She began her career teaching Optics and Photonics at the École nationale supérieure d'arts et métiers in Paris before immigrating to Canada and starting her first company, AFC Technologies. Yang received five patents for inventions in the field of fiber optic networking and was recognized as the "Queen of EDFA." She has founded multiple startups, including VINCI Education, and has been listed as one of the Top 10 Female Entrepreneurs/Mompreneurs to Watch by Forbes in 2011.

title: Daosheng Christ's Church
summary: Daosheng Christ's Church, also known as Daosheng Church, is a Protestant church located in Gulou District, Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. Founded by the Protestant Episcopal Church Mission in 1915 with Chinese architecture style, it was initially closed in 1958 and repurposed as the Library of Nanjing No.12 High School. In 1992, it was classified as a municipal cultural relic preservation organ by the Nanjing government. A new building for the church was constructed in Hekou Gate Park, with a foundation laying ceremony held on December 18, 2008. The church was further classified as a provincial cultural relic preservation organ by the Jiangsu government in 2019.

title: Death toll of the Nanjing Massacre
summary: The Nanjing Massacre occurred during the Second Sino-Japanese War, when Japanese forces entered Nanjing on December 13, 1937. The total death toll is a contentious subject in Chinese and Japanese historiography, with estimates ranging from over 40,000 to under 200,000. The most reliable figures place the number of victims within Nanjing City Walls at around 50,000, mostly killed in the first five days. The total number of victims in Nanjing and its surrounding counties is estimated to be over 100,000 but less than 200,000. The debate centers on the validity of burial records and oral history, as well as who should be included as "massacre victims." The Chinese government estimates that approximately 300,000 people were killed.

title: Defeng Sun
summary: Defeng Sun is a Chinese applied mathematician and operations researcher. He holds the position of Chair Professor of Applied Optimization and Operations Research at The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, where he has been the Head of Department of Applied Mathematics since 2019. Sun served as President of The Hong Kong Mathematical Society from 2020 to 2024 and was elected a Fellow of the American Mathematical Society for the 2026 class. He received the Beale-Orchard-Hays Prize in 2018 for his work on semidefinite programming software and was named a SIAM Fellow in 2020. Sun's research interests include non-convex continuous optimization and machine learning, with notable contributions to the field of conic optimization.

title: Deliang Chen
summary: Deliang Chen is a Chinese-Swedish climatologist born on July 21, 1961. He holds the August Röhss Chair of the Department of Earth Sciences at the University of Gothenburg. Chen is a fellow of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences and a foreign academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences and the Royal Norwegian Society of Sciences and Letters. He has taught at the University of Gothenburg since 1993, becoming a full professor in 2000. Chen has directed 26 doctoral dissertations and held various academic leadership positions, including director of the International Council for Science from 2009 to 2012.

title: Ding Henggao
summary: Ding Henggao is a Chinese general born on February 3, 1931, in Nanjing, Jiangsu. He served as chairperson of the Commission for Science, Technology and Industry for National Defense from 1985 to 1995. Ding held various positions within the Chinese Communist Party, including alternate member of the 12th Central Committee and member of the 13th and 14th Central Committees. He also served as a member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference's 8th and 9th National Committees. Ding earned a vice-doctorate degree from the Leningrad Institute of Fine Mechanics and Optics in 1961. He was promoted to general in June 1994, after previously being promoted to lieutenant general in September 1988.

title: Ding Kuiling
summary: Ding Kuiling is a Chinese organic chemist born in March 1966 in Yongcheng, Henan, China. He earned his bachelor's degree from Zhengzhou University in 1985 and Ph.D. from Nanjing University in 1990. Ding has held various academic positions, including research professor at the Shanghai Institute of Organic Chemistry and President from 2009 to 2018. He is currently Executive Vice President of Shanghai Jiao Tong University, a position he has held since October 2018. Ding is an academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences and has received several awards for his work in asymmetric catalysis and organometallics.

title: Dingshan Temple
summary: Dingshan Temple is a Buddhist temple located in Pukou, Nanjing, Jiangsu province, China. It is situated at the bottom of The Lions near Pearl Spring and is as famous as Qixia Temple. According to legend, the temple's historical significance began when Dharma visited and studied Buddhism there after crossing the Yangtze River using a folded reed. This event is said to have occurred at the invitation of Emperor Wu of Liang, who initially sought Dharma's teachings but was rebuffed. As a result, the temple became an important site in Buddhist history.

title: Dong Jian
summary: Dong Jian was a Chinese literary scholar born in January 1936 in Shouguang, Shandong. He specialized in the history of Chinese theatre and held various positions at Nanjing University, including Chair of the Department of Chinese and Vice President. Dong pursued his master's degree under Chen Zhongfan, an expert in classical Chinese theatre, and later became a faculty member at Nanjing University. He published numerous works on theatre history and theory, including A Draft History of Modern Chinese Theatre, which won multiple national and provincial prizes. Dong died on 12 May 2019 in Nanjing at the age of 83.

title: Donglei Fan
summary: Donglei "Emma" Fan is a professor at The University of Texas at Austin, affiliated with the Cockrell School of Engineering and the Materials Science and Engineering Program. She is a faculty member of the Texas Materials Institute and works in its Nanomaterials Innovation Lab. Fan holds two master's degrees from Johns Hopkins University, one in materials science and engineering and the other in electrical engineering. She received her Doctor of Philosophy degree in materials science and engineering from Johns Hopkins University in 2007. Fan is an inventor of the patented "3D Electrokinetic Tweezers" and holds multiple patents, with nine granted and seven pending.

title: Donna Sheng
summary: Donna Sheng is a condensed matter physicist specializing in two-dimensional systems, including the fractional quantum Hall effect and quantum spin Hall effect. She is a professor of physics at California State University, Northridge and affiliated with the Princeton Center for Complex Materials. Sheng earned her Ph.D. from Nanjing University in 1989 and joined California State University, Northridge's faculty in 2000. She was awarded the Preeminent Scholarly Publications Award by California State University, Northridge in 2012 and named a Fellow of the American Physical Society in 2013. In 2025, Sheng was elected to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.

title: Drum Tower of Nanjing
summary: The Drum Tower of Nanjing is a historical landmark located in the Gulou District of downtown Nanjing, China. It was first built in 1382 AD during the Ming Dynasty's 15th year of reign. The tower measures 44 meters long, 22 meters wide, and 30 meters high with a square stone foundation pedestal featuring three archways. The structure includes four side-rooms and a two-story watch tower made of wood and bricks, which served as a sacred place for ceremonies. The Drum Tower is situated at 32°03′31″N 118°46′55″E.

title: Du Xiaogang
summary: Du Xiaogang is a Chinese politician born in June 1976 in Changzhou, Jiangsu Province. He studied international finance at Nanjing University and later obtained a Master of Business Administration degree through a joint program with Maastricht School of Management in the Netherlands. Du joined the Chinese Communist Party in June 1997 and began his career in August 1999. He has held various positions, including deputy secretary and secretary of the Gulou District Committee of the Communist Youth League, mayor of Taicang, Kunshan, and Wuxi. Du is currently serving as Chinese Communist Party Committee Secretary of Wuxi and Chairman of the Standing Committee of the Wuxi Municipal People's Congress.

title: Eduard Sperling (businessman)
summary: Eduard Sperling was a member of the Nazi Party and served as a representative of the Shanghai Insurance Company in Nanjing. He was also a member of the International Committee for the Nanking Safety Zone during the Nanjing Massacre. Sperling served in the German military during World War I, participating in the Siege of Tsingtao and being detained in Japan for four years. As General Inspector of the International Committee, he protected Chinese refugees from Japanese forces while denouncing them and expressing loyalty to Hitler. In February 1938, he received medical treatment from Jin Yongpan before assisting him in submitting a report on the Nanjing Massacre to the Nationalist Government.

title: Empress Dowager Zheng
summary: Empress Dowager Zheng (died December 26, 865) was an empress dowager of the Chinese Tang dynasty. She was a concubine to Emperor Xianzong and gave birth to his son Li Yi, who later became Emperor Xuānzong. After Emperor Xianzong's death in 820, Li Yi became emperor and created his mother Consort Zheng as empress dowager. She continued to serve in this role until her death during the reign of her grandson Emperor Yizong. Little is known about her family origins, but according to the New Book of Tang, she was from Danyang (modern Nanjing) and may have been originally from the Erzhu family.

title: Empress Ma (Jianwen)
summary: Empress Xiaominrang was the empress consort to the Jianwen Emperor and the second empress consort of China's Ming dynasty. Born in 1378, she was a member of the Ma clan and married Zhu Yunwen, grandson of the Hongwu Emperor. She was proclaimed consort in 1395 and became empress consort after Zhu Yunwen ascended the throne in 1398. Empress Xiaominrang had two sons, Zhu Wenkui and Zhu Wengui, who were posthumously honored. She died in 1402 during the sack of Nanjing by Zhu Di.

title: Empress Wang (Chenghua)
summary: Empress Xiaozhenchun (1440/1450-1518) was a Chinese empress consort of the Ming dynasty, married to the Chenghua Emperor. She was chosen as empress after her predecessor's deposition due to a conflict with Consort Wan, the emperor's favorite concubine. Empress Wang avoided conflict by staying childless to prevent competition with Consort Wan, who feared the emperor's favor would shift if another consort gave birth to a son. After the Chenghua Emperor's death in 1487, Empress Wang was given the title of empress dowager. She was further elevated in rank by her grandson, the Zhengde Emperor, in 1510.

title: Ernest Forster
summary: Ernest Herman Forster was an American Episcopal missionary born on November 1, 1896. He graduated from Princeton University in 1917 and served as a missionary in China, teaching at Mahan School in Yangzhou from 1920. In 1936, Forster married Clarissa Townsend and they returned to Yangzhou before moving to Nanjing in 1937, where he became Secretary General of the International Red Cross Committee. Forster held this position alongside John Gillespie Magee during the Nanjing Massacre and later served as Secretary of the Nanking International Relief Committee. He returned to the United States in 1942 and worked as a chaplain and priest until his death on December 18, 1971.

title: F. Tillman Durdin
summary: Frank Tillman Durdin was a foreign correspondent for The New York Times from 1937 to 1974. Born on March 30, 1907, in Elkhart, Texas, Durdin reported on significant events including the Second Sino-Japanese War, the collapse of European colonial rule in Indo-China, and the emergence of the People's Republic of China. He was granted a visa to reenter China in 1971, becoming the first American journalist to do so. Durdin's reporting included accounts of the Nanjing Massacre, although he initially attributed mass killings to Japanese soldiers before recanting in 1987. He and his wife Peggy were among the few Western reporters to cover the February 28 massacre in Taiwan in 1947. Durdin retired from The New York Times in 1974 and passed away on July 7, 1998.

title: Fan Chunhai
summary: Fan Chunhai is a Chinese chemist born in March 1974 in Zhangjiagang, Jiangsu province. He received his bachelor's degree and doctor's degree from Nanjing University in 1996 and 2000, respectively. Fan was a postdoctoral researcher at the University of California, Santa Barbara under Alan J. Heeger before returning to China in 2000. He became the director of the Laboratory of Physical Biology at the Shanghai Institute of Applied Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2000. In 2018, Fan joined Shanghai Jiaotong University as a Chair Professor of the School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering.

title: Fan Jian (legal scholar)
summary: Fan Jian is a Chinese legal scholar born in 1957 in Nantong, Jiangsu, China. He graduated from Nanjing University School of Law with a master's degree in 1988 and later studied at the University of Göttingen from 1989 to 1991. Fan was a visiting scholar at Columbia University from 2000 to 2001, teaching laws related to commerce, corporate law, economics, international trade, and security. He has authored over 160 academic papers and contributed to the Commercial Law textbook. Fan was recognized as one of China's ten distinguished young legal scholars in 1995 and one of the 100 most influential legal scholars in building the rule of law in China by China Today in 2017.

title: Fang Wei
summary: Fang Wei is a Chinese politician born in May 1965 in Kunshan, Jiangsu. He obtained his bachelor's degree in philosophy from Nanjing University in 1987 and joined the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) in June 1986. Fang's career spans multiple roles, including positions in Suzhou, Taizhou, Wuxi, and Lianyungang. He has held various leadership positions since 1992, including deputy director, director, and party secretary in several administrative committees. Fang has also held positions as Vice Mayor, Mayor, and Party Secretary in different cities. As of July 2022, he serves as Vice Governor of Jiangsu Province and was appointed Vice Chairman of the Jiangsu Provincial Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference in January 2023.

title: Fang Xianjue
summary: Fang Xianjue was a Chinese National Revolutionary Army general during the Second Sino-Japanese War. Born on November 22, 1903, in a small Jiangsu village, Fang graduated from the Whampoa Military Academy in 1926 and rose through the ranks to become an army general. He commanded the Chinese 10th Army during Operation Ichi-Go in 1944, defending Hengyang for 48 days against the Imperial Japanese Army. Fang surrendered on August 8, 1944, after running out of ammunition and supplies, but was later decorated with the Order of Blue Sky and White Sun for his heroism. After the Chinese Civil War, Fang transferred to Taiwan and retired from the military in 1968, dying of a heart attack on March 3, 1983.

title: Fei Gaoyun
summary: Fei Gaoyun is a Chinese politician born in August 1971 in Huai'an, Jiangsu Province. He studied radio technology at Yangzhou Institute of Technology and later obtained a master's degree in public administration from Nanjing University. Fei joined the Chinese Communist Party in December 1992 and began his career working in Jiangsu Province. He has held various positions, including vice governor of Jiangsu Province from 2018 to 2022 and Party Secretary of Changzhou from 2017 to 2018. In December 2022, he was transferred to Anhui Province and became a member of the provincial Party committee standing committee. As of April 2023, he serves as the Party Secretary of Hefei and first secretary of the Hefei Garrison District Party Committee.

title: Feng Kang
summary: Feng Kang was a Chinese mathematician born on September 9, 1920. He studied at Suzhou High School and later at National Central University (Nanjing University), where he initially studied electrical engineering but eventually focused on mathematics. After graduating in 1944, Feng continued to study mathematics independently due to health issues and later taught at Tsinghua University. He worked at the Steklov Mathematical Institute in Moscow from 1951 to 1953 and became a key figure in computational mathematics in China. Feng made significant contributions to various fields, including topological groups, Lie groups, generalized function theory, and computational mathematics. He is known for proposing the finite difference method based on variation principles (later independently developed as the finite element method) and developing embedding theories in discontinuous finite element space.

title: Former Residence of Gan Xi
summary: The Former Residence of Gan Xi, also known as the Grand Courtyard of the Gan Clan, is a historic mansion located on Zhongshan South Road in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China. Built during the reign of the Jiaqing Emperor (1796-1820) of the Qing dynasty, it was originally known as "Fraternity Hall" and served as the residence of Gan Fu, the father of Gan Xi. The mansion now operates as the Nanjing Folk Museum and features an exhibition of local handicrafts, including Yixing clay teapots and Chinese paper cutting. The building is said to contain over 300 rooms, a significant number for a commoner's residence. It is accessible on foot from the Sanshanjie Station of Nanjing Metro and lies near the former Nanjing Police Station.

title: François Cheng
summary: François Cheng is a Chinese-born French academician, writer, poet, and calligrapher. Born on August 30, 1929, in Nanchang, Jiangxi, China, he moved to France at the age of 19 and became a French citizen. Cheng is known for his works in French, including essays, novels, poetry collections, and art books. He is also a translator of French poets into Chinese. In 2002, he was elected to the Académie française and won the 1998 Prix Femina for his novel "Le Dit de Tianyi".

title: Fu Yi (general)
summary: Fu Yi is a major general in the People's Liberation Army of China. Born in November 1953, he joined the Chinese Communist Party in August 1971 and the People's Liberation Army in March 1969. Fu started his military career in 1980 in the Nanjing Military Region and held various positions, including Chief of staff of the 1st Group Army. He was detained by Chinese military authorities in January 2015, suspected of corruption, and retired in November 2013.

title: G2503 Nanjing Ring Expressway
summary: The Nanjing Ring Expressway is a ring expressway in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It is designated as G25 03. The first section of the expressway was opened to traffic on October 7, 2005, including the Nanjing Dashengguan Yangtze River Bridge. The expressway was completed in several stages, with the Ninglian Expressway section opening on December 18, 2006, the southeast section opening on September 30, 2010, and the whole expressway opening on December 24, 2012. The Nanjing Ring Expressway runs concurrently with the G25, G40, and G42 expressways in several sections.

title: G36 Nanjing–Luoyang Expressway
summary: The Nanjing–Luoyang Expressway, also known as the Ningluo Expressway, is a 1,354.7 km (841.8 mi) expressway connecting Nanjing in Jiangsu Province and Luoyang in Henan Province, China. It was fully completed on 30 September 2006. The expressway passes through multiple cities, but specific city names are not provided in the given information.

title: Gao Hong (chemist)
summary: Gao Hong was a Chinese analytical chemist, educator, and fellow of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Born on June 26, 1918, in Jingyang, Shaanxi, he attended various schools before enrolling in the chemistry department of Central University of China in 1938. After graduating from the National Central University in 1943, Gao Hong went to the United States and obtained a doctorate in Chemistry from the University of Illinois in 1947. He returned to China and taught at Central University, later becoming a fellow of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 1980. Gao Hong held various positions, including director of the Institute of Analytical Science at Northwestern University from 1997. He died on June 14, 2013, at the age of 95 in Nanjing.

title: Gao Hua
summary: Gao Hua was a Chinese history professor at Nanjing University, born on May 12, 1954. His father, Gao Qifa, was a former member of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) who joined the underground CCP and served in the Nanjing Military Control Committee after 1949. However, due to changes in the political environment, Gao Qifa was expelled from the CCP and faced discrimination during the Anti-Rightist Campaign. Gao Hua continued his education through self-study and was admitted to the History Department of Nanjing University in 1978. He earned his master's and doctoral degrees from the university before becoming a professor of history.

title: Gaochun Old Street
summary: Gaochun Old Street is a national AAA level tourist scenic zone located in Gaochun, Nanjing, China. It is the best-preserved old street from the Chinese Ming and Qing Dynasty in Jiangsu Province, having been designated as a provincial heritage unit. The street is approximately 345 meters long and 3.5 meters wide, originally measuring 800 meters in length. It features old-styled shops selling goods and services of interest to tourists, as well as nearby attractions such as the Qianlong Old Well and the Guanwang Temple. Gaochun has been named an International Slow-rhythm City, reflecting its peaceful and slow-paced lifestyle.

title: Ge Haijiao
summary: Ge Haijiao is a Chinese politician and banker born in December 1971 in Liaozhong County, Liaoning. He holds a bachelor's degree from Liaoning University (1993), a master's degree from Jilin University (1999), and a doctorate in finance from Nanjing Agricultural University (2000). Ge joined the Chinese Communist Party in January 1998 and began his career in banking, working for the Agricultural Bank of China and China Everbright Group Co., Ltd. He entered politics in 2019, serving as vice governor of Hebei and later executive vice governor. In March 2023, he was appointed Chinese Communist Party Committee Secretary of the Bank of China, succeeding Liu Liange.

title: Georg Rosen (1895–1961)
summary: George Rosen was a German lawyer and diplomat born on September 14, 1895, in Shirvan, Iran. He was a Rhodes Scholar and son of Friedrich Rosen, who served as German Foreign Minister in 1921. Rosen worked for the German Foreign Office and assisted in organizing the Nanking Safety Zone during the Second Sino-Japanese War. He collaborated with John Rabe to protect Chinese civilians from Japanese atrocities, helping save over 200,000 lives. Due to his Jewish heritage, Rosen was forced to leave the diplomatic service in 1938 and emigrated to London and later the United States, where he taught at several universities.

title: George Ashmore Fitch
summary: George Ashmore Fitch was an American Presbyterian missionary born on January 23, 1883, in Suzhou, China. He was the fourth child of Presbyterian missionaries George Field Fitch and Mary McLellan Fitch, who had been active in the Christian community in Shanghai and Suzhou since 1870. Fitch was fluent in Chinese and worked with the YMCA for most of his career, serving as director of the International Committee for the Nanking Safety Zone during the Nanjing Massacre. He smuggled out evidence of the atrocities and later embarked on a public awareness tour across the United States. Fitch also played a role in Korean independence activism, befriending notable politicians including Syngman Rhee and Kim Ku. He served as head of the South Korean YMCA from 1947 to 1949 and passed away on January 21, 1979.

title: Gilbert Ling
summary: Gilbert Ning Ling was a Chinese-born American cell physiologist, biochemist, and scientific investigator. Born on December 26, 1919, in Nanjing, China, he studied at the National Central University and later received a Ph.D. from the University of Chicago in 1948. Ling co-developed the Gerard-Graham-Ling microelectrode, a device used to measure electrical potentials of living cells. He proposed the Association induction hypothesis in 1962, an alternative theory to the membrane and steady-state membrane pump theories of cell function. Ling's research challenged the mainstream view of cellular biology, and he spent his career conducting experiments to support his hypothesis. He died on November 10, 2019, at the age of 99.

title: Ginling College
summary: Ginling College, also known as Jinling Women's College, is a women's college of Nanjing Normal University in Nanjing, China. It offers both bachelor's and master's degrees in various fields including applied English, accounting, food science, and women's education. The college has its roots in a Christian college founded in 1913 by American missionaries, which was the first institution to grant bachelor's degrees to female students in China. Ginling College played a significant role during the Nanjing Massacre, harboring over 10,000 women trying to hide from the Japanese Imperial Army under the supervision of acting principal Minnie Vautrin. The college was closed from 1951 to 1987, when it was reestablished on its previous site.

title: Grace Louise Bauer
summary: Grace Louise Bauer was an American medical missionary of the Churches of Christ. Born on January 20, 1896, in Baltimore, Maryland, she received medical training as a laboratory technician at Howard A. Kelly Hospital. In 1919, Bauer traveled to Nanjing, China, where she worked at Drum Tower Hospital, educating local laboratory workers and supervising the hospital's laboratory department. During the Nanjing Massacre, she supported the continued operation of Drum Tower Hospital by overseeing finances and providing sustenance to civilians. Bauer returned to the United States in 1941, resumed her position at Johns Hopkins Hospital, and retired before passing away on July 29, 1976.

title: Ground Force Command College
summary: The Ground Force Command College, also known as the Army Command College, is a professional military education college in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It is affiliated with the People's Liberation Army Ground Force and serves as a command academy training army commanders. The college has undergone several name changes since its establishment, including the East China Military and Political University, Nanjing Military Region Military and Political Cadre School, Nanjing Advanced Infantry School, Nanjing Advanced Army School, PLA Army Command Academy, and the current name. The college has a long history of providing military training to foreign officers since 1957 and hosts exchange students from countries such as Azerbaijan, The Gambia, South Korea, and Pakistan. It oversees the International Military Education Exchange Center (IMEEC).

title: Guangzhao Mao
summary:
Professor Guangzhao Mao is an American chemical engineer and academic. She holds positions as professor and Head of the School of Engineering at the University of Edinburgh, and previously served as the Head of the School of Chemical Engineering at the University of New South Wales from 2020 to 2024. Mao's research focuses on nanotechnology, particularly targeted drug delivery and electrochemistry for sensors.

Mao completed her BSc in chemistry from Nanjing University in 1988 and obtained her PhD in chemical engineering from the University of Minnesota in 1994. She began her academic career at Wayne State University, where she served as a professor until 2020. Mao has held various leadership positions and is the chief investigator of several Australian Research Council (ARC) research hubs.

Mao has authored over 145 peer-reviewed articles and proposed several innovative techniques for targeted drug delivery, including using biodegradable polymer coatings and nanoparticles to bypass the blood-brain barrier. Her research has also explored nanotoxicology using human embryonic stem cells.

title: Guo Jinlong
summary: Guo Jinlong is a Chinese politician born in July 1947 in Nanjing, Jiangsu. He studied at the Physics Department of Nanjing University from 1964 to 1969, majoring in acoustics. Guo joined the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) in April 1979 and held various positions, including serving as the Secretary of the CCP Tibet Autonomous Region from 2000 to 2004 and Party Secretary of Anhui Province from 2004 to 2007. He served as the Mayor of Beijing between 2008 and 2012, and Party Secretary of Beijing from 2012 to 2017. Guo played a key role in the Qinghai-Tibet Railway project and was executive chairman of the Beijing Organizing Committee for the Olympic Games (BOCOG) during the 2008 Olympics.

title: Han Lih-wu
summary: Han Lih-wu was a Chinese educator, politician, and diplomat. Born on January 26, 1903, in Anhui, he earned degrees from Nanjing University, the University of London, and the University of Wisconsin–Madison. Han served as deputy minister of education from 1944 to 1949 and later succeeded Chen Hsueh-ping as minister. He played a key role in the Kuomintang retreat to Taiwan by relocating artworks from Peking to Taipei. Han held various diplomatic positions, including ambassador to Thailand, Laos, the Philippines, and Greece from 1956 to 1972.

title: Han Xianglin
summary: Han Xianglin (1906-1985) was a Chinese humanitarian who played a significant role during the Nanjing Massacre (1937-1938). Born in Linzi County, Shandong Province, he graduated from Shandong Christian University and served as a multilingual secretary for John Rabe. Han was instrumental in orchestrating relief efforts, proficient in English, German, and French. He managed the distribution of food to refugees at Rabe's apartment and coordinated patrols to prevent Japanese soldiers from infiltrating the camp. After the massacre, Han provided testimony against Japanese war crimes and later worked in the printing department of Nanjing University until his retirement.

title: He Jiacheng
summary: He Jiacheng is a former Chinese academic and public official. Born in May 1956 in Nanjing, Jiangsu, he earned his degrees from Nanjing University and the Graduate School of Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. He Jiacheng won several awards, including the Sun Yefang Economics Prize in 1985 and the Chinese Book Award in 1990. He held various positions, including executive vice president of China National School of Administration from 2013 to 2014. He was dismissed in October 2014 due to suspected corruption and subsequently investigated by the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection. He Jiacheng was expelled from the Communist Party in 2015 and sentenced to 9 years in prison in 2017 for taking bribes.

title: Hexi tram
summary: The Hexi tram is a part of the Nanjing tram network in China, serving the city of Nanjing. It began its first trial run on August 13 and was built as part of infrastructure works for the 2014 Summer Youth Olympics. The tram runs at ground level and features eco-friendly technologies, including an on-board storage battery and pantograph charging system. It covers 7.76 km with 13 stations, intersecting with Nanjing's existing metro lines at four points. The tram initially began service from the Olympic Stadium East station to Yuzui Wetlands Park area in southern Hexi New District.

title: Hideo Tarumi
summary: Hideo Tarumi is a Japanese diplomat born on May 23, 1961. He graduated from Kyoto University's Faculty of Law in March 1985 and joined the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Tarumi has held various positions, including serving as First Secretary at the Embassy of Japan in Beijing from 1989 to 1990, Director of Political Affairs at the Consulate-General of Japan in Hong Kong from 1999 to 2001, and Ambassador to China from November 2020 to December 6, 2023. During his tenure as ambassador, he was required to stay in quarantine due to the COVID-19 pandemic and had his credentials accepted by President Xi Jinping on April 14, 2021. Tarumi has also been accused by the Chinese government of belonging to an espionage organization due to his association with a Chinese journalist.

title: Historiography of the Nanjing Massacre
summary:
The Historiography of the Nanjing Massacre refers to the study and interpretation of the 1937-1938 massacre of Chinese civilians by the Imperial Japanese Army in Nanjing. Scholarly debates vary on the scale of atrocities, Japanese responsibility, and how the event has been remembered or downplayed in Japan, China, and internationally. The debate is influenced by nationalist perspectives, access to sources, and evolving historical methods.

A widely cited figure for the death toll is over 200,000 Chinese civilians and prisoners of war, according to the International Military Tribunal for the Far East. However, Japan and China have not reached an agreement on the death toll, contributing to regional geopolitical tensions in East Asia. The Japanese government's control over news media during the war concealed the massacre from the public, and some Japanese ultranationalists still deny its occurrence.

title: Hohai University
summary: Hohai University is a public research university in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It was established under the name Hohai College of Engineering in 1924 and became a comprehensive university in 1985. The university is affiliated with the Ministry of Education, the Ministry of Water Resources, and other government agencies. It has three campuses covering a total area of 132 hectares and offers various academic programs, including engineering, hydrology, water resources management, and marine engineering. Hohai University has nine state and provincial key laboratories, five state and provincial engineering research centers, and over 30,000 degree students. The university has a strong focus on water-related research and education, with numerous talents cultivated for China's water conservancy development.

title: Hongshan Forest Zoo
summary:
Hongshan Forest Zoo is a zoological park in Nanjing, Jiangsu province, China. It covers 168.03 acres and has a green coverage rate of 85%. The zoo is divided into three districts: Xiao Hongshan, Da Hongshan, and Fangniu Mountain, with 27 venues. It houses over 3,000 animals of more than 260 species.

Established in 1998 after the merger of Xuanwu Lake Zoo and Hongshan Park, the zoo is a self-funded public institution. It has been dedicated to wildlife conservation and science education since its opening, despite facing challenges such as a decline in visitors during the COVID-19 pandemic. The zoo was designated as a national 4A-level tourism attraction in 2013 and is the first zoo in China to end animal performances, stopping them in 2011.

title: Hongshan Forest Zoo
summary:
Hongshan Forest Zoo is a zoological park in Nanjing, Jiangsu province, China. It covers 168.03 acres and has a green coverage rate of 85%. The zoo is divided into three districts: Xiao Hongshan, Da Hongshan, and Fangniu Mountain, with 27 venues. It houses over 3,000 animals of more than 260 species.

Established in 1998 after the merger of Xuanwu Lake Zoo and Hongshan Park, the zoo is a self-funded public institution. It has been dedicated to wildlife conservation and science education since its opening, despite facing challenges such as a decline in visitors during the COVID-19 pandemic. The zoo was designated as a national 4A-level tourism attraction in 2013 and is the first zoo in China to end animal performances, stopping them in 2011.

title: Hongwu Emperor
summary: The Hongwu Emperor (1328-1398), born Zhu Yuanzhang, was the founding emperor of the Ming dynasty. He ruled from 1368 to 1398 and played a crucial role in unifying China after the collapse of the Mongol Yuan dynasty. Zhu Yuanzhang joined a rebel division in 1352 and quickly rose to lead his own army, eventually conquering Nanjing and establishing it as his capital. He formed a government consisting of both generals and Confucian scholars, adopting the concept of country administration from the Mongols. The Hongwu Emperor unified China through a four-year war, driving out Mongol armies and implementing significant reforms to improve institutions. His thirty-year reign saw the growth of Ming China, with a strong emphasis on pragmatism and caution in military affairs.

title: Hu Hongwen
summary: Hu Hongwen was a Chinese organic chemist and educator. Born on 16 March 1925, he served as an academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Hu was also the chief editor of a higher education textbook on Organic Chemistry. He passed away on 19 May 2016 at the age of 91 in Nanjing, China.

title: Hu Peisong
summary: Hu Peisong is a Chinese agronomist born in May 1964 in Tonglu County, Zhejiang. He received his bachelor's degree from Zhejiang Agricultural University in 1986 and later earned a master's degree from the Graduate School of Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences, followed by a doctor's degree from Nanjing Agricultural University in 2002. Hu has been involved in genetic improvement of rice quality since 1991 and holds multiple key positions, including president of the China National Rice Research Institute. He serves on various editorial boards and advisory roles, contributing to international organizations such as the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations.

title: Hua Chunying
summary: Hua Chunying is a Chinese diplomat born on 24 April 1970 in Huai'an, Jiangsu. She graduated from Nanjing University with a Bachelor of Arts in English language and literature in 1992. Hua joined the Ministry of Foreign Affairs as a section member, working her way up to become spokesperson and eventually serving as Assistant Minister of Foreign Affairs from 2021 to 2024.
