She was appointed Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs in May 2024, a position she still holds. Hua has been described as a "wolf warrior diplomat" due to her assertive approach in defending China's interests.

title: Hualing Nieh Engle
summary: Hualing Nieh Engle was a Chinese novelist, fiction writer, and poet. Born on 11 January 1925 in Wuhan, Hubei, China, she graduated with a degree in English from National Central University in 1948. After the Chinese Communist Revolution, she relocated to Taiwan and began teaching creative writing courses at National Taiwan University and Tunghai University. In 1964, she moved to the United States and attended the Iowa Writers' Workshop, where she met her future husband Paul Engle. Together they founded the International Writing Program (IWP) at the University of Iowa in 1967, which aimed to promote cross-cultural exchange among international writers.

title: Huang Lixin
summary: Huang Lixin is a Chinese politician born in August 1962 in Suqian, Jiangsu province. She graduated from the Jiangsu Agricultural College and later obtained a graduate degree in Marxist philosophy at Nanjing University. Huang began her career as an office worker and rose through the ranks, becoming a fully licensed engineer in 1991. She has held various leadership positions, including Vice Governor of Jiangsu and Party Secretary of Nanjing, and has been dispatched to fill vacancies left by officials accused of corruption. Huang is an alternate member of the 18th and 19th Central Committees of the Chinese Communist Party. She currently serves as chairwoman of the Shanghai Municipal People's Congress.

title: Huang Shisong
summary: Huang Shisong was a Chinese meteorologist. Born in Jinhua, Zhejiang, he initially studied at National Central University's Department of Aeronautical Engineering before switching to geography due to a finger infection. Huang received his degree in Meteorology from National Central University in 1942 and later studied at the University of Chicago and UCLA under Carl-Gustaf Rossby and Jacob Bjerknes. He led the Department of Meteorology at Nanjing University from 1977 to 1983, focusing on low-latitude circulation and East Asian monsoon circulation. Huang served as Honorary President of the Chinese Meteorological Society before his death on 11 November 2017.

title: Huang Shuxian
summary: Huang Shuxian is a Chinese politician born in September 1954 in Yangzhong, Jiangsu. He graduated from Nanjing University with a degree in philosophy and began his career in Jiangsu province, serving as party chief of Yangzhong County and head of the Communist Youth League organization. Huang held various positions, including Deputy Discipline Inspection Secretary of Jiangsu province and Vice Minister of Supervision of the People's Republic of China. He became a Deputy Secretary of the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection in 2007 and Minister of Supervision at the 2013 National People's Congress. Huang was appointed as Minister of Civil Affairs in 2016, following a corruption scandal involving then-minister Li Liguo.

title: Huatai Securities
summary: Huatai Securities is a securities company in China that operates comprehensive broking and trading services. Founded on 9 April 1991, the company was originally named Jiangsu Securities Company and later renamed to Huatai Securities in 1999. It received approval from the China Securities Regulatory Commission to be a Qualified Domestic Institutional Investor in 2008. Huatai Securities was listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in 2010 and later expanded to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 2015. The company has also acquired AssetMark, a wealth management technology provider, and launched Zhangle Global, a US stock trading mobile app.

title: Hubert Lafayette Sone
summary: Hubert Lafayette Sone, also known as Soong (or Sung) Hsu-Peh, was an American Methodist missionary in China. Born on June 7, 1892, in Denton, Texas, Sone studied at Southern Methodist University and was licensed to preach by the Methodist Episcopal Church South in 1918. He served as a missionary in China from 1920, initially working in Shanghai and later becoming the Superintendent of the Institutional Church in Huzhou. In 1933, Sone joined the faculty of Nanking Theological Seminary, where he taught Mandarin, English, and Hebrew during the Japanese invasion in 1937. He played a key role in establishing the Nanking Safety Zone and was awarded "The Order of the Blue Jade" by the Chinese government for his actions in support of the Chinese people. Sone died on September 8, 1970.

title: Hui Jianlin
summary: Hui Jianlin is a Chinese politician born in February 1964 in Suzhou, Jiangsu Province. He graduated from Nanjing University's Department of Chinese Language and Literature in 1986 with a degree in Chinese language. Hui joined the Chinese Communist Party in April 1992 and began his career as a secretary in the Office of the Jiangsu Provincial Construction Committee from 1986 to 1988. He has held various leadership roles across Jiangsu, including Deputy Director of the Suzhou Construction Committee, District Governor and Party Secretary of Pingjiang District, Mayor and Deputy Party Secretary of Changshu, and Vice Governor of Jiangsu Province. As of January 2024, Hui serves as Vice Chairman and Chinese Communist Party Deputy Committee Secretary of the Jiangsu Provincial Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference.

title: Huiji Temple (Nanjing)
summary: Huiji Temple is a Buddhist temple located in Pukou District of Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. Originally built during the Southern and Northern dynasties (420-589), it was initially known as "Tangquan Chanyuan". The temple's name changed to "Huiji Yuan" in the early Song dynasty (960-1276) and was later renamed "Xiangquan Temple" in the Ming dynasty due to a social taboo. The temple suffered damage during the Taiping Rebellion but was restored in the Guangxu period (1871-1908). A large-scale reconstruction began in 2014. The temple is home to three millennial ginkgo trees.

title: Hunan Road Commercial Street
summary: Hunan Road Commercial Street is located in Nanjing's Gulou District, covering an area of 87,000 square meters. The street is 1,100 meters long and 30 meters wide, with brand and boutique stores accounting for 83% of the total business area. The street was originally named after its extension in 1927, when Nanjing was the capital of the Republic of China. Hunan Road has a rich history, with notable events including an assassination attempt on Wang Jingwei in 1927. The street features the Lion Bridge Walk Food Street, a pedestrian area with nearly 40 businesses, including food and restaurants.

title: Hundred man killing contest
summary: The Hundred-Man Killing Contest was a sensationalized story published in Japanese newspapers in 1937 during the invasion of China. The articles described two Japanese Army officers, Toshiaki Mukai and Tsuyoshi Noda, allegedly competing to kill 100 people with a sword first while advancing toward Nanjing. The reports were later found to be likely Japanese wartime propaganda or exaggeration, and historians believe the killings were part of mass atrocities committed against Chinese prisoners of war. Both officers were later convicted by the Nanjing War Crimes Tribunal for war crimes and executed in 1948. The news stories were rediscovered in the 1970s, sparking controversy over Japanese war crimes in China.

title: Hushu Subdistrict, Nanjing
summary: Hushu Subdistrict, also known as "Little Nanjing," is a subdistrict in Jiangning District of Nanjing, Jiangsu province, China. It has a total land area of 145 square kilometers and a population of approximately 80,200. The subdistrict is home to the Hushu culture, estimated to be around 4,000-5,000 years old. Hushu is also an important Islamic center in Nanjing, with a local mosque dating back over 600 years. The subdistrict is divided into 14 residential communities and 8 administrative villages, with major agricultural products including ducks, prawn, and rice.

title: Imperial Noble Consort Duanke
summary: Imperial Noble Consort Duanke was a consort of the Xianfeng Emperor. Born on 3 December 1844 in Jinling (present day Nanjing), she was a member of the Manchu Tunggiya clan. Her personal name is not recorded in history. She entered the Forbidden City at age 14 and was initially granted the title "Concubine Qi" in 1858. Throughout her life, she held various titles including "Consort Qi," "Noble Consort Qi," and was posthumously honored as "Imperial Noble Consort Duanke." She died on 7 May 1910 and was interred in the Ding Mausoleum in Eastern Qing tombs.

title: International Committee for the Nanking Safety Zone
summary: The International Committee for the Nanking Safety Zone was established in 1937 to manage and protect a designated area, known as the Nanking Safety Zone, during the Nanjing Massacre. The committee was formed by a group of Western businessmen, journalists, and missionaries who chose to remain in Nanjing as the Imperial Japanese Army approached. Led by German businessman John Rabe, the committee protected approximately 250,000 civilians from violence and provided them with basic needs such as food, shelter, and medical care. The Nanking Safety Zone was a 2-square-mile area bordered by roads on all four sides, established to house refugees. The committee's efforts were hindered by the Japanese Army's disregard for the zone's immunity, resulting in kidnappings and executions. The committee was reorganized as the Nanking International Relief Committee in 1938, continuing humanitarian work until at least 1941.

title: International Red Cross Committee of Nanking
summary: The International Red Cross established a contingent in Nanjing during the Japanese-led Nanjing Massacre to coordinate humanitarian aid efforts. Key individuals involved included John Magee, the Red Cross chairman of the Nanking Branch, who documented the atrocities and provided care to wounded civilians. Minnie Vautrin played a crucial role in protecting thousands of women by turning Ginling Girls College into a refugee haven. Other notable individuals involved were James McCallum, who drove an ambulance to rescue wounded civilians, and Grace Bauer, who assisted in caring for the wounded at Drum Tower Hospital.

title: Iris Chang
summary: Iris Shun-Ru Chang was an American journalist, historian, and political activist. Born on March 28, 1968, in Princeton, New Jersey, to a Taiwanese American family, Chang grew up hearing stories about the Nanjing Massacre from her maternal grandparents. She earned a bachelor's degree in journalism from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and began her career as a journalist, writing for publications such as the New York Times. Chang is best known for her 1997 book "The Rape of Nanking," which documents the atrocities committed by Imperial Japanese forces during World War II. She also wrote "The Chinese in America: A Narrative History" and "Thread of the Silkworm." Chang passed away on November 9, 2004.

title: James Henry McCallum
summary: James Henry McCallum was an American missionary affiliated with the Church of Christ. Born on November 19, 1893, in Olympia, Washington, he graduated from the University of Oregon and Yale Divinity School. McCallum served as a missionary in Nanjing, China from 1921 until the outbreak of World War II. During the Nanking Massacre, he remained in Nanjing and coordinated refugee relief efforts while serving on the International Red Cross Committee of Nanking. McCallum later succeeded Lewis S.C. Smythe as Secretary General of the International Relief Committee in Nanjing from July 1938 to April 1939. He died on April 20, 1984, in Pico Rivera, California.

title: Ji Ran
summary: Ji Ran (1893-1939) was a Chinese Buddhist monk and humanitarian who played a significant role in sheltering refugees during the Nanjing Massacre (1937-1938). As the supervising monk of Qixia Temple in Nanjing, he founded the temple's Buddhist Refugee Shelter, which provided a safe haven for 24,000 people. Ji Ran allocated temple resources to support the refugees, including food and shelter, while also documenting Japanese atrocities in petitions. He used various tactics to dissuade Japanese invaders from attacking the temple, including a legend about a Buddha head and communication with commanders. Ji Ran's efforts were recognized by UNESCO, which listed the Qixia Temple Refugee Shelter Memorial Stele. He died in 1939 at the age of 46 due to exhaustion from his humanitarian work.

title: Jiang Hualiang
summary: Jiang Hualiang was a Chinese pharmacist and academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Born in 1965, he served as director of the Shanghai Institute of Materia Medica and was a member of the China Democratic League. Jiang held positions in the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, including membership in the 10th and 12th National Committees. He received his degrees from Nanjing University, East China Normal University, and the Shanghai Institute of Materia Medica. Jiang held various roles at the Shanghai Institute of Materia Medica from 1995 until his death in 2022. He passed away on December 23, 2022, at the age of 57 in Shanghai.

title: Jiang Long
summary: Jiang Long was a Chinese physical chemist and academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Born on 1 January 1933 in Shanghai, his ancestral home is in Jian'ou, Fujian. Jiang joined the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) in December 1949 and graduated from Nanjing University's Department of Chemistry in 1953. He obtained a vice-doctorate degree from the Soviet Academy of Sciences in 1960 and held various positions at the Chinese Academy of Sciences, including director of the Academic Committee of Key Laboratory of Colloids and Interfaces. Jiang Long passed away on 31 December 2022, at the age of 89.

title: Jiang Shusheng
summary: Jiang Shusheng is a Chinese physicist and politician. Born in April 1940 in Wuxi, Jiangsu, he served as President of Nanjing University from 1997 to 2006. He was chairman of the China Democratic League, one of eight legally recognized political parties under the Chinese Communist Party, from 2005 to 2012. Jiang also held the position of Vice Chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress from 2008 to 2013.

title: Jiang Zemin
summary: Jiang Zemin was a Chinese politician who served as general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party from 1989 to 2002, chairman of the Central Military Commission from 1989 to 2004, and president of China from 1993 to 2003. Born on August 17, 1926, in Yangzhou, Jiangsu, he joined the Chinese Communist Party while studying electrical engineering at National Chiao Tung University. Jiang rose to power after the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests and massacre, becoming a compromise candidate as CCP general secretary. He consolidated his hold on power in 1989 and introduced the term "socialist market economy" in 1992, accelerating reform and opening up. Jiang's administration oversaw significant economic growth, including China's entry into the World Trade Organization in 2001 and the return of Hong Kong from the United Kingdom in 1997. Jiang died on November 30, 2022.

title: Jiangjun Mountain
summary:
Jiangjun Mountain is a historical site located in Jiangning District, Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China. It faces the Qinhuai River and borders Niushou Mountain. The mountain features a ground spring that flows into a lake at its base and is home to metasequoia trees. Jiangjun Mountain was the site of a battle in 1130, where the Yue Army of Song defeated the Jin Army. The remaining ramparts from this battle are well-preserved and now serve as historical relics.

The mountain is also known for its local cuisine, including "泡椒花枝片" (Pickle Cuttlefish), "竹蛏浸水蛋" (Solen grandis with eggs), and "将军山泉水鱼" (Herring from Jingping Lake).

title: Jiangnan Examination Hall
summary:
Jiangnan Examination Hall is a historic examination hall located in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China. It was first built in 1168 during the Southern Song dynasty and served as a major examination hall for imperial examinations. The hall was used for both provincial-level and metropolitan examinations, with over 20,000 buildings expanded during the Ming dynasty. It is one of the largest examination halls in ancient China and now houses the Imperial Examination Museum.

The hall was a significant site for scholars, with 58 examinees from Jiangnan Province passing the provincial imperial examination and becoming Number One Scholars. The hall featured a "Thorns Wall" to prevent cheating, and its surrounding area was once prosperous due to the Examination Hall, a government-run brothel, and Confucius Temple.

Famous individuals such as Tang Bohu, Zheng Banqiao, Wu Jingzi, and Zhang Jiang took the imperial examination at the hall. The Jiangnan Examination Hall was listed as a Provincial Key Cultural Relics Protection Unit in 1982 and is now a museum showcasing the Chinese imperial civil examination system.

title: Jiangning Subdistrict
summary: Jiangning Subdistrict is a subdistrict located in Jiangning District, Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It is situated at a geographic coordinate of 31°52′00″N 118°36′12″E. Jiangning Subdistrict is part of the larger Jiangning District, which is a district in Nanjing. The subdistrict falls within the province of Jiangsu and is a part of the city of Nanjing.

title: Jiangsu Dragons
summary: Jiangsu Dragons Kentier, also known as Jiangsu Dragons or Jiangsu Kentier, is a Chinese professional basketball team based in Nanjing, Jiangsu. They compete in the Southern Division of the Chinese Basketball Association. In the 2004-05 season, the team finished last in their division but achieved notable victories against Xinjiang Flying Tigers and Yunnan Bulls before losing to Guangdong Southern Tigers in the Finals. The team's performance was led by Tristan Wells, who scored the most points for Jiangsu Dragons that season.

title: Jiangsu Expressway Company
summary: Jiangsu Expressway Company Limited is a road construction and operations enterprise based in the People's Republic of China. Incorporated to invest, construct, operate, and manage toll expressways in Jiangsu Province, the company oversees several major expressways. These include the Shanghai-Nanjing Expressway and sections of China National Highway 312, Xicheng Expressway, Guangjing Expressway, Nanjing-Lianyungang Expressway, and Sujiahang Expressway. The company also manages the Jiangyin Yangtze River Bridge.

title: Jiangsu High People's Court
summary: The Jiangsu High People's Court, officially known as the High People's Court of Nanjing Province, is the highest judicial organ in Jiangsu, China. Located in Nanjing, it serves as a high people's court for the province. The current president of the Jiangsu High People's Court is Gong Pixiang. As a high people's court, it plays a significant role in the judicial system of Jiangsu province. The article is currently considered a stub and may benefit from further expansion to provide more information on the court's history, jurisdiction, and operations.

title: Jiangsu Military District
summary: The Jiangsu Military District is a military district of the National Defense Mobilization Department of the Central Military Commission in China. It was established in November 1952 as part of the country's military organization. The full name of the district is People's Liberation Army Jiangsu Military District or PLA Jiangsu Military District.

title: Jiangsu Nanjing Broadcast Television Tower
summary: The Nanjing Broadcast Television Tower is a free-standing telecommunications and observation tower in Jiangsu Province, China. It was built in 1996 in Nanjing, China. The tower's antenna reaches a height of 318.5 meters (1,045 feet). Its location is at 32°4′3.84″N 118°44′42.40″E. The tower serves as a telecommunications and observation facility, providing services to the surrounding area.

title: Jiangsu Sainty (company)
summary: Jiangsu Sainty Corporation Limited is a Chinese listed company based in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province. Incorporated in 1993 as a state-owned enterprise, it transformed into a company limited by shares and became listed in 2000. Initially majority-owned by the Jiangsu Provincial Government, its ownership structure changed over time due to mergers and acquisitions. In 2010, it merged with Jiangsu Guoxin Investment Group to become an intermediate holding company. The company has undergone significant changes in its ownership and business operations, including the sale of a financial leasing stake to Jiangsu Broadcasting Corporation in 2015.

title: Jiangsu Second Normal University
summary: Jiangsu Second Normal University is a university located in Nanjing, Jiangsu province, China. Established in 1952 as the Jiangsu Institute of Education, it is dedicated to teacher education and educational science research. The university has three campuses: Caochangmen, Pukou, and Xiaohang. It offers undergraduate diplomas and degrees, postgraduate diplomas, certificates, and in-service programs to pre-service students and serving teachers. Jiangsu Second Normal University is committed to training administrative personnel and teachers for key provincial schools, as well as undertaking UNESCO projects. In 2013, the university was officially renamed from Jiangsu Institute of Education to Jiangsu Second Normal University.

title: Jiangsu State Security Department
summary:
Jiangsu State Security Department (江苏省国家安全厅) is the provincial bureau of China's Ministry of State Security in Jiangsu, serving as the province's intelligence service and secret police. The department is involved in espionage against the United States, particularly in aviation-related industrial espionage and operating the advanced persistent threat TURBINE PANDA (APT26). 

In 2015, the department was allegedly responsible for a high-profile hack of the United States Office of Personnel Management, stealing personal details of over 20 million U.S. federal civil servants. The department was established in September 1983 from the Jiangsu Investigation Department, with its headquarters located in Gulou, Nanjing.

title: Jiangxin Island
summary: Jiangxin Island, also known as Jingxinzhou, is a 6.5 km long spear-shaped island in the Yangtze River east of Jianye District in Nanjing, China. The island is approximately 4 miles from the city's downtown district and is known for its diverse grape varieties, with over 130 types grown on the island. The annual Grape Festival attracts around 50,000 visitors each year. Jiangxin Island is a national scenic area and has been designated as one of Nanjing's four "green lungs" due to its rich vegetation. The island is undergoing urbanization, with a three-phase project aiming to create an eco-urban city with low carbon impact and sustainable development, targeted for completion in 2020.

title: Jiming Temple
summary: The Jiming Temple is a Buddhist temple in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. Located in the Xuanwu District near Xuanwu Lake, it is one of the oldest temples in Nanjing. The temple was first constructed in 527 during the Liang dynasty and has been destroyed and reconstructed multiple times, with its existing form dating back to the Ming dynasty in 1387. The temple features various halls, including Guanyin Hall and Huomeng Building, as well as the Medicine Buddha Pagoda. It is a popular tourist destination and the busiest temple in Nanjing, especially during the Lunar New Year.

title: Jin Yugan
summary: Jin Yugan was a Chinese paleontologist and academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Born on December 26, 1937, in Dongyang County, Zhejiang, he graduated from Nanjing University's Department of Geology and Paleontology in 1959. Jin was involved in the study of brachiopods and conducted research on stratigraphy, particularly during the Carboniferous and Permian periods. He founded China's first open laboratory for paleobiology and stratigraphy in 1989, and was elected a member of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2001. Jin died on June 26, 2006, at the age of 68 in Nanjing, Jiangsu.

title: Jing Chi
summary: Jing Chi is a full professor at Massey University, specializing in Initial Public Offerings, Chinese corporate finance and governance. She holds a PhD in finance from the University of Reading (2003) and is a Chartered Financial Analyst. Chi has worked in China for Huatai Securities and at the London Stock Exchange as an analyst. She joined Massey University's faculty in 2004 and rose to full professor in 2024, becoming the university's first Chartered Financial Analyst. Chi has received several awards for her teaching and research, including the Ako Aotearoa 2013 award for Sustained Excellence in Tertiary Teaching.

title: Jingguang Chen
summary: Jingguang Chen is a Chinese-American chemical engineer and member of the National Academy of Engineering. He holds the Thayer Lindsley Professorship in Chemical Engineering at Columbia University and a joint appointment as Senior Chemist at Brookhaven National Laboratory. Chen earned his Bachelor's degree in chemistry from Nanjing University (1982) and Ph.D. in chemistry from the University of Pittsburgh (1988). He has made significant contributions to the development of novel materials for catalytic and electrocatalytic applications, including bimetallic and transition metal carbide catalysts. Chen has held various leadership roles in academia, industry, and professional organizations, including director of the Center for Catalytic Science and Technology at the University of Delaware. His research focuses on understanding and developing tunable, low-cost catalysts for clean fuel production and use.

title: Jinghai Temple
summary: Jinghai Temple, also known as the Temple of the Calm Sea, is a 15th-century temple located in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It was built by the Yongle Emperor of the Ming dynasty in 1416 to honor Zheng He, a court eunuch and explorer. The temple was originally dedicated to the Goddess of the Sea, Tianfei, but was later renamed after a young woman who rescued sailors at sea. Jinghai Temple played a significant role in Chinese history, as the Qing government discussed and signed the Nanjing Treaty with British officials within its walls in 1842. The temple has undergone three rebuildings, most recently in 1996 and 2005, and is now a National 4A Level Scenic Spot and part of the National Patriotism Education Base.

title: Jinjue Mosque
summary: The Jinjue Mosque is a mosque located in Qinhuai District, Nanjing City, Jiangsu province of China. It was constructed in 1392 under the order of Hongwu Emperor of the Ming Dynasty and has undergone several renovations, including repairs in 1430, 1492, 1877, 1879, 1957, 1982, 1984, and 2002. The mosque's site was reduced from 107 hectares to 1,650 square meters due to the Taiping Rebellion and subsequent tax reductions. The current structure was built in the late Qing Dynasty, covering an area of 4,000 square meters. In 2007 and 2014, the mosque underwent reparation and renovation with government support. The Jinjue Mosque features a Sino-Islamic architectural style, including a three-entry gate and various prayer halls.

title: Jinling Arsenal
summary: The Jinling Arsenal, also known as the Nanjing Arsenal, was a military arsenal established in 1865 in Nanjing. It was initially moved from Suzhou by Li Hongzhang, who planned its expansion into China's largest arsenal. The facility was built on the former site of Xitian Temple and featured Western-style architecture, with over 80 rooms for machinery and boilers. The arsenal produced firearms, ammunition, and other military supplies, primarily for Li Hongzhang's Huai Army. It continued to operate under the Republic of China and underwent significant expansions, including a relocation to Chongqing in 1937.

title: Jinling College, Nanjing University
summary: Jinling College, Nanjing University is a college of Nanjing University in Nanjing, China. Founded in 1998 on the Pukou Campus of Nanjing University, it was initially established to cultivate first-class interdisciplinary talents with innovation spirits and problem-solving capabilities in industry. The college adopted a new educational scheme as an experimental approach to education, aiming to become a prestigious institution. In 2022, Jinling College was restructured as part of the Suzhou Campus of Nanjing University.

title: Jinling friendship award
summary: The Jinling Friendship Award is an award established by the Nanjing Municipal Government in 2007. It recognizes foreign scholars, experts, and diplomats who have made significant contributions to Nanjing's economic development, social progress, and ethical standards. The award was first presented in 2010 and is given every two years thereafter.

title: Jinling Library
summary: Jinling Library is a Nanjing Municipal Library located in the Jianye District of Nanjing, China. Founded in 1927 as the Nanjing Special (No.1) Popular Library, it has undergone several name changes and relocations throughout its history. The library was severely damaged during the Japanese occupation of Nanjing in 1937 and most of its books were destroyed. After a period of reconstruction, the library was reestablished in 1958 and relocated to its current site at 158 Leshan Road. The library has a collection of over two million books and is accessible by the Nanjing Metro, within walking distance of Olympic Stadium East Station.

title: Jinyu Liu
summary: Jinyu Liu is the Betty Gage Holland Professor of Roman History at Emory University's Department of History. Born and raised in China, she received her BA from Nanjing University in 1993 and MA in 1996. Liu earned her PhD from Columbia University in 2004 with a thesis on the collegia centonariorum. She began her academic career as an assistant professor at DePauw University in 2004 and later moved to Emory University as the acting Betty Gage Holland Professor of Roman History in 2023. Liu holds a distinguished guest professorship at Shanghai Normal University and has received several awards, including the Mellon New Directions Fellowship.

title: Jiong Qiu
summary: Jiong Qiu is a Chinese-born American astrophysicist. She completed her Bachelor's of Science in Astronomy at Nanjing University, China in 1993 and earned her PhD from the same university in 1998 for observational work on solar flares. Qiu worked as a postdoc at the Big Bear Solar Observatory in California and later became an assistant professor of Physics and Astronomy at Montana State University in 2005. She has contributed to the fields of Heliophysics, Heliodynamics, and Atmospheric sciences. Qiu received the 2007 Karen Harvey Prize for her major contributions to understanding the Sun's effects on Earth's atmosphere and climate.

title: Jizhaoying Mosque
summary: The Jizhaoying Mosque is a mosque located in Xuanwu District, Nanjing, Jiangsu province of China. The prayer hall was rebuilt in 1912 and underwent renovation in 1987 with funds raised by the Urban Islamic Association. The current building was designed by Ma Xiaodong and covers an area of 815.1 square meters with four floors, featuring various facilities including a main prayer hall and administrative offices. The mosque is accessible on foot from Zhujianglu Station of Nanjing Metro.

title: John Magee (missionary)
summary: Reverend John Gillespie Magee was an American Episcopal priest born on October 10, 1884, in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. He served as a missionary in China and was the minister at an Episcopal mission in Nanjing from 1912. During the Nanjing Massacre, Magee documented atrocities committed by Japanese soldiers using a 16mm movie camera. He risked his own safety to rescue over 200,000 Chinese civilians and smuggled out footage of the massacre. Magee's films were shown to members of the United States government and sent to the German Foreign Ministry in an attempt to persuade them to impose sanctions on Japan. He left Nanjing for the United States in 1938 and went on a speaking tour about the massacre.

title: John Rabe
summary: John Rabe was a German diplomat and businessman who played a key role in establishing the Nanking Safety Zone during the Nanjing Massacre. Born on November 23, 1882, in Hamburg, Germany, Rabe worked for Siemens AG China Corporation and later became the head of its Nanjing branch. In 1937, he joined the International Committee for the Nanking Safety Zone and created a neutral zone to protect Chinese civilians from Japanese atrocities. The zone, which was established in the western quarter of Nanjing, sheltered approximately 250,000 people. Rabe's efforts were motivated by a sense of morality and responsibility to protect the Chinese civilians who had placed their trust in him.

title: John Rabe House
summary: The John Rabe House, located at Xiaofenqiao No. 1 in Nanjing, China, was the residence of John Rabe from 1932 to 1938. During the Nanjing Massacre, Rabe protected over 600 Chinese refugees in this house and its garden from Japanese persecution. The house now serves as the "John Rabe and International Safety Zone Memorial Hall" and the "John Rabe Research and Exchange Centre for Peace and Reconciliation." After being renovated in 2005, the Memorial Hall officially opened to the public on October 31, 2006. It features six exhibition areas with over 300 photographs and historical materials telling Rabe's life story, focusing on his efforts to save lives during the Nanking Massacre.

title: Kang Tao
summary: Kang Tao is a Chinese politician born in April 1963 from Zhenjiang, Jiangsu. He joined the Chinese Communist Party in March 1984 and began his career in August of that year. Kang studied economic management at Nanjing University from 1980 to 1984 and initially worked in Xiamen, Fujian Province, holding various positions including deputy director of the Municipal Planning Commission and Director of the Municipal Development and Reform Commission. He later served in Quanzhou, holding positions such as Deputy Party Secretary, Mayor, and Party Secretary. As of 2021, Kang Tao has held the position of Vice Governor and Member of the Leading Party Members' Group of the Fujian Provincial People's Government.

title: Karl Günther (engineer)
summary: Karl Günther, also known as Kund or Mr. German Kund, was a German engineer born in Tangshan, China in 1903. He resided in China until the late 1950s, with a brief return to Germany for studies. During World War II, Günther established a safety zone at the Jiangnan Cement Plant in Nanking alongside Bernhard Arp Sindberg, saving tens of thousands of Chinese lives. He witnessed the Nanjing Massacre and documented it with photographs and records. After the war, Günther served as a chemical engineer at the Jiangnan Cement Factory until his departure for Germany in 1950.

title: Karl R. Hearne
summary: Karl R. Hearne is a film director and screenwriter, born in Montreal and raised in Dublin, Ireland. He studied at McGill University and later pursued a doctorate at Nanjing University before returning to Montreal to study film at Concordia University. Hearne's short film "Song" received the Prix Fasken-Martineau in 2003 and was nominated for a Prix Jutra at the 5th Jutra Awards. His feature directorial debut "Touched" premiered in 2017 and was nominated for the John Dunning Best First Feature Award at the 7th Canadian Screen Awards in 2019. His 2023 feature "The G" premiered at several film festivals and received a Special Jury Prize for Best Director at the 2024 Fantasia Film Festival.

title: Katsuichi Honda
summary: Katsuichi Honda is a Japanese journalist and author born on January 28, 1932. He is best known for his writings on the Nanjing Massacre and Imperial Japanese atrocities during World War II. Honda's series of articles, "Chūgoku no Tabi" (Travels in China), first appeared in the Asahi Shimbun in the 1970s and helped to reexamine Japan's wartime history. His work was a key factor in the reintroduction of the Nanjing Massacre into Japanese school textbooks. Honda also worked as a war correspondent in Vietnam during the Vietnam War, publishing a book on the conflict titled "Vietnam War: A Report through Asian Eyes" in 1972. His book "The Nanjing Massacre: A Japanese Journalist Confronts Japan's National Shame" was published in English in 1999.

title: Kenneth Hsu
summary:
Kenneth Jinghwa Hsu is a Chinese scientist born on June 28, 1929. He studied at the Chinese National Central University (later Nanjing University) and later in the United States, earning his Ph.D. from the University of California, Los Angeles in 1953.

Hsu worked as a petroleum geologist for Shell Oil Company from 1954 to 1963 and later became a professor of geology at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology (ETH Zürich) from 1967 to 1994. He promoted experimental geology and established five international laboratories in various fields.

Hsu participated in the Earth Science Revolution of the 1960s, contributing to Plate Tectonics Theory. He is known for his work in Process Oriented Geology, emphasizing the physical, chemical, and biological processes that shape geological problems. His research areas include sedimentation, tectonics, evaporite and pelagic diagenesis, and the effects of meteorite impacts on life forms.

title: Kim Jun-yop
summary: Kim Jun-yop was a Korean historian born on August 26, 1920. He focused on China and North Korea issues. Kim served as president of Korea University and held visiting professor positions at Harvard University and Princeton University. He declined a nomination to become Prime Minister of South Korea in 1990, choosing to remain in academia. Kim received the Korea Foundation Award in December 2009 and was chairman of the Institute of Social Sciences in Korea from January 2005.

title: Kjeld Erik Brødsgaard
summary: Kjeld Erik Brødsgaard is a Danish historian and academic. He is Professor of China Studies at Copenhagen Business School, where he also directs the China Policy Program. Brødsgaard is an internationally recognized authority on China's political economy, including state-Party-business relations and the role of the Chinese Communist Party. He obtained his MA in History from Aarhus University and the University of Copenhagen, and his Ph.D. in Modern Chinese Studies from the University of Copenhagen in 1990. Brødsgaard has held various academic positions, including visiting professorships at Peking University and National University of Singapore. He serves on several editorial boards, including China: An International Journal and Governance and Public Policy in China.

title: Kong Xianjing
summary: Kong Xianjing was a Chinese engineer and academician of the Chinese Academy of Engineering. Born on 4 January 1952 in Nanjing, Jiangsu, Kong earned his degrees from Dalian Institute of Technology (now Dalian University of Technology): a bachelor's degree in 1980, a master's degree in 1983, and a doctor's degree in 1990. Kong held various positions at Dalian University of Technology, including full professor (1992), doctoral supervisor (1995), vice president (1999-2002), and deputy party secretary (2002-2009). He later served as executive party secretary until May 2012. Kong Xianjing died on 10 September 2024, at the age of 72.

title: Kuo-Chen Chou
summary: Kuo-Chen Chou was a Chinese-American biophysicist and bioinformatician. He founded the Gordon Life Science Institute in Boston, Massachusetts. Chou made significant contributions to computational biology, including developing pseudo amino acid composition (PseAAC) and pseudo K-tuple nucleotide composition (PseKNC). He was also involved in research on enzyme kinetics, protein structure prediction and function, low-frequency collective motion in macromolecules, proteome and genome analyses, and identification of posttranslational modification sites. Chou published over 720 scientific papers and was a highly cited researcher, with an h-index of 135. However, he was involved in controversy surrounding scientific misconduct and manipulation of the peer-review process.

title: Lai Yonghai
summary: Lai Yonghai is a Chinese philosopher of religion. He serves as a professor in the Department of Philosophy at Nanjing University and is also the dean of the Institute of Chinese Culture.

title: Lewis S. C. Smythe
summary:
Lewis Strong Casey Smythe (1901-1978) was an American sociologist and Christian missionary to China. Born in Washington, D.C., Smythe spent his early life in Great Falls, Montana, before enrolling at Drake College. He earned degrees from Chicago Divinity School and the University of Chicago, where he was influenced by notable sociologists Ernest Burgess and Robert E. Park.

Smythe served as Professor of Sociology at Nanking University from 1928 to 1951, while his wife worked as a medical missionary. During the Nanjing Massacre in 1937, Smythe served on the International Committee for the Nanking Safety Zone and documented atrocities committed by Japanese troops. After World War II, he testified about the massacre at the International Military Tribunal of the Far East.

The Smythes were forced to leave China in 1951 and Smythe went on to work as an adviser, write articles and books, and teach at The College of the Bible in Lexington, Kentucky.

title: Li Beiqun
summary:
Li Beiqun is the President of Nanjing University of Information Science and Technology in China. Born in 1969 in Xinyi, Jiangsu province, he received his bachelor's degree in climatology from Nanjing University in 1991 and later earned master's and Ph.D. degrees in higher education from the same university in 1998 and 2011, respectively.

Li held various administrative roles at Nanjing University of Information Science and Technology from 1999 to 2014, including assistant director and vice president. He was appointed university president in 2017 and led the formation of a graduate school and research institute at Wuxi, China in 2018.

title: Li Cai
summary: Li Cai is an American statistician and quantitative psychologist born around 1980. He is a professor at the UCLA Graduate School of Education and Information Studies, with a joint appointment in the quantitative area of the UCLA Department of Psychology. Cai is also Director of the National Center for Research on Evaluation, Standards, and Student Testing, and Managing Partner at Vector Psychometric Group. He invented the Metropolis–Hastings Robbins–Monro algorithm, a breakthrough in high-dimensional latent variable models. Cai earned his PhD in quantitative psychology from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill in 2008 and was awarded tenure at UCLA in 2011.

title: Li Haijun
summary: Li Haijun is a Chinese academic born in November 1952, from Wuwei, Gansu. He received his B.A. degree in English literature from Lanzhou University in 1976 and later pursued master's degrees from Jilin University (1981) and Nanjing University (1986). Li Haijun worked in various institutions, including Tibet Normal College, Tibet University, and Zhengzhou University. He served as the director of foreign affairs at Zhengzhou University from 1999 to 2004. He became the president of Sias International University in the spring of 2005, succeeding his role as president at Sias University.

title: Li Jijun
summary: Li Jijun was a Chinese geographer and geomorphologist. Born on October 9, 1933, in Pengzhou, Sichuan, he graduated from the Geography Department of Nanjing University in 1956. Li was elected as a member of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 1991 and held professorships at Lanzhou University, including a term as Dean of the Geography Department. Three of his students became academicians of the Chinese Academy of Sciences: Chen Fahu, Qin Dahe, and Yao Tandong. Li Jijun passed away on July 21, 2020.

title: Li Jisheng
summary: Li Jisheng was a Chinese aerospace engineer born on May 31, 1943, in Jinan, Shandong. He specialized in satellite orbital dynamics and TT&C (telemetry, tracking, and command). Li graduated from Nanjing University in 1966 and was assigned to the Xi'an Satellite Control Center as a researcher. He participated in the test mission of China's first man-made satellite, Dong Fang Hong I, on April 24, 1970. Li was elected a member of the American Geophysical Society in 1985 and an academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 1997. He died on July 28, 2019, at the age of 76 in Beijing.

title: Li Kwoh-ting
summary: Li Kwoh-ting (1910-2001) was a Chinese economist and politician known as the "Father of Taiwan's Economic Miracle" for his role in transforming Taiwan's economy. Born on January 28, 1910, in Nanjing to a family from Jiangxi Province, Li excelled in mathematics and physics at an early age. He studied at National Central University and later received a scholarship to pursue doctoral studies in England at the University of Cambridge. After returning to China, Li supported the war effort and later fled to Taiwan with the Nationalist Party in 1948. He held various leadership positions, including economic minister and finance minister, and played a key role in creating Taiwan's electronics industry.

title: Li Lanni
summary: Li Lanni is a contemporary Chinese author and scriptwriter born in 1956. She attended Nanjing University, graduating from its writers class in 1989 after publishing her first work in 1981. Li received the Guangdong Province New Writers Award in 1981 and has been a member of the Chinese Writer's association since 1990. Her writing often explores difficult topics such as mental health struggles and everyday problems in modern China, earning her numerous awards including the Guangdong Luxun Award for Literature and Art. Li has also written award-winning scripts for films and TV dramas, including the series "The Story of Macau."

title: Li Lin (biochemist)
summary:
Li Lin is a Chinese biochemist and academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Born in 1961 in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, he graduated from Nanjing University with a bachelor's degree in biochemistry in 1983 and earned his Ph.D. from the Shanghai Institute of Biochemistry in 1989.

Li's research focus is on the Wnt signaling pathway. He worked as a postdoctoral researcher at the State University of New York, Stony Brook from 1990 to 1992 and was promoted to full professor in 1993. He served as director of the Shanghai Institute of Biochemistry and Cell Biology from 2004 to 2009 and became director of the Shanghai Institutes for Biological Sciences in 2013.

Li has received several awards, including the CAS Young Scientist Award and National Outstanding Young Scientist Award. He was elected as an academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2011 and is a member of the 12th National People's Congress.

title: Li Lu
summary:
Li Lu is a Chinese-born American value investor, businessman, and philanthropist. Born on April 6, 1966, in Tangshan, China, he survived the 1976 Tangshan earthquake and experienced his parents being sent to labor camps during Mao Zedong's Cultural Revolution. Li Lu was a student leader in the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests and later fled to France and then New York City, where he attended Columbia University. He earned three degrees simultaneously from Columbia: a B.A. in economics, an M.B.A., and a J.D. in 1996.

Li Lu founded Himalaya Capital in 1997, adopting a disciplined and value-oriented approach to investing. He has been influenced by investors such as Warren Buffett and Charlie Munger, who was a mentor and investor in his fund. In 2021, Li Lu co-founded The Asian American Foundation and serves as its chairman.

title: Li Peiwu
summary: Li Peiwu is a Chinese agronomist born in November 1961 in Chengwu County, Shandong. He graduated from Nanjing Agricultural University in 1986 and was subsequently offered a faculty position at the Oil Crops Research Institute (OCRI) of the Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences (CAAS). Li currently works as a researcher at OCRI, focusing on agronomy.

title: Li Quanlin
summary: Li Quanlin is a retired Chinese politician and engineer born in July 1949 in Suzhou, Jiangsu. He attended the Affiliated School of Pharmacy of Nanjing College of Pharmacy and later studied at Nanjing University, earning an MBA. Li joined the Chinese Communist Party in July 1978 and began his career in the pharmaceutical sector, holding various positions. He served as Vice Governor of Jiangsu Province from 2003 to early 2008 and later as Vice Chairman and Deputy Party Secretary of the Standing Committee of the Jiangsu Provincial People's Congress from 2008 to 2012.

title: Li Shengjiao
summary: Li Shengjiao was a senior Chinese diplomat, jurist, educator, scholar, and bilingual author. Born on January 7, 1935, in Nanjing, China, he was a renowned expert on international law and U.S.-China relations. Li made significant contributions to the International Law of the Sea, China's boundary and ocean affairs, and was recognized as an authority on international maritime law. He held various diplomatic positions, including Acting Chinese Ambassador to Barbados and First Deputy Consul General of China in Toronto. Li was known for his exceptional talent, having written antithetical couplets at age 6 and composed poems at 8. He died on August 6, 2017, in Beijing at the age of 82.

title: Li Wei (politician, born 1958)
summary: Li Wei is a Chinese politician born in January 1958, from Zhangjiagang, Jiangsu. He joined the Chinese Communist Party in July 1977 and graduated from Nanjing University with a degree in Chinese language and law. Li served as the head of the CCP Beijing Municipal Committee's Publicity Department from 2013 and chairman of the Standing Committee of the Beijing Municipal People's Congress from 2017 to 2023. He was also a delegate to the 13th National People's Congress from 2018.

title: Li Xiaomin
summary: Li Xiaomin is a Chinese politician born in May 1959 in Laiyang, Shandong province. He joined the Chinese Communist Party in 1982 and graduated from Nanjing University, majoring in European capitalism and social development history. Li has held various positions including deputy head of the Organization Department, deputy secretary-general of the provincial government, vice governor of Jiangsu, and member of the Jiangsu Provincial Party Standing Committee. He served as Secretary of the provincial Political and Legal Affairs Commission from 2011 to 2015. Li is currently serving as the Chinese Communist Party Committee Secretary of Wuxi and Vice-Chairman of the Jiangsu People's Congress.

title: Li Xiuling
summary: Li Xiuling is a Chinese political figure born in December 1962 in Tongshan, Jiangsu Province. He holds degrees from Nanjing University in history and regional studies, and a PhD in history. Li joined the Chinese Communist Party in February 1984 and began his career as a teacher at Nanjing University. He has held various positions in the government, including deputy director of the Foreign Affairs Office of Hainan Province and vice governor of the Hainan Provincial People's Government. Li has also served as secretary of the CCP Wanning Municipal Committee, deputy secretary of the Yunnan Provincial Committee of the CCP, and head of the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region CPPCC. In January 2023, he was appointed Party Secretary and Director of the Standing Committee of the Beijing Municipal People's Congress.

title: Linggu Temple
summary: Linggu Temple is a famous Buddhist temple located in Nanjing, China. It was first built in 515 during the Liang dynasty and initially lay at the foot of Purple Mountain. The temple was later moved to its current location by the Hongwu Emperor and rebuilt after being destroyed in warfare during the Qing dynasty. The temple grounds feature several notable structures, including Wuliang Hall, a beamless hall constructed in 1381 without the use of wood or nails. The temple also houses a Three Superb Tablet, featuring works by renowned artists and poets from the Tang dynasty.

title: Liu Dan (artist)
summary: Liu Dan is a Chinese artist born in 1953. He studied traditional Chinese painting under Ya Ming at the Academy of Chinese Painting, Hangzhou from 1978 to 1981. After moving to Hawaii in 1981, Liu Dan studied Western art and developed a distinctive style combining classical Chinese painting with photo-realism. He later moved to New York in 1992, where he interacted with notable Chinese artists such as Ai Weiwei and Xu Bing. In 2006, Liu Dan returned to China to mentor young artists.

title: Liu Dongsheng
summary: Liu Dongsheng, also known as Tung-sheng Liu, was a Chinese geologist born in 1917 and died in 2008. He was a renowned researcher in paleontology, Quaternary geology, and environmental geology. Liu graduated from National Southwestern Associated University in 1942 and later studied at Nanjing University from 1946 to 1949. He was elected an academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 1980 and received several notable awards, including the Tyler Prize for Environmental Achievement in 2002 and the State Preeminent Science and Technology Award in 2003. Liu was also a member of the Third World Academy of Sciences since 1991.

title: Liu Haihong
summary: Liu Haihong is a Chinese politician born in November 1974 in Shuyang, Jiangsu. She joined the Chinese Communist Party in July 2000 and holds a master's degree in law from Nanjing University. Liu has held various positions, including county magistrate of Siyang County and Party Secretary of Suyu District. She served as a member of the Standing Committee of the Suqian Municipal Party Committee from 2021 to 2025. In February 2025, Liu was appointed deputy minister of the Jiangsu Provincial Department of Social Work and secretary of the Party Committee of the Jiangsu Provincial Comprehensive Committee for Social Organizations.

title: Liu Hua (politician, born 1961)
summary: Liu Hua is a Chinese legal scholar and politician born in May 1961 in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province. She studied at East China University of Political Science and Law and the China University of Political Science and Law, earning a Master of Law degree. Liu began her career as a researcher at the Institute of Law in 1986 and held various positions, including Vice President of the Shanghai High People's Court and Director of the Shanghai Municipal People's Government Legal Affairs Office. In 2016, she was appointed Chief Prosecutor of the Jiangsu Provincial People's Procuratorate and Chinese Communist Party Committee Secretary. Liu currently serves as President of the China Association of Women Prosecutors and is a delegate to the 13th National People's Congress.

title: Liu Shouren
summary: Liu Shouren was a Chinese engineer specializing in wool and an academician of the Chinese Academy of Engineering. Born on 21 March 1934, in Gushan, Jingjiang, Jiangsu, he was hailed as the "Father of Chinese Fine Wool Sheep". Liu attended Zhejiang University and later Nanjing Agricultural College, where he studied animal husbandry. He joined the Chinese Communist Party in 1960 and held various positions, including president of Xinjiang Agriculture Academy from 1988 to 1995. Liu died on 11 June 2023, at the age of 89, in Shihezi, Xinjiang.

title: Liu Wei (footballer)
summary: Liu Wei is a Chinese professional footballer born on January 7, 1993. He plays as a centre-back for Nantong Zhiyun in the Chinese Super League and captains the team. Liu received his bachelor's degree of administration from Nanjing University in 2015 and began his professional football career with Jiangsu Sainty's reserve team. He made his debut for Jiangsu Suning in the 2016 AFC Champions League against Becamex Bình Dương on February 23, 2016. Liu transferred to Nantong Zhiyun in March 2018 and helped the team gain promotion to the top tier by the end of the 2022 China League One season.

title: Liu Xianjue
summary: Liu Xianjue was a Chinese architectural historian and educator born on 12 December 1931 in Fuzhou, Fujian. He studied under the "Four Modern Masters in Architecture" of China and taught at Southeast University for over 50 years. Liu advocated for the protection of architectural heritage in Nanjing and advised the government of Macau on its successful application for World Heritage status for the Historic Centre of Macau. He published 30 books and over 100 papers, advised numerous students, and received several awards for his contributions to architecture. Liu died on 16 May 2019 at the age of 87 in Nanjing, China.

title: Liu Xin (news anchor)
summary: Liu Xin is a Chinese journalist and host for the China Global Television Network (CGTN). Born on November 10, 1975, in Zhenjiang, Jiangsu, China, she is fluent in Mandarin, English, and French, and conversational in German and Turkish. Liu attended Nanjing University from 1993 to 1997, majoring in English language and literature. She won the International Public Speaking Competition in London in 1996, becoming the first Chinese student to do so. Liu has worked as a journalist and anchorwoman for CCTV, serving as the Geneva Bureau Chief from 2011 to 2017. She currently hosts the opinion show "The Point with Liu Xin" on CGTN.

title: Liu Yongtan
summary: Liu Yongtan is a Chinese electrical engineer born on December 1, 1936, in Nanjing, Jiangsu. He is a member of the Chinese Academy of Sciences and Chinese Academy of Engineering. Liu studied at Harbin Institute of Technology, Tsinghua University, and pursued advanced studies in radar technology at the University of Birmingham and University of Essex. He was elected an academician of both academies in 1991 and 1994, respectively. Liu received the 2018 Highest Science and Technology Award in 2019 for his contributions to science.

title: Long Xiang
summary: Long Xiang is a former Chinese politician born in June 1963 in Nanjing, Jiangsu. He joined the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) in January 1983 and graduated from Henan University with a major in Chinese language and literature in July 1984. Long held various positions, including deputy party secretary of Nanjing from November 2003 and party secretary from July 2010. He served as chairperson of the Nanjing Municipal People's Congress from January 2018 until his investigation began. As of April 2025, Long was under investigation by China's top anti-graft watchdog for alleged "serious violations of discipline and laws."

title: Longpao Subdistrict
summary: Longpao Subdistrict is a subdistrict in Luhe District, Nanjing, Jiangsu province, China. It has administrative control over 6 residential communities and 5 villages as of 2018. The subdistrict is located in Jiangsu province, China. Longpao Subdistrict falls under the jurisdiction of Luhe District in Nanjing city. This article is a stub and requires further expansion for more information.

title: Lu Kang (diplomat)
summary: Lu Kang is a Chinese diplomat born on May 14, 1968, in Nanjing, Jiangsu. He joined the Foreign Service in 1993 and has held various diplomatic posts, including serving as a consultant and attaché at the UN headquarters in New York City from 1996 to 1999. Lu has also served as the Chinese ambassador to Indonesia from 2022 to 2024 and was previously director of the Department of North American and Oceanian Affairs of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. He has made public comments on various international issues, including the Sino-Russian Treaty of Friendship and the Syrian Civil War. As of May 2024, Lu is serving as a deputy minister of the International Department of the Chinese Communist Party.

title: Lu Shaye
summary:
Lu Shaye is a Chinese diplomat born in October 1964 in Nanjing, Jiangsu. He graduated from the China Foreign Affairs University and joined the Chinese foreign service in 1987. Lu has held various diplomatic positions, including Ambassador to Senegal (2005-2009), Canada (2017-2019), and France/Monaco (2019-2025). He is known for his combative remarks as a "wolf warrior diplomat." 

Lu has also served in other roles, including Deputy Director-General of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Department of African Affairs and Vice Mayor of Wuhan. In 2023, he became a member of the 14th National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference. In February 2025, Lu was appointed as the Special Representative of the Chinese Government for European Affairs.

title: Luhe-Ma'an Air Base
summary: Luhe-Ma'an Air Base, also known as Nanjing Luhe Airport or Nanjing Air Base, is a military airport in suburban Luhe District of Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China. It replaced the old Dajiaochang Airport in 2015 and is home to the Nanjing Air Base of the People's Liberation Army Air Force. The air base hosts the 29th and 30th Bomber Regiments of the 10th Bomber Division, equipped with H-6K bombers. Construction on Luhe Airport began in 2012 and it was opened in July 2015, with Dajiaochang Airport closing on the same day. The site was determined in 2006 and received approvals from the State Council and Central Military Commission in 2009.

title: Luo Yimin
summary: Luo Yimin is a retired Chinese politician born in February 1954, in Lianshui County, Jiangsu Province. He joined the Chinese Communist Party in December 1976 and began his career at Xuzhou Second Machinery Plant in December 1970. Luo pursued higher education, studying Chinese language and literature at Nanjing University from 1977 to 1980. He held various leadership positions, including Party Secretary of Nantong from 2002 to 2011 and Vice Chairman of the CPPCC Jiangsu Provincial Committee from 2011 to 2017. Luo resigned as Vice Chairman in February 2017, due to reaching the mandatory retirement age.

title: Lyu Jian
summary:
Lyu Jian, also known as Lu Jian, is a Chinese computer scientist and academic administrator. Born in 1960 in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China, he studied Computer Science at Nanjing University and received his bachelor's degree in 1983, master's degree in 1984, and Ph.D. in 1988.

Lyu Jian served as President of Nanjing University from 2018 to 2023 and held various positions within the university, including vice president since 2010. He has conducted research in computer software and related fields, receiving several awards for his work, including the Natural Science award and Technological Invention award from the Ministry of Education, China. He was elected as a member of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2013.

title: Ma Ainong
summary: Ma Ainong is a Chinese translator of literary works, particularly children's literature from English. Born in September 1964 in Nanjing, Jiangsu, she comes from a family with a background in translation and editing. Her grandfather Ma Qinghuai was also a translator, while her sister Ma Aixin translates children's literature and their parents are editors. Ma Ainong graduated from Nanjing University in 1986 with a major in English and later worked as an English teacher at Nanjing Medical University. She then pursued postgraduate studies at Beijing Foreign Studies University, graduating in 1993 and later working as an editor.

title: Ma Zhencheng
summary: Ma Zhencheng was a Chinese translator born in March 1934 in Shanghai. He is notable for being the first person to translate The Little Prince into Chinese and was praised as its best translator. Ma graduated from Nanjing University with a major in French language and literature, later teaching at various institutions including Beijing Institute of Light Industry and Shanghai Second Medical University. He began translating French literary works in 1980, including the works of Michel de Montaigne, Milan Kundera, André Gide, and Marguerite Duras. Ma pursued advanced studies in France at the age of 56. He died on November 17, 2025, at the age of 91.

title: Maji, Luhe District
summary: Maji Town (马集镇) is a town located in the Luhe District of Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China. It lies in the northern part of the district and has a population of approximately 44,000 residents. The town comprises 20 villages within its administrative area.

title: Mao Dehua
summary: Mao Dehua was a Chinese geographer and politician. Born in November 1935 in Taicang, Jiangsu, Republic of China, he graduated from Nanjing University with a degree in natural geography in 1957. Mao began working for the Xinjiang branch of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) in 1958 and held various positions, including Director of the CAS Xinjiang branch from July 1984. He also served as Vice Chairman of Xinjiang Autonomous Region and Vice Chairman of the Xinjiang Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC). Mao died on 26 January 2019, at the age of 83.

title: Mao Rubai
summary: Mao Rubai is a Chinese politician born in May 1938 in Yangzhou, Jiangsu. He studied at Yangzhou High School and Nanjing University, majoring in Meteorology. Mao joined the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) in November 1959 and held various positions, including director of the Meteorological Bureau of Tibet Autonomous Region from 1980 to 1984. He served as party secretary of Ningxia from 1997 to 2002 and chairman of the National People's Congress Environment Protection and Resources Conservation Committee from 2003 to 2008. Mao was a member of the 15th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party and a delegate to the 9th National People's Congress.

title: Mao Zhi
summary: Mao Zhi was a Chinese engineer specializing in hydraulics and an academician of the Chinese Academy of Engineering. Born on 20 September 1932 in Nanjing, Jiangsu, Mao's family was displaced during the Second Sino-Japanese War and eventually settled in Hechuan County, Sichuan. Mao graduated from East China Water Conservancy Institute (now Hohai University) in 1953 and went on to teach at various institutions, including Hebei Agricultural University and Wuhan Institute of Water Resources (now College of Water Resources and Hydropower, Wuhan University). Mao joined the Chinese Communist Party in 1988. He died on 13 January 2023 at the age of 90 in Wuhan, Hubei.

title: Mary Twinem
summary: Mary Dorothy Fine Twinem was an American missionary and schoolteacher born on April 8, 1895, in Trenton, New Jersey. She obtained a Bachelor of Arts from Hartford College and a Master's degree from New York University before arriving in China as a Presbyterian missionary in 1919. Twinem worked at Jinling University and Ginling College, where she managed refugee camps during the Second Sino-Japanese War. She collaborated with Soong Mei-ling and Minnie Vautrin in her humanitarian efforts. After the war, Twinem relocated to Taiwan, where she taught at the Huaxing Nursery School until her death on September 9, 1983.

title: May-lee Chai
summary: May-lee Chai is an American author of fiction and nonfiction, as well as a professor of creative writing at San Francisco State University. Her notable works include novels such as My Lucky Face, Dragon Chica and its sequel Tiger Girl, for which she won the 2014 Asian/Pacific American Award for Literature. Chai has also written nonfiction books, including the family memoir The Girl from Purple Mountain and Hapa Girl, which explores her mixed-race family's experiences in a small Midwestern town. Her writing has been recognized with several awards, including the 2008 Notable Book Kiriyama Prize and a Honorable Mention from the Gustavus Myers Center for the Study of Bigotry and Human Rights. Chai has also published a collection of short stories, Useful Phrases for Immigrants: Stories, which won the 2018 Bakwin Award for Writing by a Woman.

title: Mei-Fu Zhou
summary: Mei-Fu Zhou is a Chinese geologist. He graduated from Nanjing University in 1983 and pursued further education in Canada, earning a master's degree from the University of Saskatchewan in 1992 and a doctorate from Dalhousie University in 1995. Zhou began teaching at the University of Hong Kong in 1996. He is a fellow of the Geological Society of America and serves as the chief editor of the Journal of Asian Earth Sciences.

title: Meiling Palace
summary: Meiling Palace, also known as Meiling Villa and Meiling Gong, is a large villa in Nanjing, China. It was built by Chiang Kai-Shek for his wife Soong Meiling in 1934 as the National Government Chairman Residence. The villa is located below Purple Mountain, about 6 km from Nanjing's city centre, and has a floor area of over 2,000 square meters. The exterior is built in traditional Chinese style with double eaves and a roof of green glazed tiles, while the interior is in Western style. The villa features various decorations and exhibits, including paintings by Soong Meiling and a private chapel on the second floor.

title: Memorial Hall of the Victims in Nanjing Massacre by Japanese Invaders
summary: The Memorial Hall of the Victims in Nanjing Massacre by Japanese Invaders is a museum located in downtown Nanjing, China. It was built in 1985 by the Nanjing Municipal Government to memorialize the victims of the Nanjing Massacre, which occurred in December 1937 when the Imperial Japanese Army occupied the city. The massacre resulted in an estimated 300,000 civilian and unarmed soldier deaths, with numerous atrocities committed including rape, arson, looting, torture, and mass executions. The museum features outdoor exhibits, sheltered skeletal remains of victims, and an exhibition hall with historical documents. It occupies a total area of approximately 28,000 square meters and admission is free but requires prior registration.

title: Memorial Hall of the Victims in Nanjing Massacre by Japanese Invaders
summary: The Memorial Hall of the Victims in Nanjing Massacre by Japanese Invaders is a museum located in downtown Nanjing, China. It was built in 1985 by the Nanjing Municipal Government to memorialize the victims of the Nanjing Massacre, which occurred in December 1937 when the Imperial Japanese Army occupied the city. The massacre resulted in an estimated 300,000 civilian and unarmed soldier deaths, with numerous atrocities committed including rape, arson, looting, torture, and mass executions. The museum features outdoor exhibits, sheltered skeletal remains of victims, and an exhibition hall with historical documents. It occupies a total area of approximately 28,000 square meters and admission is free but requires prior registration.

title: Miao Ruilin
summary: Miao Ruilin is a former Chinese politician born in November 1964 in Rudong County, Jiangsu. He graduated from the Jiangsu Agricultural College with a bachelor's degree in agriculture and a doctorate in land management. Miao served in various government roles, including chief of the Jiangsu Agricultural Resources Development Bureau and Mayor of Nanjing from 2014 to 2018. In November 2018, he was placed under investigation by the Chinese Communist Party's anti-corruption agency for serious violations of laws and regulations. Miao was expelled from the Party, dismissed from office, and sentenced to 10 years and 6 months in prison for taking bribes of 7.2 million yuan ($99,700) by the Qingdao Intermediate People's Court in November 2019.

title: Michelle Wang
summary: Michelle Dong Wang is a Chinese-American physicist and the James Gilbert White Distinguished Professor of Physical Sciences at Cornell University. She is an Investigator of the Howard Hughes Medical Institute and a Fellow of the American Physical Society (2009) and the Biophysical Society (2024). Wang's research focuses on biomolecular motors, single molecule optical trapping techniques, and the interactions between histones and DNA in nucleosomes. She has developed several structural probes, including angular optical trapping, DNA unzipping, and nanophotonics. Wang earned her undergraduate degree in nuclear physics from Nanjing University, a doctorate in physics from the Chinese Academy of Sciences, and completed additional graduate studies at the University of Southern Mississippi and the University of Michigan.

title: Min Enze
summary: Min Enze was a Chinese chemical engineer and chemist born on 4 February 1924 in Chengdu, Sichuan, China. He graduated from National Central University (Nanjing University) in 1946 and obtained his doctor's degree from Ohio State University in the United States in 1951. Min was an expert in petrochemical catalysis and held various academic positions, including being elected as an academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 1980 and the Chinese Academy of Engineering in 1994. He received the Highest Science and Technology Award in 2007, China's most prestigious scientific prize. Min Enze died on 7 March 2016 at the age of 92 in Beijing, and an asteroid is named in his honor.

title: Min Naiben
summary: Min Naiben, also known as Nai-Ben Ming, was a Chinese materials scientist, physicist, and politician. Born on August 9, 1935, in Rugao, Jiangsu, he graduated from Shanghai Advanced Mechanical Vocational School in 1954 and later studied at Nanjing University. Min held various academic positions, including associate visiting professor at the University of Utah and guest professor at Tohoku University. He was elected an academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 1991 and a fellow of The World Academy of Sciences in 2001. Min joined the Jiusan Society in 1995 and served as a Standing Committee member of its Central Committee. He died on September 16, 2018, in Nanjing, Jiangsu.

title: Min Zhu (paleontologist)
summary: Min Zhu is a Chinese paleontologist born in October 1965. He is affiliated with the Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology (IVPP), a CAS Member. Zhu completed his undergraduate studies at Nanjing University and earned his PhD from IVPP. He currently leads a research team at IVPP, contributing to the discovery of new fossil depositories that shed light on the evolution of jawed vertebrates.

title: Miner Searle Bates
summary:
Miner Searle Bates was an American scholar born in 1897 and died in 1978. He held the Chinese name Bei Deshi ( 贝德士). Bates was educated at prestigious institutions including the University of Oxford and Yale University, where he earned a Ph.D. in Chinese history.

Bates worked at the University of Nanking from 1920 to 1950, teaching history and later becoming Vice President in 1938. During the Battle of Nanking in 1937, he led the International Committee for the Nanking Safety Zone and risked his life to secure the safety of the remaining population. After the war, he testified at the Tokyo Trials and Chinese trials for war criminals.

Bates wrote Religious Liberty: An Inquiry (1945) and was appointed Professor of Missions at Union Theological Seminary from 1950 to 1965. He is quoted as saying that genuine regard for all members of the human family will save mankind, not national guns or gods.

title: Ming Fan
summary: Ming Fan is a senior investigative TV producer at China Central TV and an independent documentary filmmaker. She has focused on covering complex issues in China, including environmental protection and social problems. Her documentary "Under the Dome" (2015) about air pollution in China was watched by 300 million people and improved China's environmental policy. The film has been included in the Global Environmental Justice Documentaries Project and was hailed as China's "Silent Spring" moment. Fan has received various fellowships, including the Asia Journalism Fellowship in 2010 and a Mason Fellow at Harvard Kennedy School. She has also been selected as a visiting scholar and adjunct assistant professor at Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.

title: Ming Palace
summary: The Ming Palace, also known as the Forbidden City of Nanjing, was a 14th-century imperial palace in Nanjing, China. It served as the capital of the early Ming dynasty from 1368 to 1420, when Nanjing was the southern capital of China. The palace was built by Zhu Yuanzhang, the founder and first Emperor of the Ming dynasty, in 1367-1368. After the capital was moved to Beijing in 1420, Nanjing's palace retained its status as a "reserve" capital and was gradually damaged by fires. The palace briefly served as the seat of the Southern Ming dynasty in 1644, but was eventually demolished by the Qing dynasty.

title: Mingming Wu
summary: Mingming Wu is a professor at Cornell University's Department of Biological and Environmental Engineering. She earned her bachelor's degree from Nanjing University in 1984 and completed her doctorate at Ohio State University in 1992. Wu joined the Cornell faculty in 2003 and was named a fellow of the American Physical Society in 2016. Her research focuses on understanding how physical forces regulate cell migration and developing micro-scale tools to study cellular environments. Wu's work has applications in health, particularly in tumor invasion and development, as well as environmental issues such as algal blooms.

title: Minnie Vautrin
summary:
Wilhelmina "Minnie" Vautrin was an American missionary, educator, and president of Ginling College in China. Born on September 27, 1886, in Secor, Illinois, Vautrin spent 28 years as a Christian missionary in China before returning to the United States in May 1940. During World War II, she protected and cared for at least 10,000 Chinese refugees in the Nanking Safety Zone during the Nanjing Massacre. Vautrin was awarded the Order of the Blue Jade by the Chinese government for her humanitarian work.

Vautrin's life was marked by personal struggles, including being sent to foster homes after her mother's death at a young age. She excelled in school and eventually became a teacher, graduating first in her class from Illinois State Normal University. Vautrin went on to become a missionary, working with the Foreign Christian Missionary Society in China. She kept a diary during the Nanjing Massacre, which was later published.

Vautrin's humanitarian work and bravery during World War II have been recognized, but her personal struggles continued after she returned to the United States. She committed suicide in 1941 due to extreme stress and trauma from her experiences during the Nanjing Massacre.

title: Mochou Lake
summary: Mochou Lake is a lake located in Nanjing, China, inside Mochou Lake Park. The park was originally owned by Zhu Yuanzhang, the first emperor of the Ming dynasty, and was later bestowed to his general Xu Da. The lake is named after Mochou, a legendary woman known for her beauty and loyalty, who either committed suicide to prevent an undesirable marriage or turned into a lake in search of her husband. The park features various pavilions, gardens, pools, and a stunning rock display, including the two-storied Shengqi Pavilion. Mochou Lake Park has undergone several restorations, including a major renovation in 1953. The park covers an area of 47 hectares and has a circumference of 5 km, making it a popular tourist destination in Nanjing.

title: Mochtar Riady
summary: Mochtar Riady, born Lie Mo Tie on May 12, 1929, is an Indonesian financial magnate and founder of Lippo Group. He was born in Malang to a Chinese-Indonesian family and spent his early childhood in Fujian, China. Riady's parents, Liapi and Sibelau, were batik traders who migrated from Fujian to Malang in 1918. His father, Liapi, was born in 1887 and passed away in 1959, while his mother, Sibelau, was born in 1889 and passed away in 1937.

title: Modern Express Post
summary: The Modern Express Post, also known as Xiandai Kuaibao or Modern Express News, is a Nanjing-based Chinese-language metropolitan newspaper published in China. It was formerly known as Deal Post, sponsored by the Jiangsu Branch of Xinhua News Agency in 1993.
