The newspaper was renamed Modern Economic Post in 1994 and then to its current name, Modern Express Post, on October 12, 1999. The National Press and Publication Administration of China approved the name change. Modern Express Post is a metropolitan newspaper published in China, with its headquarters based in Nanjing.

title: Nanjing Agricultural University
summary: Nanjing Agricultural University is a public university located in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It was established as the Agriculture Section of Sanjiang Teacher's College in 1902 and has its predecessors in the College of Agriculture of Jinling University and National Central University. The university was renamed several times, including Nanjing Agricultural College in 1979 and Nanjing Agricultural University in 1984. It is affiliated with the Ministry of Education, co-sponsored by the Ministry of Education and Jiangsu Provincial Government. The university is part of Project 211 and the Double First-Class Construction, and was identified as one of China's key agricultural colleges in the 1960s.

title: Nanjing Amity Printing
summary: Nanjing Amity Printing Co., Ltd. is the largest producer of Bibles in China and one of the world's largest. It is a joint venture between Amity Foundation, United Bible Societies, and was established in 1988. In its first year, the company printed 500,000 Bibles on a press donated by UBS. Since then, it has published over 100 million Bibles in various languages, including Mandarin and ethnic minority languages. The company is China's only legal printer of Bibles and distributes them through officially registered Protestant churches, not state-run bookstore chains.

title: Nanjing Ange Pharmaceutical
summary: Nanjing Ange Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd. is a pharmaceutical company based in Nanjing, China. Founded in 2003, it specializes in developing "New Drugs" and researching, producing, and trading chemical APIs and pharmaceutical intermediates. The company has established cooperative relationships with major universities in Nanjing, including China Pharmaceutical University. Its main products are Antineoplastic medicines and related pharmaceutical intermediates. Nanjing Ange has collaborated with companies such as Abbott Laboratories Ltd. and Simcere Pharmaceutical Group in recent years.

title: Nanjing anti-African protests
summary:
The Nanjing anti-African protests occurred from December 1988 to January 1989 in Nanjing, China. The protests began after a brawl between African and Chinese students at Hohai University on December 24, 1988. The incident involved a dispute over two Chinese women that African students were trying to bring onto campus, leading to a fight between the groups. 

The brawl escalated into mass demonstrations and riots, with 300 Chinese students destroying African dormitories and setting fire to one. The authorities eventually dispersed the protesters, but not before they had marched on the railway station and called for human rights and political reform. 

The protests resulted in the deportation of three African students, who were accused of starting the brawl, and the implementation of new regulations for foreign students at Hohai University. The protests also spread to other cities, including Shanghai and Beijing, marking a significant moment of dissidence in China.

title: Nanjing Audit University
summary: Nanjing Audit University (NAU) is a national public university in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. Founded in 1983, it is affiliated with the Province of Jiangsu and co-sponsored by several government agencies. The university offers courses in economics, management, law, languages, literature, science, and engineering to over 15,000 students on two campuses. NAU specializes in areas such as e-commerce and has an affiliation with the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA) since 1998. It is one of the first institutions to offer courses in e-commerce and promotes international Certified Public Accountants (CPAs).

title: Nanjing Baguazhou Yangtze River Bridge
summary: The Nanjing Baguazhou Yangtze River Bridge is a cable-stayed bridge over the Yangtze River in Nanjing, China. Spanning 628 meters, it carries traffic on the G36 Nanjing–Luoyang Expressway and China National Highway 104. Upon completion in 2001, it was the third longest cable-stayed span worldwide. As of 2013, it remains among the 20 longest spans globally. The bridge connects Qixia District to Bagua Island, crossing the Yangtze River. It was renamed on December 20, 2019.

title: Nanjing Botanical Garden, Memorial Sun Yat-Sen
summary: Nanjing Botanical Garden Memorial Sun Yat-Sen is a national botanical garden in China, established in 1929. It was the first of its kind in China and is located in the eastern suburbs of Nanjing, covering 1.86 square kilometers. The garden has a living collection of approximately 3,000 species and holds over 700,000 sheets of botanical specimens. It serves as a research center for central and northern subtropical floras, with five research departments and ten featured gardens. The garden has established exchange programs with over 600 organizations worldwide, including the Missouri Botanical Garden in the USA.

title: Nanjing Brain Bay
summary: Nanjing Brain Bay, also known as Nanjing Brain Bay International Talent Community, is a development area in Nanjing. It was launched with a ceremony held in December 2020. The area is divided into four zones: Jianye District, Jiangbei District, Jiangning District, and Zidong core area.

title: Nanjing City F.C.
summary: Nanjing City Football Club is a Chinese professional football club based in Nanjing, Jiangsu. The team competes in China League One, the second tier of Chinese football, and plays its home matches at Wutaishan Stadium. Founded on December 29, 2014 as Nanjing Fengfan F.C., the club initially participated in youth football training and local leagues. After completing Chinese Football Association registration, Nanjing Fengfan F.C. began competing in the Chinese football pyramid in 2018. The team changed its name to Nanjing City in January 2021 after achieving promotion to China League Two.

title: Nanjing Communication College
summary: Nanjing Communication College is a private undergraduate college in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It was previously known as Communication University of China, Nanjing from 2004 to 2020. The college was established through a licensing contract between the private Nanjing Meiya Education Investment Limited Company and the Communication University of China. In 2008, the Ministry of Education required independent colleges to change their names and in 2020, the Jiangsu Provincial People's Government renamed it Nanjing Communication College. The college has no affiliation with the Communication University of China in Beijing and is currently owned by Huaxia Group Holdings Limited Company.

title: Nanjing County
summary: Nanjing County is a county in the south of Fujian province, People's Republic of China. It is under the administration of Zhangzhou City and is divided into several towns, including Shuyang and Meilin. The county is home to many famous Fujian Tulou, with four sites listed on UNESCO's World Heritage list. Nanjing County gained its first railway connection in 2012 with the opening of the Longyan–Xiamen Railway. The county has two railway stations: Nanjing Station and Longshan, serving the eastern and northern parts of the county.

title: Nanjing Daily
summary: The Nanjing Daily is the official newspaper of the Nanjing Municipal Committee of the Chinese Communist Party. Established on March 15, 1956, it initially launched as a four-page newspaper but ceased publication in February 1961. The newspaper was re-established on January 1, 1978, as the Nanjing Newsletter before reverting to its original title of Nanjing Daily on July 2, 1979. It underwent a conversion to a large folio format in January 1986 and began publishing weekly on Wednesdays from October 1992. The newspaper received recognition in 2018 as one of the top 100 newspapers in China for 2017.

title: Nanjing Dajiaochang Airport
summary:
Nanjing Dajiaochang Airport was a military air base and former commercial airport in Nanjing, Jiangsu province, China. It was located 6.2 kilometers south of the city center and surrounded by the Qinhuai River. The airport was first built in 1931 as a training ground for the Central Aviation School of China and later converted into a military air base in 1934. 

During World War II, the airport served as a primary air force base for the Chinese Air Force. After the war, it was expanded several times and became a dual-use military and public airport in 1956. However, with the opening of Nanjing Lukou International Airport in 1997, all commercial flights were transferred to the new airport. 

Dajiaochang Airport remained in use as a military air base until 2015, when it was closed and replaced by Nanjing Luhe Airport. The airport's historic runway will be conserved as a public open space, and the terminal building and air traffic control tower still exist today.

title: Nanjing Dashengguan Yangtze River Bridge
summary: The Nanjing Dashengguan Yangtze River Bridge is a cable-stayed bridge located in Nanjing, China. It spans the Yangtze River and is part of a 4.7 kilometer long bridge, featuring dual 215 meter steel towers and a main span of 648 meters. Constructed at a cost of $490 million, the bridge was completed in 2005 and initially held the title of third longest cable-stayed span in the world. The bridge carries the G42 Shanghai–Chengdu Expressway and the G2503 Nanjing Ring Expressway. It features an orthotropic box girder deck supported by 168 stay cables, each formed from multiple wires.

title: Nanjing decade
summary: The Nanjing decade, also known as the Golden decade, was a period in the Republic of China from 1927 to 1937. It began when Nationalist Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek took Nanjing from warlord Sun Chuanfang in 1927, declaring it the national capital. The decade ended with the outbreak of the Second Sino-Japanese War in 1937 and saw significant economic growth, with an average GDP increase of 3.9% per year from 1929 to 1941. Historians view the decade as a period of Chinese conservatism, marked by both progress and frustration, including stability, economic growth, and the start of ambitious government projects, but also suppression of dissent, corruption, and internal conflicts. The Nationalist government struggled to address widespread unrest and protests over their failure to check Japanese aggression.

title: Nanjing dialect
summary: The Nanjing dialect, also known as Nanjingese or Nankingese, is the prestige dialect of Mandarin Chinese spoken in urban Nanjing, Jiangsu province. It belongs to the Jianghuai group of Chinese varieties and has distinct features such as maintaining the glottal stop final, entering tone, and retroflex initials. The dialect has lost syllable-initial /n/, which have become /l/. It also features a merged nasal final, where /n/ and /ŋ/ have become one sound. The Nanjing dialect has been influenced by various historical events, including the migration of people from northern China and Central Asia. The dialect has undergone changes over time, with old Nanjing dialect mostly found in old communities and new Nanjing dialect being the variety most frequently spoken today.

title: Nanjing Dinghuaimen Yangtze River Tunnel
summary: The Nanjing Dinghuaimen Yangtze River Tunnel is a set of two tunnels under the Yangtze River in Nanjing, China. It connects the Gulou District to Jiangbei New District in Nanjing. Construction began in 2010 and was completed with the tunnel breaking through in 2015. The tunnel opened on January 1, 2016, and was renamed from the Nanjing Yangzijiang Tunnel to its current name on December 20, 2019.

title: Nanjing Economic and Technological Development Zone
summary:
Nanjing Economic and Technological Development Zone (Nanjing ETDZ) is a state-level economic and technological development zone in Qixia District, Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China. Established on September 18, 1992, it was upgraded to a national-level development zone in March 2002. The zone covers an area of 200 km² and is divided into four main sub-zones: Xinguang, Qixia, Longtan, and LCD Valley. 

Nanjing ETDZ has developed rapidly with significant improvements in infrastructure and investment attraction, achieving a total industrial output of ¥371.1 billion by 2015 and ¥345.56 billion by 2023. The zone houses key enterprises, including optoelectronic displays, integrated circuits, biomedicine, and new energy vehicles. It was designated one of the first China–Japan–South Korea (Jiangsu) Industrial Cooperation Demonstration Parks in February 2021.

title: Nanjing Financial City II
summary: Nanjing Financial City II is a mixed-use skyscraper complex in Jianye District, Nanjing, China. The complex consists of five towers and was built between 2019 and 2025. Tower 1, the tallest at 416.6 meters (88 floors), is currently the second-tallest building in Nanjing, after the Zifeng Tower. The complex spans a total area of 798,000 square meters and features diverse mixed uses, including office units, a five-star hotel with 250 rooms, and serviced apartments. The complex was topped out in January 2024.

title: Nanjing Foreign Language School
summary: Nanjing Foreign Language School (NFLS) is a municipal public secondary school in Xuanwu, Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It is managed by the Nanjing City Education Bureau. The school was founded in 1963. As of 2019, NFLS has established several branch schools in Nanjing and around Jiangsu Province.

title: Nanjing Forestry University
summary: Nanjing Forestry University (NJFU) is a provincial public university in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It is affiliated with the Province of Jiangsu and part of the Double First-Class Construction. The university originated from the Forest Departments of Jinling University and Central University, later merging with other institutions to form Nanjing Forestry College in 1952. The college underwent name changes, becoming Nanjing Technological College of Forest Products in 1972 and adopting its current name in 1985. NJFU has hosted 23 international symposia and conferences, with academic publications including the Journal of Nanjing Forestry University and China Forestry Science and Technology.

title: Nanjing Fuxing metro station
summary: Nanjing Fuxing is a metro station in Taipei, Taiwan served by the Taipei Metro. It is a transfer station between the Wenhu line and Songshan–Xindian line, located at the intersection of Fuxing North Rd. and Nanjing East Rd. The station has two side platforms, one island platform, and eight exits with three wheelchair-accessible platforms. It connects to various landmarks such as Taipei Arena and Taipei Municipal Stadium. The Green Line station has a theme of "Reflective Mosaic of Light" and features artworks throughout the station.

title: Nanjing Fuzimiao
summary: Nanjing Fuzimiao, also known as the Confucius Temple, is a historic temple complex located in southern Nanjing City on the banks of the Qinhuai River. It was initially founded as Nanking Imperial University in 317 CE and later became a Confucius Temple. The temple was destroyed multiple times throughout history, with the current buildings dating back to the 19th century. In 1985, the Fuzimiao area was restored and is now a popular tourist attraction with pedestrian shopping streets surrounding the temple. The complex has been a place of study for Confucianism and was officially approved as China's first 5A open-style scenic spot in 2010.

title: Nanjing General Hospital of People's Liberation Army
summary: Nanjing General Hospital of People's Liberation Army (NGH) is a comprehensive teaching hospital located at 305 Zhongshan East Road, Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China. It is a large hospital integrating medical services with teaching and research, serving as the Department of Clinical Medicine of the Medical School, Nanjing University. NGH has been ranked in the top 10 among hospitals nationwide for 10 successive years and was second for four years on end. The hospital's history dates back to the Central Model Army Hospital established in 1929, which was later renamed National Central Hospital and played a significant role during the Second Sino-Japanese War. After the war, parts of the hospital were relocated to different cities, and it underwent several name changes before becoming the Nanjing General Hospital of People's Liberation Army.

title: Nanjing General Military Hospital
summary: The Nanjing General Military Hospital is located in twin towers that originally served as the Central Hospital of Nanjing. The hospital was constructed in 1929 during the Kuomintang government. One tower houses the Research Institute of Nephrology, while the other is home to the Research Institute of General Surgery. The Central Hospital was targeted by Japanese bombs during the Battle of Nanking in 1937, despite having a large red cross painted on its roof. The hospital's original buildings date back to the 1920s, with a history tied to the city of Nanjing.

title: Nanjing Great Hall of the People
summary:
The Nanjing Great Hall of the People is a building located in Xuanwu District, Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China. It serves as the Jiangsu Provincial People's Congress and the National Theatre of Drama and Music and Art Gallery. The building was originally constructed in 1936 as the National Great Hall, with a gross floor area of 5,100 square meters and four stories made of reinforced concrete. The design emphasizes vertical lines with simplicity and modernism, featuring simplified traditional Chinese patterns in its decorations.

The building was designed by Xi Fuquan and supervised by Li Zongkan, with a construction cost awarded to the Shanghai Construction Factory of Lugen's Engineering Office. The hall features over 3,400 seats and is equipped with modern amenities such as automatic voting systems, translation devices, and air conditioning. The National Art Gallery is located opposite the hall, sharing a similar style as an integral whole.

title: Nanjing incident (1976)
summary: The Nanjing Incident, also known as the Nanjing Anti-Cultural Revolution Force Movement, was a movement that took place in Nanjing, China from 1976. It began as a commemoration of Premier Zhou Enlai's death on January 8, 1976, and the Qingming festival on April 5. Initially organized by Nanjing University faculty members and students, it spread nationwide and led to the Tiananmen incident. The movement was sparked by an article in Shanghai's Wenhui Bao newspaper, which criticized Deng Xiaoping and implied attacks on Zhou Enlai. The protests in Nanjing and other cities were suppressed by the Gang of Four, but news still spread to Beijing where it contributed to the Tiananmen incident.

title: Nanjing incident of 1616
summary: The Nanjing incident of 1616, also known as the Nanjing Church incident, was a significant setback for Christianity in China. It occurred after the initial success of Matteo Ricci and other Jesuit missionaries who integrated themselves into Ming Dynasty bureaucracy and scholarly culture using Western science and technology. The incident was instigated by the vice-minister of Rites, with support from others in the bureaucracy. Twelve Jesuit missionaries were put on trial for their actions in Beijing and Nanjing, resulting in four being banished to Macao and the remaining eight retiring from public life. This incident led to a halt in the publication of religious and scientific works until 1622.

title: Nanjing Institute of Technology
summary: The Nanjing Institute of Technology (NJIT) is a provincial public college in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. Established in June 2000 through the merger of two vocational schools, it is affiliated with the Province of Jiangsu and sponsored by the provincial government. NJIT offers programs in disciplines including engineering, science, management, and arts, and is accredited to confer bachelor's and master's degrees. The institution provides higher education in Nanjing, Jiangsu province.

title: Nanjing International Exhibition Center
summary: The Nanjing International Exhibition Center is located in the Xuanwu District of Nanjing, China. It hosts the National Travel Expo annually by the China National Tourism Administration. The center will be used for equestrian competitions during the 2014 Summer Youth Olympics in Nanjing. The center is accessible on foot from Nanjing Railway Station and by taking the Nanjing Metro to Nanjing Forestry University-Xinzhuang Station. The center's coordinates are 32°4′28.1″N 118°48′32.63″E.

title: Nanjing International Expo Center
summary:
Nanjing International Expo Center is a landmark and exposition center in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China. It has an exposition area of 120,000 square meters and can host exhibitions with over 4,500 international standard large-scale exhibition booths. The center has six exposition pavilions, 38 conference rooms, and a multi-function pavilion. It has hosted various events including The 6th World Chinese Entrepreneur Convention and the annual meeting of BASF-YPC Co. Ltd.

The center was designed by tvsdesign, an American design company, and represents the unique style of "Curling Dragon, Crouching Tiger" in Nanjing. The total power capacity of every pavilion is 2800 kW, and telephone and internet are available to every booth. The center has hosted events since 1988, including the China World Logistics Conference in 2008.

title: Nanjing International Youth Cultural Centre
summary: The Nanjing International Youth Cultural Center is a complex of two skyscrapers in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. Designed by Zaha Hadid Architects, the buildings were completed in 2015 after construction began in 2012. Tower 1 stands at a height of 314.5 meters (1,032 ft), while Tower 2 is 255 meters (837 ft) tall. The complex's location is at 31°59′30″N 118°42′29″E. The buildings are part of a larger cultural center, but further information is limited due to the article being a stub.

title: Nanjing Iron and Steel Company
summary:
Nanjing Iron and Steel Co., Ltd. (NISCO) is a publicly traded steel maker based in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China. Founded in 1958 as a steel plant, it was spun off from Nanjing Iron and Steel Group in 1999 to form NISCO. The company became publicly traded on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in 2000, initially with Nanjing Iron and Steel Group as its controlling shareholder. 

NISCO was ranked 45th globally in production volume by the World Steel Association in 2015, producing 8.59 million metric tons of steel. The company has undergone significant changes in ownership and structure, including a debt-to-equity swap agreement signed in 2016. 

NISCO's parent company, Nanjing Nangang Iron and Steel United Co., Ltd., is a joint venture between Fosun International and Nanjing Iron and Steel Group. The company has also had business partnerships with other entities, including Prosperity International for trading iron ore.

title: Nanjing Iron and Steel Group
summary: Nanjing Iron and Steel Group Corp., Ltd. is a Chinese conglomerate company based in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China. Founded in 1958 as a steel plant, it was one of the 18 small-sized steel plants established in China. The company was incorporated as Nanjing Iron and Steel Group Corp., Ltd. in 1996 and listed one of its major assets, Nanjing Iron and Steel Company (NISCO), on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in 2000. In 2015, Nanjing Iron and Steel Group regained voting rights on a joint venture with Fosun International. The company has undergone significant restructuring, including the sale of several subsidiaries and the injection of assets into new holding companies.

title: Nanjing Jinling High School
summary: Nanjing Jinling High School, also known as Jin-Zhong or Jinling Middle School for short, is a public high school in Gulou District, Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. Founded by American missionaries of the Methodist Episcopal Church in 1888 as Fowler Biblical School, it was reorganized and renamed several times before regaining its original name in 1988. The school relocated to Chongqing during the Second Sino-Japanese War but returned to Nanjing in 1939 and fully recovered after the war. Jinling High School has a strong athletic program, with its boys' soccer team being national champions and the girls' basketball team winning Asian and National championships. The school has a rich history, with its original chapel being recognized as a Major Sites Protected at the National Level in 2006.

title: Nanjing Library
summary:
Nanjing Library is the third-largest library in China, housing over 10 million items. Established in 1907 as Jiangnan Library, it has undergone several organisational changes throughout its history. The library contains 1.6 million ancient books and 100,000 volumes of documents and manuscripts dating from the Tang dynasty to the Ming dynasty. Its collection includes 2.3 million books, with a significant portion being ancient documents.

The library was initially established by Viceroy Duanfang to preserve ancient books and scrolls from the Song, Yuan, Ming, and Qing dynasties. It was renamed several times, including China Studies Library and National Central University Library, before being handed over to the Nanjing Military Control Commission in 1949. The library was later renamed National Nanjing Library by the Ministry of Culture in 1950.

title: Nanjing Little Red Flower Art Troupe
summary: Nanjing Little Red Flower Art Troupe is a children's art troupe in China, established by the Nanjing Bureau of Art in the 1950s. It is the first Chinese children's art troupe to combine culture education and art education. The troupe has a faculty of high level and 138 students, divided into six grades with six classes each. Students attend Chinese and mathematics classes in the morning and professional dance or instrument classes in the afternoon. The troupe has performed internationally, visiting over 20 countries and performing for state heads and foreign delegations.

title: Nanjing Lukou International Airport
summary: Nanjing Lukou International Airport (IATA: NKG, ICAO: ZSNJ) is an international airport serving Nanjing and the Yangtze River Delta area. As of 2020, it is China's 12th busiest civil airport, handling 19,906,576 passengers and 389,362.4 tons of freight in that year. The airport is a hub for China Eastern Airlines' Jiangsu Company, Shenzhen Airlines' Jiangsu branch, and Juneyao Air's Jiangsu branch. It is also the main base for China Postal Airlines, providing pure cargo service to major cities in China. The airport has undergone significant expansions and renovations since 2006, including the completion of Terminal 2 in 2014.

title: Nanjing Man
summary: Nanjing Man is a fossil specimen of Homo erectus found in China. The remains, including large fragments of one male and one female skull and a molar tooth, were discovered in 1993 in Hulu Cave on the Tangshan hills in Jiangning District, Nanjing. The fossils were dated to be approximately 580,000 to 620,000 years old using mass spectrometric U-series dating. This age estimate pushed the colonization of eastern Asia by Homo erectus almost 270,000 years earlier than previously thought. The discovery supports the hypothesis that Homo erectus lived in Asia before pre-modern Homo sapiens existed. The Nanjing Man fossils exhibit distinct morphological features, differing from other Chinese hominins.

title: Nanjing Massacre
summary:
Nanjing Massacre 

The Nanjing Massacre, also known as the Rape of Nanjing, occurred in December 1937 during the Second Sino-Japanese War. It involved mass rape and murder of Chinese civilians, noncombatants, and prisoners of war by the Imperial Japanese Army in Nanjing, China. Estimates of death toll vary from 100,000 to over 340,000 people killed and between 4,000 to over 80,000 women raped. The massacre is considered one of the worst wartime atrocities in history.

The event took place after the Battle of Nanking and the retreat of the National Revolutionary Army. Japanese forces committed violent atrocities, including killing contests and massacres of entire villages, as they marched on Nanjing. The massacre began on December 13, 1937, and continued until late March 1938. The Nanking Safety Zone, established by John Rabe, a Nazi German citizen, saved at least 200,000 lives. After the war, several Japanese commanders were found guilty of war crimes and executed.

title: Nanjing Massacre denial
summary: The Nanjing Massacre refers to the murder and rape of hundreds of thousands of Chinese soldiers and civilians by Imperial Japanese forces in Nanjing during the Second Sino-Japanese War. Estimates of the death toll vary widely, ranging from 40,000 to 200,000. Most historians accept the findings of the Tokyo tribunal that the massacre occurred and was a result of Imperial Japanese Army atrocities. However, in Japan, there has been debate over the extent and nature of the massacre, with some historians attempting to downplay or deny its occurrence. This denial has become a staple of Japanese nationalist discourse and is seen as negatively affecting China-Japan relations.

title: Nanjing Massacre Memorial Day
summary: The National Memorial Day for the Victims of the Nanjing Massacre is a national memorial day in China observed on December 13 annually. Established in 2014, it honors Chinese victims of the Second Sino-Japanese War and draws attention to Japanese war crimes during this period. The day commemorates all victims of the era, including those killed in the Nanjing Massacre, chemical and biological warfare, forced labor, comfort women, and indiscriminate bombing. The Nanjing Massacre occurred from December 13, 1937 to January 1938, resulting in hundreds of thousands of deaths. The event was a crime under international law and led to trials after World War II.

title: Nanjing Medical University
summary:
Nanjing Medical University (NJMU) is a provincial public university in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It was originally established in 1934 as National Jiangsu Medical College in Zhenjiang, and relocated to Nanjing in 1957. The university is part of the Double First-Class Construction and has two main campuses: Wutai and Jiangning. 

NJMU offers various degree programs, including bachelor's, master's, and Ph.D degrees in medicine, public health, and other medical fields. The university has 24 affiliated hospitals and around 50 teaching hospitals across Jiangsu, Zhejiang, and Shandong provinces. As of 2020, it has over 1,400 registered faculty members and is involved in international exchange programs with institutions in the UK, US, Australia, Germany, Japan, and France.

title: Nanjing Metro
summary: The Nanjing Metro is a rapid transit system serving Nanjing, Jiangsu Province in China. Proposals for the metro began in 1984 and were approved by the State Planning Commission in 1994. The initial Line 1 opened in 2005, and the system now has 14 lines with 236 stations on 521 km of track. It is operated by the Nanjing Metro Group Company, with future expansion plans including 30 lines set to open in the coming years. The system's initial phase consisted of a north-south line, east-west line, and diagonal Northwest to Southeast line meeting in the city center.

title: Nanjing Military Region
summary: The Nanjing Military Region was one of the seven former military command regions for the Chinese People's Liberation Army. It covered six provinces and Shanghai, as well as Taiwan, which is claimed by the People's Republic of China. The region was established with an estimated 250,000 personnel and included three group armies, several divisions, and various brigades. The headquarters for the East Sea Fleet were located within the region at Ningbo, and several People's Liberation Army Air Force units were also based there. The Nanjing Military Region was dissolved and is now part of the Eastern Theater Command, with Cai Yingting as its final head.

title: Nanjing Monkey Kings
summary: The Nanjing Monkey Kings are a Chinese professional basketball team based in Nanjing, Jiangsu. They play in the Southern Division of the Chinese Basketball Association (CBA). The team was previously known as the Jiangsu Monkey Kings, joining the CBA ahead of the 2014-15 season after spending seven seasons at lower levels. They were renamed Nanjing Monkey Kings following the 2016-17 CBA season. The team competes in the top-tier league of Chinese basketball.

title: Nanjing Municipal Committee of the Chinese Communist Party
summary:
The Nanjing Municipal Committee of the Chinese Communist Party is the local branch of the CCP in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province. It is elected by the Nanjing Congress of the CCP and executes directives from the CCP Central Committee and Jiangsu Provincial Committee. The committee oversees Nanjing's administration, providing regular reports to the Central Committee and Jiangsu Provincial Committee.

The CCP established a presence in Nanjing in 1922, with various branches and committees forming over the years. The committee faced numerous disruptions by the Kuomintang, with periods of restoration and reformation occurring between 1927 and 1934. After the Japanese army's takeover in 1937, the CCP re-established a branch in Nanjing in 1940.

Following World War II, the committee underwent further reorganizations and name changes. A new Nanjing Municipal Committee was constituted in May 1949, after the CCP's Yangtze River Crossing campaign. The committee was temporarily usurped by rebels in 1967, but reinstated in 1971.

title: Nanjing Municipal Museum
summary: The Nanjing Municipal Museum is a comprehensive museum of history and art located inside Chaotian Palace in Nanjing. Established in 1978, it is a key historical and cultural site. The museum features various exhibitions showcasing its rich collection of cultural relics, including "Treasures in Nanjing Municipal Museum" and "Seven Overseas Voyages by Zheng He". The museum's exhibitions cover topics such as the Six Dynasties, Ming Dynasty, and Nanjing's history. It is a notable cultural institution in the city of Nanjing.

title: Nanjing Museum
summary: The Nanjing Museum is located in Nanjing, the capital of Jiangsu in East China. It covers an area of 70,000 square meters and has over 400,000 items in its permanent collection. The museum is particularly notable for its extensive collections of Ming and Qing imperial porcelain, one of the largest in the world. Established as a preparatory department for the National Central Museum in 1933, it took over 12.9 hectares of land and initially built the Humanity Hall due to China's political instability in the 1930s. The museum has undergone extensions in 1999 and 2009, with its main building designed by Liang Sicheng combining Chinese and Western architectural styles.

title: Nanjing No.1 High School
summary: Nanjing No. 1 High School is a high school located in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China on the bank of the Qinhuai River. Established as "Chong Wen School" in 1907, it was later renamed the Capital City Central Experimental School in 1927 and then Nanjing City No. 1 High School in 1933. The school has a long history dating back to the late Qing dynasty and was initially established for children from Nanjing's southern district. It has produced notable achievements in various competitions, including mathematics, physics, English, and information technology events. The school's symphony orchestra has also received awards in national music festivals.

title: Nanjing Normal University
summary:
Nanjing Normal University (NJNU) is a provincial public university in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It was established in 1902 as Sanjiang Normal School and has undergone several name changes, including National Nanjing Higher Normal School, University of Nanking, and Nanjing Normal College. In 1984, it was renamed Nanjing Normal University.

The university is affiliated with the Province of Jiangsu and co-sponsored by the Ministry of Education and the provincial government. It is part of the Double First-Class Construction and Project 211, a national initiative to promote excellence in higher education. As of 2020, NJNU has three campuses and consists of 28 colleges and schools with an enrollment of over 30,000 students.

Nanjing Normal University has a rich history dating back to the Qing dynasty and has been recognized for its academic excellence, including being named among the best student cities in the world by Quacquarelli Symonds in 2019.

title: Nanjing Olympic Sports Center Gymnasium
summary: The Nanjing Olympic Sports Center Gymnasium is an indoor arena in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It primarily hosts indoor sports such as basketball and figure skating. The facility has a seating capacity of 13,000 people and was opened in 2005. Located near the Nanjing Olympic Sports Center Stadium, it serves as a venue for various indoor sports events. The arena is part of the larger Nanjing Olympic Sports Center complex.

title: Nanjing Olympic Sports Centre
summary: Nanjing Olympic Sports Center Stadium is a multi-purpose stadium in Hexi New Town, Nanjing, China. It primarily hosts football and athletics events as part of the larger Olympic Park complex. The stadium was opened in 2005, hosting the National Games of China and the 2014 Summer Youth Olympics. It features a hyperboloid roof design, seating for 61,443 spectators, and large screens created by Barco. The stadium was constructed at a cost of ¥8,698,000 and has hosted various events including the opening and closing ceremonies of the 2005 National Games.

title: Nanjing Olympic Sports Centre
summary: Nanjing Olympic Sports Center Stadium is a multi-purpose stadium in Hexi New Town, Nanjing, China. It primarily hosts football and athletics events as part of the larger Olympic Park complex. The stadium was opened in 2005, hosting the National Games of China and the 2014 Summer Youth Olympics. It features a hyperboloid roof design, seating for 61,443 spectators, and large screens created by Barco. The stadium was constructed at a cost of ¥8,698,000 and has hosted various events including the opening and closing ceremonies of the 2005 National Games.

title: Nanjing Olympic Suning Tower
summary: Nanjing Olympic Suning Tower is a skyscraper in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. Initially expected to be completed in 2017, the project was put on hold but construction restarted in 2020. The building site is located near the Nanjing Olympic Sports Centre. A new completion date of 2025 has been planned for the tower.

title: Nanjing Publishing House
summary: Nanjing Publishing House is a publishing house located in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. Established in October 1988, it is under the administration of Nanjing Press and Publication Administration. The publishing house releases various publications including government guidelines, economic and technological works, as well as local writers' contributions. Notable achievements include winning the 8th Jiangsu Book Excellence Awards second prize in 2001 for "Civilized City" and receiving the Advanced Press and Publications Award in Jiangsu in 2013 and 2018. Additionally, Nanjing Publishing House was awarded the title "General Reading Advance Organization" by Jiangsu Radio and Television Administration in 2015.

title: Nanjing Qixiashan Yangtze River Bridge
summary: The Nanjing Qixiashan Yangtze River Bridge, formerly known as the Fourth Nanjing Yangtze Bridge, is a suspension bridge located over the Yangtze River in Nanjing, China. It is one of the longest span bridges in the world and was renamed on December 20, 2019. The bridge connects various towns and highways in Jiangning District, including Hengliang town, Long Pao, Xianling, and Qilin. It features a dual six-lane carriageway designed for high-speed traffic, with a speed limit of 100-125 km/h. The bridge is Jiangsu province's first suspension bridge and lies downstream of the second Yangtze River Bridge.

title: Nanjing salted duck
summary: Nanjing Salted Duck is a local dish from Nanjing, China. The history of the dish dates back hundreds of years, possibly to the 14th century, and gained popularity during the Qing Dynasty. The dish is characterized by tender white duck meat with a fragrant and often crispy presentation. Experts believe that duck in autumn possesses a sweet scent of osmanthus, making it the best season for consumption. Nanjing Salted Duck is a staple in southern China and is often served with osmanthus for added flavor.

title: Nanjing Sister Hong incident
summary: The Nanjing Sister Hong incident is a scandal that emerged in July 2025 involving a 38-year-old man surnamed Jiao from Nanjing, China. He allegedly posed as a woman named "Sister Hong" and engaged in sexual acts with several men, recording the encounters which were subsequently circulated online. Jiao used dating apps to present as a married woman, attracting men who wanted to engage in intimate relations with another person's spouse. He operated by offering "free sexual services" and profited from the video footage by charging a membership fee. The police launched an investigation, arrested Jiao on July 6, and are working to remove the illicit videos from the internet. At least three victims tested positive for HIV, but it is unclear if this was related to Jiao.

title: Nanjing South railway station
summary: Nanjing South Railway Station is a high-speed railway station in Nanjing, Jiangsu province. It serves multiple railways including the Beijing-Shanghai high-speed railway and is connected to the Nanjing Metro. The station opened on June 28, 2011, and is one of the world's largest railway stations in terms of gross floor area at 458,000 square meters. The station features a "Smart Station System" that adjusts lighting and monitors air conditioning based on passenger flow and environmental conditions. It has implemented solar panels covering the majority of its roof, generating 228 MWs of electricity within 25 years. The station has improved regional connectivity and stimulated local economic growth, facilitated tourism, and attracted businesses to Nanjing.

title: Nanjing Sport Institute
summary: Nanjing Sport Institute (南京体育学院) is a public university in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. Founded in 1956, it specializes in sports and physical education. The institute has national responsibility for elite athlete training and physical education research, as well as sports sciences. It operates three main sites in Nanjing: the Central area (also known as Linggu Temple area), Xianlin area, and Wukesong area. The Central area is home to several historic stadiums from the Republic of China era (1912-1949).

title: Nanjing Tech University
summary: Nanjing Tech University is a provincial public technological university located in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It was established in 2001 through the merger of Nanjing Chemical Engineering University and Nanjing Architectural Engineering College. The university is affiliated with the Province of Jiangsu. It has a campus located at 32°04′43.36″N 118°46′19.07″E.

title: Nanjing Tech University
summary: Nanjing Tech University is a provincial public technological university located in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It was established in 2001 through the merger of Nanjing Chemical Engineering University and Nanjing Architectural Engineering College. The university is affiliated with the Province of Jiangsu. It has a campus located at 32°04′43.36″N 118°46′19.07″E.

title: Nanjing Theological Review
summary: Nanjing Theological Review is a Chinese-language journal of Protestantism in China. Established in 1914, it was originally founded by Chen Chin-yung as Theological Review and has undergone several name changes. The journal's publication was interrupted, with the name changing to Nanking Union Theological Review in 1953 and Nanjing Theological Review in 1986. It is currently published by the Nanjing Union Theological Seminary. Since 1985, the journal has been supported by the Foundation for Theological Education in Southeast Asia.

title: Nanjing Trams
summary: Nanjing Trams is the tram system of Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China. It consists of two separate lines: Hexi tram and Qilin tram. The system is wireless, powered by lightweight Li-ion batteries charged via pantographs at stations and terminals, with 90% of the line being catenary-free. The Hexi tram opened on August 13, 2014, while the Qilin tram began test runs on October 10, 2016. The Hexi tram line spans 7.76 kilometers and has stations in Jianye District, while the Qilin tram line is 9.4 kilometers long with 13 stations.

title: Nanjing Underwater World
summary: Nanjing Underwater World is an aquarium located near the Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum in Nanjing, China. It is a joint venture between Andover Capital Group and the Administration Bureau of Dr. Sun Yat-Sen's Mausoleum, opened in 1996 with a total investment of approximately 200 million yuan. The aquarium covers an area of 16,000 square meters and features a four-story structure with a 1,000-seat Dolphinarium. It houses almost 10,000 animals representing 200 species and includes an ocean tank with over 100 species of sea creatures. The aquarium also features various exhibits, including a Polar Region display and a Science Education Hall with interactive zones.

title: Nanjing Union Theological Seminary
summary: Nanjing Union Theological Seminary is the flagship theological seminary of Protestant Christianity in China. Established as Nanking Theological Seminary in 1911, it merged with ten other East China seminaries in November 1952 and later absorbed Yanjing Union Theological Seminary of Beijing in 1961. During the Japanese invasion, the seminary provided protection to thousands of Chinese civilians. The Three-Self Patriotic Movement reformed theological education in 1952, leading to the seminary's union. The institution was reopened as a primary center for religious study in 1981 and began publishing academic journals, including Nanjing Theological Review and Religion.

title: Nanjing Union Theological Seminary
summary: Nanjing Union Theological Seminary is the flagship theological seminary of Protestant Christianity in China. Established as Nanking Theological Seminary in 1911, it merged with ten other East China seminaries in November 1952 and later absorbed Yanjing Union Theological Seminary of Beijing in 1961. During the Japanese invasion, the seminary provided protection to thousands of Chinese civilians. The Three-Self Patriotic Movement reformed theological education in 1952, leading to the seminary's union. The institution was reopened as a primary center for religious study in 1981 and began publishing academic journals, including Nanjing Theological Review and Religion.

title: Nanjing University Library
summary: Nanjing University Library is a library located in Nanjing, China. It has a long history and houses approximately 400 thousand ancient thread-bound Chinese books. As of 2014, the library's total collection reached 5.77 million items. The library is popular among students but faced issues with long queues for study spaces, which were addressed in 2016 by introducing an online seat-booking system. The library is accessible on the Gulou and Xianlin campuses of Nanjing University, with nearby metro stations including Zhujianglu Station and Nanda Xianlin Station.

title: Nanjing University mutilation case
summary: The Nanjing University Dismemberment Case, also known as the Diao Aiqing Case, is a notorious unsolved crime in Nanjing, China. On January 19, 1996, the mutilated remains of 19-year-old Diao Aiqing were found across multiple locations near Nanjing University. The remains, over 2,000 pieces in total, were discovered in plastic-wrapped packages at eight locations around the university. Diao had been missing for nine days prior to her remains being found, and it is believed she was dismembered after her disappearance. The case remains unsolved to this day, with the police confirming that Diao's head and internal organs were boiled for several days.

title: Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics
summary:
The Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics (NUAA) is a public university in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. Founded in October 1952 as the Nanjing College of Aviation Industry, it has undergone several name changes to its current title. The university is affiliated with the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology, part of Project 211 and the Double First-Class Construction. 

NUAA comprises three campuses: Ming Palace Campus, Jiangjun Road (Jiangning) Campus, and Tianmu Lake Campus. The university offers a wide range of programs including 46 undergraduate, 127 master, and 52 doctoral programs. It has 18 colleges and awards national key disciplines in Aerospace Science & Technology, Mechanics, and other fields.

title: Nanjing University of Chinese Medicine
summary: Nanjing University of Chinese Medicine (NJUCM) is a provincial public university in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. Established in 1954, it is one of the earliest established universities of Traditional Chinese Medicine in China. The university has three campuses: Xianlin, Hanzhongmen, and Taizhou, with nearly 20,000 enrolled students. NJUCM offers undergraduate programs in traditional Chinese medicine and related fields, as well as master's and doctoral degree programs. The university is affiliated with the Province of Jiangsu and is part of the Double First-Class Construction initiative.

title: Nanjing University of Finance and Economics
summary: Nanjing University of Finance and Economics (NUFE) is a public university located in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It specializes in economic and business studies, with research strengths in environmental economics, international economics, and other sub-fields. NUFE offers a wide range of degree programs in law, liberal arts, fine arts, science, and engineering. The university has three campuses: one in the city centre, one at Xianlin, and a small campus in Qiaotou. As of 2025, NUFE ranked #3 in East China and #10 nationwide among universities in China according to the Best Chinese Universities Ranking.

title: Nanjing University of Finance and Economics
summary: Nanjing University of Finance and Economics (NUFE) is a public university located in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It specializes in economic and business studies, with research strengths in environmental economics, international economics, and other sub-fields. NUFE offers a wide range of degree programs in law, liberal arts, fine arts, science, and engineering. The university has three campuses: one in the city centre, one at Xianlin, and a small campus in Qiaotou. As of 2025, NUFE ranked #3 in East China and #10 nationwide among universities in China according to the Best Chinese Universities Ranking.

title: Nanjing University of Information Science and Technology
summary: Nanjing University of Information Science and Technology (NUIST) is a provincial public university in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It was established in 1960 as the Meteorology College of Nanjing University and is affiliated with the Province of Jiangsu. NUIST is known for its meteorology research and education, being the oldest institution of higher learning in meteorology science in China. The university offers degree programs in various fields, including Atmospheric Science, Environmental Science, Engineering, and management. NUIST is part of the Double First-Class Construction and offers scholarships for local and international students, including the Chinese Government Scholarship-WMO Program.

title: Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications
summary: Nanjing University of Posts and Telecommunications (NJUPT) is a provincial public university in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. Established in 1958, its history dates back to a training class for postal cadres during World War II in 1942. The university has undergone several name and structural changes, including affiliations with Shandong University and the East China General Administration of Posts and Telecommunications. NJUPT is part of the Double First-Class Construction and consists of 16 schools and departments, focusing on engineering subjects such as telecommunications, transportation, electronics, and cybersecurity. The university is jointly administered by the central and provincial governments, with the provincial government playing a leading role. NJUPT ranked 76th nationally in 2019 according to the Shanghai Ranking.

title: Nanjing University of Science and Technology
summary: The Nanjing University of Science and Technology (NJUST) is a provincial public university in Xuanwu, Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. Founded in 1953 as the Department of Artillery Engineering of Institute of Military Engineering of the PLA, it has undergone several name changes and is currently affiliated with the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology. NJUST is a multidisciplinary university offering programs in science, engineering, liberal arts, economics, and more. It is part of Project 211 and the Double First-Class Construction, and has been recognized as a National Key University. The university has one main campus in Xiaolingwei, covering an area of 3,118 mu.

title: Nanjing University of the Arts
summary: Nanjing University of the Arts (NUA) is a university in China offering undergraduate and graduate degrees in fine arts, design, and related subjects. Founded in 1912 as Shanghai Chinese Art College, it has undergone several name changes: to the Shanghai Academy of Fine Arts in 1930 and East China Arts College in 1952. The university relocated to Nanjing in 1958 and acquired its current name in 1959. NUA has partnerships with the University of Dayton and Hokuriku University, and is served by the Caochangmen/NUA/JSSNU station of the Nanjing Metro. The school song's lyrics were written by Cai Yuanpei.

title: Nanjing University of the Arts

title: Nanjing University Press
summary: Nanjing University Press is a scholarly publishing house established in 1984 and affiliated with Nanjing University. Initially focused on humanities, social sciences, and natural sciences, it expanded its scope post-2000 to include interdisciplinary studies. The press is renowned for its Library of Chinese Thinkers series and collaborations with institutions like the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. Nanjing University Press was awarded "National First-Class Publisher" in 2017 and publishes over 500 titles annually. Its publications cover fields such as philosophy, technology, and environmental studies.

title: Nanjing University Town
summary:
Nanjing is a city in China with a total area of 6582.31 square kilometers and a population of approximately 9.3146 million. The city has four university towns: Xianlin University Town, Pukou University Town, Jiangning University Town, and Lishui University Town. 

Xianlin University Town, located in the northern part of Nanjing City, was established in 2002 and covers an area of about 80 square kilometers. It is home to several colleges, including Nanjing University Xianlin Campus and Nanjing Normal University Xianlin campus.

Pukou University Town, established in 1988, is the earliest university town built in Nanjing and includes institutions such as Nanjing University of Technology and Nanjing Agricultural University.

Jiangning University Town, located in the southern part of the city, has a planned area of 27 square kilometers and includes several universities.

Lishui University Town is a newly emerging university town in the southern district of Nanjing, aiming to create a hub for literature, art, science, and education.

title: Nanjing War Crimes Tribunal
summary: The Nanjing War Crimes Tribunal was established by the Nationalist government of China in 1946 to judge Imperial Japanese Army officers for crimes committed during the Second Sino-Japanese War. The tribunal convicted several high-ranking officers, including Lieutenant General Hisao Tani and General Yasuji Okamura. However, Okamura was later protected by Nationalist leader Chiang Kai-shek and retained as a military adviser. The tribunal sentenced all the accused to death in 1947, with Hisao Tani being executed on April 26. The official estimate of the Nanjing Massacre death toll is 300,000, engraved on a memorial in Nanjing.

title: Nanjing West railway station
summary: Nanjing West railway station is a railway station in Nanjing, China. Originally named Nanjing railway station, it was first opened in 1908 as the end point of the Shanghai–Nanjing Railway. The station was later renamed to Nanjing West railway station after a new Nanjing railway station was constructed closer to the city center. It served as a transfer point for passengers traveling from Shanghai to Beijing, who would have to board a river ferry to continue their journey. The station suspended passenger services in 2012 and will be converted into a railway museum, with a metro station on Line 5 scheduled to open near the site in 2025.

title: Nanjing World Trade Center Tower 1
summary: Nanjing World Trade Center Tower 1 is a supertall skyscraper located in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. The building will stand at a height of 326.5 meters (1,071.2 ft). Construction began in 2011 and is expected to be completed by 2022. The tower's location is at 31°59′44″N 118°43′06″E. This article about the building is currently a stub and requires expansion for further information.

title: Nanjing Yangtze River Bridge
summary: The Nanjing Yangtze River Bridge is a double-decked road-rail truss bridge in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It spans the Yangtze River and connects the city's Pukou and Gulou districts, with a total length of 6,772 metres (lower deck) and 4,588 metres (upper deck). The bridge was completed in 1968 and carries approximately 80,000 vehicles and 190 trains per day. It was the first heavy bridge designed and built using Chinese expertise, and it surpassed the Golden Gate Bridge as the most frequent suicide site in the world by 2006, with over 2,000 estimated suicides. The bridge's design features nine piers and a maximum span of 160 metres.

title: Nanjing Yingtian Avenue Yangtze River Tunnel
summary: The Nanjing Yingtian Avenue Yangtze River Tunnel is a tunnel under the Yangtze River in Nanjing, China. It connects the Pukou District to Jiangxin Island and was constructed from 2005 to 2010. The tunnel broke through in 2009 and opened in May 2010, with a name change occurring on December 20, 2019. The tunnel continues over the Jiajiang Bridge into the Jianye District of Nanjing. It spans across the Yangtze River and its smaller Jiajiang branch.

title: Nanjing Yingtian Avenue Yangtze River Tunnel
summary: The Nanjing Yingtian Avenue Yangtze River Tunnel is a tunnel under the Yangtze River in Nanjing, China. It connects the Pukou District to Jiangxin Island and was constructed from 2005 to 2010. The tunnel broke through in 2009 and opened in May 2010, with a name change occurring on December 20, 2019. The tunnel continues over the Jiajiang Bridge into the Jianye District of Nanjing. It spans across the Yangtze River and its smaller Jiajiang branch.

title: Nanjing Youth Olympic Sports Park
summary: The Nanjing Youth Olympic Sports Park is a sport complex in Pukou District, Nanjing, China. It was constructed from December 2011 to host the 2014 Summer Youth Olympics and covers approximately 1,000,000 m² of land. The complex features a main arena with two parts: the 21,000-seater Nanjing Youth Olympic Sports Park Arena and the 18,000-seater Nanjing Youth Olympic Sports Park Stadium. The indoor arena is China's largest and can host various sports such as basketball, badminton, ice hockey, and gymnastics. The park also includes temporary venues built for the 2014 Summer Youth Olympics, including a BMX Park and beach volleyball arena.

title: Nanjing Zhonghua High School
summary: Nanjing Zhonghua High School was founded in 1899 by Dr. William E. Macklin, a British missionary doctor. Initially known as Christian Middle School, the school changed its name several times due to various historical events and was officially named Nanjing Zhonghua High School in 1983. The school's campus moved to Hexi in 2011, and a new Yuhua Campus opened in 2022. The Yuhua Campus covers approximately 13.3 hectares and features modern facilities, including teaching buildings, a cafeteria, dormitories, an integrated STREAM center, and sports facilities. The school operates across two campuses under an integrated management model and began enrolling international students in 2022.

title: Nanjing–Anqing intercity railway
summary:
Nanjing–Anqing Intercity Railway 

The Nanjing–Anqing intercity railway is a high-speed rail line in China, connecting cities of Nanjing and Anqing. The 258-kilometre railway was opened on December 6, 2015, after construction began in January 2010. The line runs parallel to the Yangtze River and passes through several cities, including Ma'anshan, Wuhu, Tongling, and Chizhou. The railway has a total of ten stations and is connected to the Yangtze River Delta region's railway network. The line has a capacity of 125 pairs of trains per day, with a top speed of 250 kilometres per hour.

title: Nankeen
summary: Nankeen, also known as Nankeen cloth, is a type of pale yellowish fabric originally made in Nanjing, China from a specific variety of cotton. However, it is now manufactured using ordinary cotton that is dyed to achieve the desired color. The term blue nankeen refers to a hand-printed fabric with artistic refinement and primitive simplicity, originating from the Silk Road over three thousand years ago. This type of fabric is created using hand-carved stencils and indigo dye, resulting in a blue cloth with white patterns.

title: Nanking Safety Zone
summary: The Nanking Safety Zone was a demilitarized zone established in Nanjing, China on December 13, 1937, to protect Chinese civilians from the impending Japanese invasion. The zone was set up by expatriates and Hang Liwu, with John Rabe as chairman of the International Committee for the Safe Zone. The zone was designated a 3.86 square kilometer area in the western region of Nanjing city, with committees for sanitation, lodging, and food established to ensure its normal operation. Despite the Chinese government's acceptance of the zone, the Japanese army disregarded its existence and committed atrocities within its boundaries. The International Committee for the Safe Zone was eventually reorganized into the Nanking International Relief Committee in February 1938, marking the conclusion of the safe zone.

title: Nanyang Industrial Exposition
summary: The Nanyang Industrial Exposition, also known as the 1910 Nanking or Nanjing Exposition, was a world's fair held in Nanjing, China from June 5 to December 15, 1910. The exposition was an official event backed by the Qing government and aimed to showcase the region of Nanyang, which includes Jiangsu, Jiangxi, and Anhui provinces. The event was proposed by Duanfang, the viceroy of Liangjiang, and Chen Qitai, the governor of Jiangsu Province, in 1908. The exposition covered an area of approximately 41 acres and featured exhibits from China, Japan, the Dutch East Indies (now Indonesia), the United States, France, Great Britain, and Germany.

title: Nari Technology
summary: NARI Technology Co., Ltd, also known as Nari, is a partially state-owned Chinese company listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange. Established in 1973 as the Nanjing Automation Research Institute under the State Grid Corporation of China, it became a separate unit in 2001. Nari held its initial public offering on October 16, 2003. The company is a supplier of power and automation technologies in China, primarily manufacturing high-power insulated-gate bipolar junction transistors. In 2023, Britain's National Grid terminated its contract with Nari's subsidiary NR Electric due to unspecified reasons, reportedly including cybersecurity concerns.

title: National Hohai Technology University
summary: National Hohai Technology University was a university located in Nanking, established in 1924 through the merger of the Engineering College of National Southeastern University and Hohai Engineering Specialized School. The university existed until 1927, when it was merged with several other public schools in Jiangsu province to form the new Nanking capital national university. The first president of National Hohai Technology University was Mao Yisheng, who was later succeeded by Yang Hsiaoshu in 1925. The university's engineering college was reestablished after the merger, and its legacy continued through various institutions. In 1952, the Engineering College of Nanking University formed several independent schools, including Nanjing Institute of Technology (later Southeast University) and Each China Institute of Water Conservancy (later Hohai University).

title: Niushoushan
summary:
Niushou Mountain, also known as Niushoushan or Tianque Mountain, is a low hill located in Jiangning District of Nanjing City, Jiangsu Province, China. It is part of the southern branch of the western Ningzhen Hills and has an elevation of 242.9 meters. The mountain's name, meaning "Ox Head Mountain," comes from its twin peaks resembling the horns of an ox. 

The location has been a Buddhist site since the Tang dynasty (618-907 AD) and was previously known as Xian Ku Mountain ("Immortal Grotto Mountain") due to a cave where the monk Pizhi achieved enlightenment. In 2015, it became the shrine for the world's only parietal relic of Buddha, the skull of Shakyamuni.

title: Organic Food Development Center
summary: The Organic Food Development Center (OFDC) is an organic certification organization in China. Founded in 1994, it is based in Nanjing and serves as a branch of the State Environmental Protection Administration (SEPA). The OFDC was certified by the International Federation of Organic Movements in 2002. It is involved in promoting and developing organic food standards within China.

title: Panmao Zhai
summary: Panmao Zhai is a Chinese climatologist and Secretary General of the Chinese Meteorological Society. He holds a bachelor's degree in climatology from Nanjing University (1984) and a master's degree in physical climatology from the same institution (1990). Zhai is a professor at the Chinese Academy of Meteorological Sciences and has held various positions, including Director-General of Department of Forecasting and Networking in China Meteorological Administration. He was a contributing author to the IPCC fourth assessment, Lead Author of working group I for the IPCC fifth assessment (2008-2015), and was elected as co-chair of the IPCC working group 1 for the sixth assessment.

title: Party Secretary of Nanjing
summary: The secretary of the Nanjing Municipal Committee of the Chinese Communist Party is the highest-ranking post in Nanjing, serving as the leader of the committee. The position is officially appointed by the CCP Central Committee, with approval from the Politburo and its Standing Committee. The secretary leads the Standing Committee of the Nanjing Municipal Committee, outranking the mayor who is generally the deputy secretary. The current secretary of the CCP Nanjing Municipal Committee is not specified in the provided information, however it mentions that Zhou Hongbo took office on 1 December 2024.

title: Pauline Woo Tsui
summary: Pauline Woo Tsui was a Chinese American anti-discrimination activist born on October 2, 1920, in Nanjing, China. She held dual U.S. citizenship due to her father's birth in Hawaii and was a niece of influential educator Kuo Ping-Wen. Tsui studied at St. John's University in Shanghai and later earned a master's degree in music education from Columbia University in New York. She worked at the United States Army Map Service for 30 years and co-founded the Organization of Chinese American Women in 1977, serving as its executive director from 1983 to 2007. The organization aimed to empower Chinese American women through education and training programs. Tsui was posthumously named a member of the Maryland Women's Hall of Fame in 2019.

title: Peng Jiamu
summary: Peng Jiamu was a Chinese biochemist and explorer born on May 19, 1925. He received a biology degree from Central University of China in 1947 and joined the Shanghai Institute of Biochemistry, where he studied under Cao Tianqin. Peng participated in several scientific expeditions to Xinjiang starting in 1956, cataloguing flora and fauna and measuring potassium accumulation. He was promoted to Vice President of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 1979, before leading an expedition to the Lop Nur desert in 1980. Peng disappeared on June 17, 1980, leaving behind a note saying he had gone to find water.

title: Pfrang Association
summary: Pfrang Association is a charitable organization based in Nanjing, China. Established in November 2000, it aims to help overcome social inequality by providing education assistance to children in poor and rural regions of Jiangsu Province. The association was founded in memory of Sandra, Thorsten, Petra, and Jürgen Pfrang, a German family who were murdered in 2000. The organization focuses on making education financially possible for disadvantaged students, allowing them to reach their full potential and break the cycle of poverty and crime. Pfrang Association supports over 500 students annually, in partnership with the Amity Foundation and local schools.

title: Population of Nanjing in December of 1937
summary:
Nanjing Massacre Population Estimates:

The population of Nanjing in December 1937 is a subject of debate among scholars due to the lack of reliable data. Estimates vary widely, ranging from 200,000 civilians and 70,000 soldiers to as many as 500,000 civilians and 150,000 soldiers. 

The city's population had decreased significantly since March 1937 when an official survey put the total civilian population at 1,019,667. Many residents, particularly the wealthy and middle class, had fled after Japanese bombing began in August 1937. Those who remained were mostly the poor and city officials.

The chaotic conditions during the Second Sino-Japanese War, including rapid population movements and a scorched earth policy by the Chinese Army, made it difficult to track the city's population. The International Committee established a demilitarized zone, known as the Nanking Safety Zone, which housed many of Nanjing's remaining residents by the time of the city's fall on December 13, 1937.

title: Porcelain Tower of Nanjing
summary: The Porcelain Tower of Nanjing is a historical site located on the south bank of the Qinhuai River in Nanjing, China. Originally constructed as part of the Great Bao'en Temple during the Ming dynasty in the 15th century, it was destroyed in the 19th century during the Taiping Rebellion. The tower's reconstruction began in 2010 with a donation of one billion yuan from Chinese businessman Wang Jianlin, and it was reopened to the public in 2015. The original tower stood at a height of 79 meters with nine stories and was one of the largest buildings in China, featuring white porcelain bricks, intricate designs, and numerous Buddhist images. It was sometimes listed as one of the Wonders of the World before its destruction in 1856.

title: Porcelain Tower of Nanjing
summary: The Porcelain Tower of Nanjing is a historical site located on the south bank of the Qinhuai River in Nanjing, China. It was sometimes listed as one of the Wonders of the World before its destruction in 1856.

title: Port of Nanjing
summary: The Port of Nanjing is a major inland port located in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China. It has the largest throughput of any inland port in the world, with 191 million tons of cargo handled in 2012. The port has a long history dating back to A.D 229, when it became a major seaport. It is situated in the lower reaches of the Yangtze River, with authority over 208 km of shoreline. As of 2010, the port operated six public ports and three industrial ports.

title: Purple Mountain Observatory
summary: Purple Mountain Observatory, also known as Zijinshan Astronomical Observatory, is a dual-use astronomical observatory operated by the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Located at Purple Mountain east of Nanjing, it conducts both open science and classified space domain awareness activities for the PLA Aerospace Force. Established in 1934, it was initially funded by the Nationalist Government of the Republic of China and administered by Academia Sinica. The observatory shifted its focus to public education in the late 1980s due to increasing light pollution. It has discovered over 750 minor planets, including periodic comets and asteroids such as the Trojan asteroid 2223 Sarpedon.

title: Qi Dayu
summary: Qi Dayu is a Chinese diplomat born in September 1963 in Andong (now Dandong), Liaoning. He graduated from Nanjing University in 1986 with a major in Russian. Qi joined the Foreign Service in 1986 and has primarily served in the Department of Eurasia, Ministry of Foreign Affairs. He held various positions including secretary at the Chinese Embassy in Russia (1996-2001), counsellor of the Chinese Embassy in Georgia (2001-2005), and Chinese Ambassador to Kyrgyzstan (2013-2016). He served as Communist Party Secretary of China Foreign Affairs University from 2017 to 2020, before being appointed Chinese Ambassador to Hungary.

title: Qi Zhaochang
summary:
Qi Zhaochang was a Chinese architect and civil engineer born in 1880 in Hangzhou, Zhejiang. He earned a master's degree in civil engineering from Ohio State University and worked on various projects, including campus buildings at Jinling University and St. Paul's Church in Nanjing.

Qi taught agricultural engineering at Jinling University, where he also designed and constructed several buildings. He was involved in the construction of the Science and Technology Museum, university gymnasium, student dormitories, faculty housing, Twinem Memorial Chapel, Ginling College, and Nanjing Zhonghua High School.

During the Second Sino-Japanese War, Qi designed a 40-meter steel flagpole for Jinling University to express national pride. He also served as the director of a refugee shelter on campus during the Nanjing Massacre, which accommodated over 30,000 refugees.

title: Qingliang Temple (Nanjing)
summary: Qingliang Temple, also known as Stone Cooling Bodhimaṇḍa, is a temple located in Qingliangshan Park in Nanjing City, Jiangsu, China. Originally built as Xingjiao Temple during the Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period, it was renamed Stone Cooling Bodhimaṇḍa in 937 by Li Jing, the second ruler of Southern Tang. The temple was rebuilt during the Northern Song dynasty in 980 and again by the Yongle Emperor of the Ming dynasty in 1402, when it was renamed Qingliang Temple. After suffering damage from various catastrophes, the temple underwent renovations in 2003 and reopened in 2009.

title: Qinhuai Lantern Fair
summary: The Qinhuai Lantern Fair, also known as Jinling Lantern Fair or Jinling Lantern Festival, is a popular folk custom celebration of the Lantern Festival in Nanjing. The fair has been held yearly at the Confucius Temple between the Spring Festival and Lantern Festival, with 25 fairs held to date. It is one of China's most famous celebrations of the Lantern Festival and was named an Intangible Cultural Heritage of China in 2006. The fair's origin dates back to Eastern Wu, where hanging lanterns was used in festivals and celebrations. The tradition of lantern fairs during the Lantern Festival became a regular practice by the Tang dynasty, with an increase in scale and duration over time.

title: Qiu He
summary: Qiu He is a former Chinese politician born in January 1957, in Binhai County, Jiangsu. He spent his career in Jiangsu and Yunnan provinces, holding various positions including Deputy Communist Party Secretary of Yunnan. Qiu was a member of the 12th National People's Congress and an alternate member of the 18th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party. He was investigated by the Chinese Communist Party's anti-graft agency in March 2015 for "serious violations of laws and regulations." Qiu was expelled from the Chinese Communist Party in July 2015, accused of accepting cash gifts, using his office for personal gain, and accepting massive bribes. He was also indicted on criminal charges of bribery.

title: Qiu Shusen
summary: Qiu Shusen was a Chinese historian born on July 4, 1937. He specialized in the history of the Mongols and the Yuan dynasty, as well as China's ethnic minorities. Qiu graduated from Nanjing University in 1959 and later became a faculty member, serving as Chair of the Department of History from 1984 to 1988. He held professorships at North Minzu University and Jinan University, and taught as an adjunct professor at Macau University of Science and Technology after retiring. Qiu published over 20 monographs and more than 200 research papers, including works on the history of China's ethnic minorities. He died on November 20, 2019, at the age of 82.

title: Qiudong Wang
summary: Qiudong Wang is a professor at the University of Arizona's Department of Mathematics. He received his B.S. from Nanjing University in 1982 and Ph.D. from the University of Cincinnati in 1994. Wang is known for his 1991 paper "The global solution of the n-body problem," which generalized Karl F. Sundman's 1912 results to a system of more than three bodies. However, L.K. Babadzanjanz claims to have made the same generalization in 1979.

title: Qixia Mountain
summary: Qixia Mountain is a mountain located in the northeast part of Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China. The name Qixia originated from a Qixia cottage established in the Southern Dynasties (420-589). The mountain features three main peaks: Sanmao Peak, Dragon Mountain, and Tiger Mountain. Qixia Mountain is known for its scenic spots, historical sites, and natural attractions such as red autumnal leaves and the Dongfeitian grottos. It is a popular tourist destination both domestically and internationally.

title: Qixia Temple
summary: Qixia Temple is a Buddhist temple located on Qixia Mountain in the suburban Qixia District of Nanjing, Jiangsu. It is one of Nanjing's most important Buddhist monasteries and the cradle of East Asian Mādhyamaka. The temple was built in AD 489 during the Southern Qi dynasty and has undergone several name changes throughout its history. It was completely destroyed by the Taiping Rebellion in the late Qing dynasty but was restored in 1919. During the Nanjing Massacre, the temple served as a temporary refuge for over 24,000 civilians. The temple complex features a large collection of Chinese Buddhist visual art and sculptural art, including pagodas, murals, and artwork dating back to the 10th century.

title: Qu Bochuan
summary: Qu Bochuan was a Chinese scholar and educator born on November 16, 1909. He earned his doctoral degree in Chemical Engineering from the Dresden University of Technology in Germany and later returned to China. Qu played a key role in establishing the Yan'an Institute of Natural Science, and served as academic dean. He was sent to Dalian in 1948 to establish the first tertiary technical school under the Communist Party, which later became Dalian University of Technology. Qu served as its first president from 1948 to 1981 and was awarded the 'Highlighted Seniors' award in 1981.

title: Qu Qinyue
summary:
