Qu Qinyue is a Chinese astrophysicist and writer born on May 21, 1935. He is a professor and former president of Nanjing University, known for his research in high-energy astrophysics. Qu's work focuses on pulsars, neutron stars, X-ray sources, gamma-ray sources, and quasars. He was elected a member of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 1980.

Qu received his education at various schools in Shandong, before attending Nanjing University to study astronomy, mathematics, and physics. After graduating in 1957, he became a teaching assistant at Nanjing University and later worked on the development of China's first solar tower. Qu became a full professor in 1978 and served as President of Nanjing University from 1984 to 1997.

title: Ren Mei'e
summary: Ren Mei'e was a Chinese geomorphologist, geologist, and marine scientist. Born on September 8, 1913, in Zhenhai, Ningbo, Zhejiang, China, he graduated from the Department of Geology at National Central University (now Nanjing University) in 1934. Ren received his doctorate from the University of Glasgow, Scotland in 1939. He was a professor at Zhejiang University, Fudan University, and Nanjing University, serving as head of the Department of Geography at Nanjing University. Ren was selected as an academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 1980 and received the Victoria Medal from the Royal Geographical Society of London in 1986.

title: Ryo Takeuchi (director)
summary: Ryo Takeuchi is a Japanese filmmaker born on October 23, 1978, in Abiko, Chiba, Japan. He is known for his documentaries about China's efforts in combating the coronavirus, including Long Time No See, Wuhan and China's Post-Pandemic Era: Winning Against All Odds. Takeuchi began his connections with China in 2002 while shooting a documentary about mahjong, and he later emigrated to China with his wife in 2013. He founded the Hezhimeng Culture Communication Co., Ltd. in 2014 and produced several documentary series, including The Reason I Live Here. Takeuchi rose to fame in 2020 for his hit documentary series Nanjing's Anti-epidemic Scene and Long Time No See, Wuhan.

title: Sanjiang University
summary: Sanjiang University, located in Nanjing city's countryside, is the first private institution of higher learning in Jiangsu Province. Founded as Sanjiang College in 1993, it was upgraded to a university in 2002 by the Ministry of Education. The university has a campus covering over 300,000 square meters with 200,000 square meters of floor space. Sanjiang University has around 18,000 students and employs approximately 550 faculty members, including over 380 professors and associate professors. The university also recruits foreign students and has a president who is a member of the ninth National People's Congress of China.

title: School of Foreign Languages and Cultures of NNU
summary: The School of Foreign Languages and Cultures of NNU, located in Nanjing, China, was originally established in 1898. The school offers undergraduate programs in eight languages: English, Spanish, Japanese, Russian, Italian, Korean, German, and French. The duration of these programs varies, with four-year English majors and five-year programs for the other languages. Students can pursue bachelor's degrees, master's degrees, and Ph.D.s through the school.

title: Sebastian Heilmann
summary: Sebastian Heilmann is a German political scientist and sinologist born in 1965 in Offenbach am Main. He has been a professor at the University of Trier since 1999 and was the founding director of the Mercator Institute for China Studies (MERICS) from 2013 to 2018. Heilmann received his doctorate in 1993 and completed his habilitation at the University of Münster in 1999. His research focuses on China's political system, international relations, economic and innovation policy. Heilmann has held various positions including research fellow at the Institute of Asian Studies in Hamburg and guest researcher at Harvard University. He is considered one of Europe's most renowned China experts, with international reviews highlighting his research contributions on the Chinese Communist Party and Chinese industrial policy.

title: Second Historical Archives of China
summary: The Second Historical Archives of China (SHAC) is a central-level national archive located in Nanjing, Jiangsu. Established in February 1951, it is responsible for collecting and managing archives of central government agencies during the Republic of China period (1912-1949). As of 2024, SHAC holds over 2.58 million volumes and has shelves exceeding 50 thousand meters in length. The archive covers major historical events and figures of the Republic of China, including archives from various governments such as Nanjing Provisional Government and Wang Jingwei regime. SHAC opened to the public for the first time on 9 June 2017.

title: Sha Zukang
summary: Sha Zukang is a Chinese diplomat born in 1947. He served as the head of the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs from 2007 to 2012. Sha started his diplomatic career at the Chinese Embassy in the United Kingdom and held various positions, including Director-General of the Department of Arms Control. He also served as Ambassador for Disarmament Affairs and Deputy Permanent Representative to the United Nations Office at Geneva. Sha has held several high-profile roles, including Secretary-General to the Rio Earth Summit in 2012. He is known for being outspoken and has made several notable comments during his career as a diplomat.

title: Shangxinhe
summary: Shangxinhe is a former town in the Jianye District of Nanjing, China. It was located on the Jia River, a tributary of the Yangtze River. The town was known for its timber trade during the Ming and Qing dynasties, with Huizhou wood being shipped to various regions. Shangxinhe's economy reached its peak during the Qing dynasty, with up to 32 timber suppliers shipping wood to Jiangxi, Hubei, Hunan, and Sichuan. The town's annual Grand Lantern event was a notable cultural occurrence, featuring lanterns made from Huizhou wood. The introduction of the railroad led to a decline in Shangxinhe's economy.

title: Sheng Tongsheng
summary: Sheng Tongsheng was a Chinese veterinary physician and microbiologist. Born in 1911 at Changsha, he made significant contributions to veterinary education and modern Chinese veterinary medicine. He was the first president of China's first independent college of veterinary medicine. Sheng studied at National Central University, Shanghai Medical College, and the Universities of Munich and Berlin in Germany. He received his Dr. Med. degree from the University of Berlin in 1936 and a doctorate in veterinary medicine in 1938.

title: Shouheng Sun
summary: Shouheng Sun is a Chinese-American chemist. He holds the position of Vernon K. Krieble Professor of Chemistry and Professor of Engineering at Brown University. Sun's research focuses on nanochemistry and materials chemistry. He received a Bachelor of Science in chemistry from Sichuan University in 1984 and a Master's degree in chemistry from Nanjing University. Sun completed his doctorate in chemistry at Brown University in 1996 and began teaching there in 2005.

title: Shuang Chuanxue
summary: Shuang Chuanxue is a Chinese journalist, editor, and political figure. Born in January 1967 in Yizheng, Jiangsu, China, he joined the Chinese Communist Party in June 1987. Shuang completed his postgraduate education and began working at Yangzhou Normal College in August 1991, where he remained until 2002. He then served in various roles within the Publicity Department of the Jiangsu Provincial Party Committee from 2005 to 2016. In September 2016, he moved to Xinhua Daily and was promoted to President in March 2018. He currently serves as the Chinese Communist Party Committee Secretary and President of Xinhua Daily, Chairman of the Xinhua Daily Media Group, and a member of the 14th National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference.

title: Six Dynasties
summary: The Six Dynasties was a period in Chinese history spanning from 220-589 AD, following the end of the Eastern Han dynasty and preceding the Sui dynasty. This era is characterized by six Han-ruled dynasties, including the Wei, Jin, and Southern and Northern dynasties. The primary southern six dynasties were based in Jiankang (modern-day Nanjing), while the northern six dynasties existed concurrently. The Six Dynasties period saw significant cultural and economic development, particularly in southern China, which became the country's new economic center. This era also marked a flourishing of Buddhism in China and saw increased openness towards male homosexuality, with terms like "Nanfeng" emerging to describe it. The period's poetry is notable for its frank descriptions of love and beauty, with the anthology "New Songs from the Jade Terrace" being a significant example.

title: Six-Dynasty Juniper
summary: The Six-Dynasty Juniper is a Chinese juniper tree located on the campus of Southeast University in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It is estimated to be over 1500 years old and dates back to the Liang dynasty, specifically during the reign of the Wu Emperor (502-549). The tree was planted within the Liang imperial palace compound and has survived despite the destruction of the palace by war. The site was later used for various institutions, including the Imperial Academy of the Ming and Southeast University. The tree's location is at 32°03′32″N 118°47′11″E.

title: Slater Rhea
summary: Slater David Rhea is an American singer, songwriter, and television personality based in China. Born in 1987 in Alexandria, Louisiana, Rhea has a background in international relations and holds positions as lecturer in English and International Studies at Beijing Foreign Studies University. He performs in Chinese, Mongolian, and English, singing traditional Chinese folk tunes, pop music, educational songs, American jazz standards, and rock-and-roll. Rhea has been referred to as a cultural ambassador and "musical diplomat" due to his efforts in improving U.S.–China relations through music. He has appeared on various Chinese television stations and holds dual master's degrees in China Studies and International Politics from Johns Hopkins University and Nanjing University.

title: Social Development Academy, Nanjing Normal University
summary: The Social Development Academy at Nanjing Normal University is an institute focused on social development. Its predecessor dates back to the Liangjiang Normal School in 1907, and it has undergone various changes since then. The academy established its current form in 2001 and offers undergraduate programs in several departments, including history, geography, sociology, and social security. It has the authority to award doctoral degrees in specific history and master's degrees in 11 departments. The academy has achieved significant development, with notable achievements in teaching and research, including winning national and provincial-level awards and publishing numerous works.

title: Song Bao'an
summary: Song Bao'an is a Chinese pesticide expert and the current president of Guizhou University. Born in February 1963, he was raised in Shiqian County, Guizhou. Song received his Bachelor of Science degree from Guizhou University in 1983, and later earned a Master of Engineering degree from Shenyang Research Institute of Chemical Industry and a Doctor of Science degree from Nanjing Agricultural University in 2003. He was a visiting scholar at the University of California, Berkeley from 2001 to 2002. Song joined Guizhou University's faculty in 1986 and became president of the university in May 2018.

title: St. Jacobi Church, Wuhu
summary: St. James's Church, Wuhu is a Protestant church located in Jinghu District, Wuhu, Anhui, China. Founded by the Episcopal Church in 1905, its history spans over a century. The church was relocated 10 meters eastward in June 2011 and has been recognized as a significant cultural relic. It was inscribed as a municipal cultural relic in 2001 and a provincial one in 2012. The church features Gothic architectural style, with a bell tower standing at 25 meters high and a construction area of 389 square meters.

title: St. Paul's Church, Nanjing
summary: St. Paul's Church is a Three Self church in Nanjing, China. Established in 1912 by American Episcopalian missionary G.M.B. Gill on Taiping Road, it initially served as a place of worship in the densely populated old city centre. A new building was constructed next to the original one in 1922, and during World War II, it provided shelter for refugees. After the Cultural Revolution in 1966, the church stopped functioning but was returned to the Three-Self Patriotic Movement in 1984 and reopened in 1985. The church is built in the Gothic Revival style with polished bricks and has been designated as a 'Municipality Protected Historic Site' by the city of Nanjing.

title: Stone sculptures of Southern Dynasty mausoleums
summary: The stone sculptures of Southern Dynasty mausoleums are located in Jiangsu Province, eastern China. They are situated in four areas: Nanjing, Jiangning, Danyang, and Jurong. These sculptures are Major National Historical and Cultural Sites in Jiangsu. Created around 1,500 years ago during the Liu Song dynasty of the Southern Dynasties, they feature various stone carvings including Qilin, Tianlu, Bixie, columns, steles, and winged animals. The sculptures reflect cultural exchanges between China, Ancient Greece, and Ancient Persia, showcasing ancient stone art treasures.

title: Suguo Supermarket
summary: Suguo Supermarket, founded in 1996 as a predecessor to the Jiangsu Fruit & Food Corporation, is now the largest retailer in Jiangsu province, China. The company has made significant contributions to convenience and has maintained a top 10 ranking for nearly eleven years, holding over 50% of the market share in Jiangsu. Suguo Supermarket has expanded to cover multiple provinces, including Anhui, Hebei, Hubei, Henan, and Shandong. The company has received numerous awards, including Jiangsu Outstanding Enterprise in 1999 and China Meritorious Enterprise in 2008. Suguo Supermarket has also been recognized for its innovative strategies, including expanding into low-cost markets and developing rural areas.

title: Sun Duoci
summary: Sun Duoci (1912-1975) was a Chinese artist known for her oil paintings, sketches, and ink and wash works. Born in Shou County, Anhui province to educated parents, she was taught by renowned artist Xu Beihong, who regarded her as a "painter of genius" and had an affair with her. Sun's family background was notable, as her grandfather founded the Beijing Normal University and her father was a key figure in the late Qing dynasty's democratic revolution. After failing to enter National Central University, Sun audited classes in the fine arts department and took lessons from Xu Beihong. She became a full-time student with him in 1931, but their affair led to controversy and Sun eventually left the university.

title: Sun Jiazheng
summary: Sun Jiazheng is a Chinese politician born in March 1944 in Siyang, Jiangsu Province. He joined the Chinese Communist Party in January 1966 and graduated from Nanjing University in 1968 with a major in Chinese. Sun entered politics during the Cultural Revolution and held various positions, including secretary of Nanjing Committee of Chinese Communist Party and deputy secretary of Jiangsu Committee of Chinese Communist Party. He served as Minister of Radio, Film and Television from 1994 to 1998 and then as Minister of Culture from March 1998 to March 2008. Sun also held positions such as chairman of the China Federation of Literary and Art Circles from 2006 to 2016.

title: Sun Piaoyang
summary: Sun Piaoyang is a Chinese pharmaceutical executive and billionaire born in 1958. He holds a bachelor's degree from China Pharmaceutical University and a doctoral degree from Nanjing University. Sun took over Jiangsu Hengrui Medicine in 1990 and transformed it into one of China's largest producers of anti-infection and anti-cancer medicines. He is married to Zhong Huijuan, a fellow billionaire and chairwoman of Hansoh Pharmaceutical. They have one child together named Sun Yuan.

title: Sun Shu
summary: Sun Shu was a Chinese geologist born on July 23, 1933, in Jintan, Jiangsu Province. He graduated from the geology department of Nanjing University and began working at the Institute of Geology of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Sun served as Director of the Institute from 1984 and was elected an academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 1991. He also became a fellow of The World Academy of Sciences in 1989 and held various professorships at Chinese universities. Sun died on February 11, 2018, at the age of 84.

title: Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum
summary: The Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum is located at the foot of Purple Mountain in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It was constructed between 1926 and 1929 to honor Sun Yat-sen, the "Father of Modern China," who died in 1925. The mausoleum was designed by Lü Yanzhi and completed by Poy Gum Lee, blending traditional Chinese styles with modern architecture. The design competition for the mausoleum received over 40 proposals, and Lü Yanzhi's proposal was selected unanimously. The mausoleum features a three-tier stone stand with a bronze ding, an ancient Chinese vessel symbolizing power. Sun Yat-sen's body was embalmed and temporarily stored in Beijing before being buried at the mausoleum on June 1, 1929.

title: Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum Music Stage
summary: The Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum Amphitheatre is a building located in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China. It covers an area of over 4,200 square meters and serves as a stage for ceremonies, musical performances, and speeches to commemorate Dr. Sun Yat-sen. The amphitheatre was designed by Yang Tingbao and built in 1932-1933 with a donation of 95,000 RMB from the San Francisco Chinese-Americans and the Liaoning Province Kuomintang branch. It features a semicircular layout with an arc-shaped reinforced concrete stage and a spirit screen inspired by ancient Greek and Chinese architectural elements. The amphitheatre includes a crescent-shaped lotus pond, wave-shaped stairs, and an auditorium that can host 3,000 listeners.

title: Suning Appliance Group
summary:
Suning Appliance Group Co., Ltd. is a Chinese holding company and the third largest shareholder of Suning Appliance, after Zhang Jindong (founder) and Alibaba Group. The company was formerly known as Jiangsu Suning Appliance Co., Ltd. and Jiangsu Suning Appliance Group Co., Ltd. As of 2002, the company was owned by senior staff members including Zhang Jindong and Sun Weimin. In 2013, Zhang owned a 39.75% stake in the company, while Bu Yang was the major shareholder with a 40.17% stake.

The company has made various investments, including purchasing a 1% stake in Hydoo International Holding Limited and owning a 7.37% stake in Japanese listed company LAOX. Suning Appliance Group also owned a 25% stake in Suning Real Estate and subscribed CN¥20 billion new shares of Hengda Real Estate, a subsidiary of Evergrande Group.

title: Swallow Rock
summary: Swallow Rock is a small scenic area in northwest Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China. It is one of the 48 scenic areas in Nanjing and stands at 36 meters in the Yangtze River. The rock is shaped like a flying swallow and is one of three famous rocks in Nanjing. It has historical significance, with Li Bai visiting and writing a poem about the rock, and the Qianlong Emperor leaving a poem during his inspection tour in the Qing dynasty. A pavilion and stone tablet stand on top of the rock, while a small monument marks it as one of the sites of the Nanjing Massacre in 1937-38.

title: Taishan Subdistrict, Nanjing
summary: Taishan Subdistrict is a subdistrict in Pukou District, Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It has administrative control over 15 residential communities and one village as of 2018. The subdistrict is located in Jiangsu province, China. Further information on Taishan Subdistrict is limited due to its status as a stub article, and expansion of this information would be beneficial.

title: Tamaki Matsuoka
summary: Tamaki Matsuoka is a Japanese activist born in 1947 in Osaka, Japan. She challenges Japanese perceptions of the country's war crimes during the Second Sino-Japanese War, particularly in relation to the Rape of Nanjing. As a primary school teacher, Matsuoka felt compelled to teach her students the truth about Japanese war crimes and has visited Nanjing, China multiple times to interview veterans and survivors. Her works include the 2009 documentary "Torn Memories of Nanjing" and several books, including "Nanjing zhan: xun zhao bei feng bi de ji yi" published in 2002. Matsuoka is a member of the Japan-China Peace Research Organization and has been cautious about her safety due to threats from Japanese nationalist groups.

title: Tang I-Fang
summary: Tang I-Fang DUBC was a China-born Singaporean public servant, economic strategist, and businessman. Born on September 16, 1924, he graduated from National Central University (Nanjing University) with a B.Sc. in mechanical engineering in 1944 and later earned an MBA from Harvard Business School in 1948. Tang worked for the United Nations, advising developing nations on economic development and later became Chairman of the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) in 1959. Under his leadership, EDB transformed Singapore into a key regional and global hub for business. Tang is credited with devising plans for Jurong Town Corporation (JTC) and establishing Singapore's first Science Park. He served in various roles for the United Nations until his retirement, including chief of the ECAFE and consultant for UNDP. Tang passed away on September 26, 2013.

title: Tao Xingzhi
summary: Tao Xingzhi was a Chinese educator and reformer born on October 18, 1891, in She County, Anhui. He studied at Teachers College, Columbia University and the University of Illinois, returning to China in 1917. Tao championed progressive education and was a key figure in the development of modern education systems in China. He founded the National Association for the Advancement of Education and the National Association of Mass Education Movements, which promoted literacy campaigns and rural teacher education. Tao also established the Xiaozhuang Normal College in Nanjing, which produced innovative teaching techniques and trained teachers for rural schools.

title: Tao Xingzhi Memorial (Nanjing)
summary: The Tao Xingzhi Memorial is a memorial located in Qixia District, Nanjing, Jiangsu province, China. It was built to honor the Chinese scholar Tao Xingzhi and serves as both a tomb and museum. The memorial covers an area of 800 square meters, with a 25-meter building featuring a thatched cottage-style roof made from cement. Inside the building, there is a bronze statue of Tao and two exhibition rooms containing 120 pictures, manuscripts, and over 200 artifacts. The memorial is managed by Nanjing Xiaozhuang University, which was founded by Tao in 1926.

title: Taoye Ferry
summary: Taoye Ferry, also known as Nanpu Ferry, is a historical place in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province, China. Located near the confluence of the Qinhuai River and ancient Qingxi River, it was a famous ferry crossing during the Six Dynasties period (229-589 AD). The site is now situated at the Lishe Bridge, which was built in 1646 to replace the ferry. According to legend, Wang Xianzhi, a renowned calligrapher, composed a "Song of Taoye" for his beloved concubine while waiting at the ferry crossing. The site was later included in the "48 Scenes of Jinling" and has been preserved as a heritage park since 2003, featuring a gallery of steles with poems and restored scenic spots.

title: Te May Ching
summary: Te May Ching was a seed physiologist born on January 9, 1923, in Suzhou, China. She earned a B.S. from Central University in Nanjing and later moved to the United States, earning an M.S. and Ph.D. from Michigan State University in 1950 and 1954, respectively. Ching worked as an Assistant Agronomist at Oregon State College from 1956 to 1988, teaching courses on seed physiology and conducting research. She developed a method using firefly extract to investigate differences between shriveled and plump seeds in 1983. Ching was a Fellow of the American Society of Agronomy/Crop Science of America and served on several professional organizations. She retired from OSU in 1988, becoming an emeritus professor, and passed away on April 21, 2020.

title: The Second Yuying Foreign Languages School of Nanjing
summary: The Second Yuying Foreign Languages School of Nanjing is a state-owned, privately run school in Nanjing, China. Established in 1993, it initially had 2 classes and 19 staff but has since grown to cover an area of 18 acres with two campuses, offering 72 classes. The school has over 2,700 students and approximately 400 staff members. It annually sends a teacher abroad for training and invites foreign teachers to the school, promoting international exchange and education.

title: Third Battle of Nanjing
summary: The Third Battle of Nanjing was the final major engagement of the Taiping Rebellion in the Qing Empire. The battle took place from November 1863 to March 1864, resulting in the fall of Nanjing, the capital of the Taiping Heavenly Kingdom. The Qing forces, led by Zeng Guofan and his brother Zeng Guoquan, gradually encircled the city, taking key positions and cutting off supply lines. The Taiping army, led by Hong Xiuquan, was eventually forced to surrender, with over 200,000 troops defecting or being killed. The battle ended on March 19, 1864, with the Qing forces capturing Nanjing and marking the end of the Taiping Rebellion.

title: Tomb of Chang Yuchun
summary: The Tomb of Chang Yuchun is a historical site located on Purple Mountain in Nanjing, Jiangsu. It dates back to 1369 and is the final resting place of Chang Yuchun, a military general from the late Yuan to early Ming dynasties. The tomb features stone animals and warriors in front of it, and was categorized as a "Major National Historical and Cultural Site in Jiangsu" by the State Council of China. In 2003, it was inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List as an extension of the Imperial Tombs of the Ming and Qing Dynasties site. The tomb was renovated in 1871 by Chang's descendants, and listed as a major historical site in Jiangsu in 2006.

title: Tomb of the King of Boni
summary: The Tomb of the King of Boni is a historical site located in Nanjing, China. It belongs to Abdul Majid Hassan, also known as Maharaja Karna or Ma Na Re Jia Na, the ruler of Boni, a medieval state on Borneo Island. The tomb was built in the early 15th century during the Ming Dynasty under the reign of the Yongle Emperor. It is one of only two foreign rulers' tombs in China, and an important heritage site under state protection. The tomb was rediscovered in 1958 after being abandoned and renamed "Huihuifen" by local residents. It was listed as a Key Cultural Relic Unit under State Protection in 2001 and is now a significant cultural site.

title: Tomio Hora
summary: Tomio Hora was a Japanese historian and professor at Waseda University. Born on November 14, 1906, he was a graduate of Waseda University's literature department and received his Doctor of Letters from the same institution. Hora is known for his efforts to counter Nanjing Massacre denial in Japan, particularly through his 1972 publication "Nankin Jiken," which refuted revisionist accounts of the incident. He continued to publish scholarly works on the subject throughout the 1970s and was a founding member of the Study Group on the Nanjing Incident in 1984. Hora passed away on March 15, 2000.

title: Tong Tekong
summary: Tong Tekong was a historian, academic, and author. Born on 23 August 1920 in Anhui province, China, he graduated from Nanjing University with a major in history. Tong later earned his PhD at Columbia University and went on to teach Chinese history there. He also worked as a professor at the City University of New York for 20 years, retiring in 1991.

title: Tony Xu
summary: Tony Xu is an American billionaire businessman and the co-founder and CEO of DoorDash. Born in Nanjing, China in 1983 or 1984, Xu immigrated to the United States with his parents at age four and grew up in Champaign, Illinois. He earned degrees from the University of California, Berkeley, and the Stanford Graduate School of Business. Xu co-founded DoorDash in 2013 with his Stanford classmates and led the company's initial public offering (IPO) in December 2020, making him a billionaire at age 36. He is also a signatory to the Giving Pledge and has made significant donations in support of various causes.

title: Tsen Shui Fang
summary: Tsen Shui Fang (1875-1969) was a Chinese nurse who worked at Ginling College in Nanjing during the Japanese invasion. She assisted American missionary Wilhelmina "Minnie" Vautrin in providing aid to women and children. Tsen kept a diary during this time, which is considered the only firsthand account of the Nanjing Massacre by a Chinese national. Her diary has been added to the UNESCO Memory of the World Programme and is kept in the Second Historical Archives of China. Tsen later became the director of dormitories at Ginling College and was forced to leave in 1942 when the Japanese army took over. After the war, she returned to her hometown of Wuchang and lived in poverty until her death at 94.

title: Tsien Tsuen-hsuin
summary:
Tsien Tsuen-hsuin was a Chinese-American bibliographer, librarian, and sinologist. Born on January 11, 1910, in Taixian (modern Taizhou), Jiangsu Province, he was a member of a prominent family that descended from King Qian Liu. Tsien studied at the University of Nanking, graduating in 1932 with a degree in history and library science. He worked at various libraries in China, including the National Library of Nanking and Shanghai.

During World War II, Tsien risked his life to smuggle tens of thousands of rare books outside of Japanese-occupied China. He packed 30,000 volumes for shipment to the United States and used a subterfuge to evade Japanese confiscation. After the war, Tsien was sent to the United States in 1947 to manage the repatriation of these volumes.

Tsien served as a professor at the University of Chicago Graduate Library School and curator of its East Asian Library from 1949 to 1978. He is known for his studies on the history of Chinese books, bibliography, paleography, and science and technology.

title: Tuniu
summary: Tuniu Corporation is a Chinese online travel agency founded in 2006 by CEO Donald Dunde Yu and COO Alex Haifeng Yan. The company was listed on the Nasdaq Stock Exchange on May 9, 2014, raising $72 million in its initial public offering. Tuniu has offices in Nanjing, Shanghai, and Beijing, with a strategic collaboration agreement signed with Ctrip in 2014. The company has received investments from various groups, including JD.com and HNA Tourism Group, with JD.com becoming its largest shareholder in 2015. Tuniu has also acquired stakes in several Chinese travel agencies and partnered with the Tourism Authority of Thailand to boost tourism.

title: University of Nanking
summary: The University of Nanking, also known as Private University of Nanking or Jinling University, was a private university in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. Founded in 1888 by C.H. Fowler as Nanking University (Huiwen Shuyuan), it initially offered liberal arts, divinity, and medicine. The university merged with Union Christian College in 1910 and was granted a charter by the Regents of the University of the State of New York in 1911. The university was damaged during the Nanking incident of 1927 and later merged with Ginling College in 1951. In 1952, the University of Nanking was merged with Nanjing University following a reorganization of Chinese higher education.

title: Walled city of Nanjing
summary:
Nanjing City, also known as the Walled city of Nanjing, is a historical core area enclosed by the Nanjing City Wall built in the early Ming dynasty. The area spans approximately 55 square kilometers and includes parts of Qinhuai, Jianye, Gulou, and Xuanwu districts. The present Nanjing City Wall was constructed during the Ming dynasty.

The city has a rich history dating back to 333 BCE, when it was known as the Stone City. It has undergone several name changes and renovations throughout its history, including being renamed Jianye by the Kingdom of Wu and later becoming Nanking during the Ming dynasty. The imperial palace site is located in the eastern part of the city, and the Nanjing Museum is situated nearby.

title: Wang Chunning
summary: Wang Chunning is a former Chinese general born in March 1963 in Nanjing, Jiangsu. He joined the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) in April 1986 and entered politics in July 1985. Wang held various positions, including chief of staff of the 1st Group Army (2009), commander of the 12th Group Army (2014-2016), and commander of the Beijing Garrison (2016-2020). He was appointed chief of staff of the People's Armed Police in April 2020 and commander in December 2020. Wang was removed as a deputy to the National People's Congress in September 2025 and expelled from the CCP and the PLA for "serious violations of discipline and law" in October 2025.

title: Wang Geng
summary: Wang Geng was a Chinese scientist and academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Born Wang Jiwei on 11 October 1927 in Nanjing, Jiangsu, he later changed his name to Wang Geng in 1960. Wang joined the Chinese Communist Party in April 1949 and graduated from Chiao Tung University with a degree in Electrical Engineering. He made significant contributions to the development of steam turbine generators, including the world's first 12,000 kW double water-cooled steam turbine generator in 1958. Wang received multiple State Science and Technology Progress Awards for his work, including a First Class award in 1985. He died on 8 May 2024 at the age of 96 in Shanghai.

title: Wang Hanzhou residence
summary: Wang Hanzhou Residence is a traditional Chinese courtyard-style wood building located at 83, Hebei Avenue in the New River area of Nanjing. Built during the late Qing dynasty, it features a courtyard, atrium, and dwelling rooms with ornate wood carvings. The structure has three stories, including a half-moon shaped hall on the top floor with views of the pier and New River. Wang Hanzhou, a major Chinese timber merchant and "enlightened gentleman," built the residence in the heart of the New River area, which was an important center for the timber trade during the Ming and Qing dynasties. The building is considered a masterpiece of residential architecture in Nanjing, but its future remains uncertain despite being protected.

title: Wang Hui (intellectual)
summary: Wang Hui is a Chinese professor and intellectual born on October 10, 1959, in Yangzhou, Jiangsu. He received his Ph.D. from the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences in 1988 and has been a prominent figure in China's intellectual scene. Wang was involved in the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests and has written extensively on contemporary Chinese literature, intellectual history, and politics. He is often associated with the Chinese New Left movement but has refused this label, citing its Western connotations and his own distinct historical context. Wang's views have been subject to controversy, with some critics accusing him of defending party-state dictatorship and others praising his nuanced analysis of China's past and present.

title: Wang Ning (general)
summary: Wang Ning is a retired Chinese general born in August 1955 in Nanjing, Jiangsu. He joined the People's Liberation Army (PLA) in 1970 and served in various positions, including commander of an artillery regiment in the 12th Group Army from 1986 to 1992. Wang held several high-ranking positions, including Chief of Staff of the Shanghai Garrison (2003), Commander of Jiangxi Military District (2006-2010), and Chief of Staff of the Beijing Military Region. He was appointed commander of the People's Armed Police in 2014 and retired in December 2020. Wang is a member of the 19th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party and has held various other positions, including vice-chairperson of the National People's Congress Constitution and Law Committee.

title: Wang Quan (politician, born 1960)
summary: Wang Quan is a Chinese politician born in July 1960 in Yixian, Anhui. He began working as a sent-down youth in Xinhua Commune, Shuyang County, Jiangsu in August 1977. Wang rose through the ranks at the People's Bank of China, holding various positions including assistant director and deputy director. He later served as president of the Suzhou Central Sub-branch of the People's Bank of China and vice president of the Nanjing Branch. Wang has held several senior positions in Jiangsu, including Mayor of Wuxi and Party Secretary of Changzhou. He currently serves as Director of the Environment, Resources, and Urban-Rural Construction Committee of the Jiangsu Provincial People's Congress.

title: Wang Wenyin
summary: Wang Wenyin is a Chinese businessman born in 1968 in Anhui province. He graduated from Nanjing University in 1993 and started his own power cord business, which eventually grew into Amer International Group. The company produces cable and copper products and has expanded globally through the acquisition of mining assets. Wang Wenyin was ranked as one of the world's billionaires by Forbes in 2015, with a net worth of $15 billion and was the 8th richest man in China. He resides in Shenzhen, China.

title: Wang Xuefei
summary: Wang Xuefei is a retired Chinese politician born in May 1956 in Xinyang, Henan Province. He joined the Chinese Communist Party in April 1975 and began working in April 1973 as a sent-down youth. Wang held various positions, including deputy director of the Urban Affairs Division and deputy secretary-general of the Provincial Committee. He was elected vice chairman of the Jiangsu Provincial Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC) in January 2015. Wang also served as a member of the Party Group and minister of the United Front Work Department of the Provincial Committee.

title: Wang Yanxin
summary: Wang Yanxin is a Chinese scientist and the current president of China University of Geosciences (Wuhan). Born in November 1963 in Yuanping, Shanxi, he graduated from Nanjing University in 1984. Wang received his master's degree and doctorate in hydrogeology from China University of Geosciences (Wuhan) in 1987 and 1990, respectively. He has held various positions at the university, including associate professor (1992), full professor (1994), and vice-president (2000). He served as a senior visiting scholar at the University of Waterloo from 1998 to 1999. Wang was promoted to president in 2010, a position he currently holds.

title: Wang Yinglai
summary: Wang Yinglai was a Chinese biochemist born on November 13, 1907. He is recognized for being the first person to create synthetic insulin through a major scientific breakthrough in 1965. Wang was elected as one of the first group of scientists to the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 1955. He founded and directed the Shanghai Institute of Biochemistry from 1958 to 1984, recruiting prominent Chinese scientists during this time. Wang's work on insulin synthesis was considered worthy of a Nobel Prize by several notable scientists, but he did not receive the award due to the Cultural Revolution.

title: Wang Zuo'an
summary: Wang Zuo'an is a Chinese politician born in May 1958 in Yixing, Jiangsu. He joined the workforce in September 1977 and the Chinese Communist Party in June 1985. Wang graduated from Nanjing University with a major in philosophy and was assigned to the United Front Work Department. He worked his way up through the State Administration for Religious Affairs, becoming its director in 2009. Wang concurrently served as vice-minister of the United Front Work Department from March 2018 to 2022.

title: Wei Huixiao
summary: Wei Huixiao is a Chinese naval officer born in November 1977 to a Zhuang ethnicity family in Baise, Guangxi. She graduated from Nanjing University in 2000 and joined Huawei as a senior vice president secretary before enlisting in the People's Liberation Army (PLA) in January 2012. Wei attended Dalian Naval Academy and rose through the ranks, becoming a vice captain of several destroyers. In April 2022, she became the first female captain of the People's Liberation Army Navy, commanding Type 052D destroyer Shaoxing. Wei is also a representative of the 19th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party.

title: Wei Keliang
summary: Wei Keliang is a Chinese politician born in January 1962 in Jian'ou, Fujian Province. He holds postgraduate and Master's degrees in Philosophy. Wei joined the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) in March 1986 and began his career in August 1982. He has served in various administrative roles, including director of the Fujian Provincial Department of Land and Resources (2008-2013) and chairman of the Xiamen CPPCC (2020-2025). Wei is a member of the 14th National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC) and its Committee for Liaison with Hong Kong, Macao, Taiwan and Overseas Chinese.

title: Wilson Plumer Mills
summary: Wilson Plumer Mills was an American missionary and humanitarian born on December 1, 1883. He earned degrees from Davidson College, the University of Oxford, and Columbia Theological Seminary before joining the YMCA in China. In 1937, Mills became vice-chairman of the International Committee for the Nanking Safety Zone during the Japanese occupation of Nanjing. He actively documented Japanese atrocities and protested to the Japanese Embassy, advocating for humanitarian aid after John Rabe's departure. Mills was interned by Japanese forces in 1941 but repatriated in 1943 and continued his work until his death on February 26, 1959.

title: Wotao Yin
summary: Wotao Yin is a professor of mathematics at the University of California, Los Angeles. He conducts research in optimization, parallel and distributed computing, and inverse problems. Yin received his PhD in operations research from Columbia University in 2006 under the supervision of Donald Goldfarb. His dissertation focused on the TV-L1 model theory, computation, and applications. Wotao Yin has received several awards for his work, including the 2016 Morningside Gold Medal and an NSF CAREER award in 2008.

title: Wu Liangyong
summary: Wu Liangyong is a Chinese architect and urban planner born on 7 May 1922 in Nanjing. He obtained his education from the National Central University, American Guangxi Art Academy, and Cranbrook Academy of Art. Wu co-founded the Faculty of Architecture at Tsinghua University in 1946 and taught there for fifty years. He held various administrative positions, including vice-president of the International Union of Architects and chairman of the World Society for the Science of Human Settlements. Wu's notable works include the redevelopment of Ju'er Hutong in Beijing and Tiananmen Square, as well as his contributions to the 2008 Summer Olympics. He received several awards for his work, including a World Habitat Award and the Prince Claus Award.

title: Wu Qiang (officeholder)
summary: Wu Qiang is a Chinese official born in August 1966, in Xinhuang Dong Autonomous County, Hunan. He received a Bachelor of Science from Nanjing University in 1988 and a Master of Engineering from Tianjin University in 2005. Wu joined the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) in November 1994 and has held various government positions, including deputy director of Guizhou Provincial Communications Department (2002), vice mayor and deputy party branch secretary of Bijie (2011-2012), director of Guizhou Provincial Economic and Information Technology Commission (2016-2020), and vice governor of Guizhou (2018-2020). He is currently the Chinese Communist Party Committee Secretary of Bijie and secretary general of the CCP Guizhou Provincial Committee.

title: Wu Rongsheng
summary: Wu Rongsheng was a Chinese meteorologist born on 17 January 1934, in Rui'an County, Zhejiang. He attended Nanjing University, graduating in 1956 with a major in the Department of Meteorology. Wu later became a professor at Nanjing University and served as president of the Chinese Meteorological Society from 2002. He was also an academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences and a member of the Chinese Communist Party, joining in 1983. Wu married Feng Ruiying and had a son, Wu Ruixin. He died on 22 August 2025 at the age of 91 in Nanjing, Jiangsu.

title: Wu Youxun
summary: Wu Youxun was a Chinese physicist born on 26 April 1897 and died on 30 November 1977. He is also known as Y. H. Woo, with the courtesy name Zhèngzhī. Wu graduated from Nanjing Higher Normal School and was associated with the Department of Physics at Tsinghua University. He studied x-ray and electron scattering as a graduate student at the University of Chicago, verifying the Compton effect. Wu served as president of National Central University and Jiaotong University in Shanghai.

title: Wuhan Nationalist government
summary: The Wuhan Nationalist government was a left-wing government of the Kuomintang (KMT) Party of China based in Wuhan from December 5, 1926 to September 21, 1927. It was led by Eugene Chen and later Wang Jingwei after the capture of Wuhan during the Northern Expedition. The government split with Chiang Kai-shek in April 1927 following the "Shanghai massacre," resulting in a purge of communists and leftists. The Wuhan government eventually reconciled with the Nanjing faction, led by Chiang Kai-shek, and moved to Nanjing. The government was marked by conflict between the KMT and Chinese Communist Party (CCP), with Joseph Stalin attempting to merge the two parties for a bourgeois revolution.

title: Wuyi Lane
summary: Wuyi Lane, located on the south side of Qinhuai River in Nanjing, was originally a barracks for the army guarding the Stone City of Wu during the Three Kingdoms period. The name Wuyi translates to "black clothes," referring to non-commissioned officers' attire at that time. In the Eastern Jin period, aristocrats gathered in Wuyi Lane, making it a popular and famous location. Wang Dao and Xie An, the founding fathers of Eastern Jin, once resided there. A poem by Tang poet Liu Yuxi is based on Wuyi Lane, and the government restored the area in 1997 to commemorate Wang Dao and Xie An.

title: Xi Zhenfeng
summary: Xi Zhenfeng is a Chinese organic chemist born on April 2, 1963, in Henan. He received his B.S. degree from Xiamen University in 1983 and his M.S. degree from Nanjing University, Zhengzhou University, and Henan Institute of Chemistry in 1989. Xi obtained his Ph.D. degree from the Institute for Molecular Sciences, Japan, in 1996 under Professor Tamotsu Takahashi. He is a Chang Jiang Scholar Distinguished Professor at Peking University, China, and was elected as an academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2015. His research focuses on organometallic chemistry and organic synthesis, including the development of synthetic methodologies based on selective bond cleavage.

title: Xiang Zhang
summary: Zhang Xiang JP is a Chinese-American mechanical engineer and the 16th president and vice-chancellor of the University of Hong Kong, serving since July 2018. Born in December 1963, Zhang received his Bachelor of Science and Master of Science from Nanjing University, a Master of Science from the University of Minnesota, and his Doctor of Philosophy from the University of California, Berkeley in 1996. He is a member of several prestigious academies, including the United States National Academy of Engineering and Academia Sinica. Zhang's research focuses on materials physics, metamaterials, and nano-photonics, with over 390 journal papers published. He has been involved in controversy surrounding national security education and was accused of potential misconduct, including the purchase of a luxury vehicle without an open tender in 2023.

title: Xianlin University City
summary: Xianlin University City, also known as Xianlin, is a community in Nanjing, China. It was planned in 1995 and established in 2002 as the country's first university city. Located in Qixia District, it is home to 12 higher education institutions, including Nanjing University and Nanjing Normal University. The area was previously undeveloped rural property that was developed to meet urban expansion demands in 1989. Xianlin University City features a range of amenities, including two metro lines and nearly 20 bus lines.

title: Xiao Gongqin
summary: Xiao Gongqin is a Chinese historian and leading exponent of neoauthoritarianism. Born in 1945, Xiao has focused his historical research on the period between the late Qing dynasty and the early Republic of China. He is a professor at Shanghai Normal University, where he was promoted to associate professor in 1987 without holding a doctorate. Xiao's work has involved reevaluating the fall of the Qing dynasty and arguing for incremental reform based on China's national character. He supports strong leadership to guide modernization, incorporating Confucian influences and abandoning Marxism in favor of Chinese nationalism. Xiao advocates for eventual democratization, believing China can follow a path similar to Taiwan once the middle class is predominant.

title: Xiao Mausoleum
summary:
Ming Xiaoling Mausoleum is the final resting place of the Hongwu Emperor, founder of the Ming dynasty. Located at the southern foot of Purple Mountain in Nanjing, it was constructed between 1381 and 1405 with a huge expenditure of resources involving 100,000 laborers. The original wall was over 22.5 kilometers long and guarded by 5,000 troops.

The mausoleum features a monumental Great Golden Gate, a giant stone tortoise supporting the "Shengong Shengde Stele," and a 1,800-meter-long Sacred Way lined with stone animals and guardian figures. The Sifangcheng pavilion, which houses the tortoise, was rebuilt in 2007-2009 after its roof was destroyed during the Taiping Rebellion. The Lingxing Gate at the end of the Wengzhong Road was rebuilt in 2006.

title: Xiaodan Gu
summary: Xiaodan Gu is the Nina Bell Suggs endowed professor of Polymer Science and Engineering at The University of Southern Mississippi. He has been a professor at the university since 2017, focusing on studying the physics and morphology of conjugated polymers. Gu's research has resulted in recognitions including the NSF CAREER Award and the DOE Early Career Research Award. He received his Bachelor of Science in Chemistry from Nanjing University in 2008 and completed his Ph.D. in Polymer Science and Engineering at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst in 2014. Gu's research focuses on polymer semiconductors and the influence of physical forces on their properties and morphology. His lab has developed a method to investigate the mechanical properties of ultra-thin polymer films, called the Shear Motion Assisted Robust Transfer (SMART) method.

title: Xiaohui Fan
summary: Xiaohui Fan is an American astronomer and full professor at the University of Arizona. Born on December 9, 1971, in Beijing, China, he is known for his studies on quasars and supermassive black holes. Fan was named to Popular Science magazine's annual Brilliant Ten list in 2003 for developing methods to investigate distant quasars. He has pioneered the detection and discovery of high-redshift quasars since 2001, introducing new techniques that have shown supermassive black holes with masses up to 10 million solar masses existed within one billion years after the big bang. Fan has led several notable discoveries, including the farthest lensed quasar in 2019 and the most distant and oldest known quasar, QSO J0313–1806, in 2021.

title: Xiaoming Li
summary: Xiaoming Li is a Chinese scientist. He earned his Bachelor of Science in computational mathematics from Nanjing University in 1982 and later served as a lecturer there until 1987. Li then earned his PhD in educational psychology from the University of Minnesota in 1992. He has taught at several institutions, including the University of Maryland School of Medicine, West Virginia University, Wayne State University, and the University of South Carolina. In 2015, he became the SmartState Endowed Chair for Clinical Translational Research at the University of South Carolina.

title: Xiaoming Wang (paleontologist)
summary: Xiaoming Wang is a Chinese-born American vertebrate paleontologist and geologist. He specializes in the fossil evolution, systematics, and phylogeny of Cenozoic mammals. Wang has conducted research on the biostratigraphy and geochronology of Asia, paleoenvironments of the Tibetan Plateau, and mammalian migrations between Eurasia and North America. He is a curator at the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County and has contributed to naming various taxa. Wang co-authored the book "Dogs: Their Fossil Relatives and Evolutionary History" with Richard H. Tedford, published in 2008 by Columbia University Press.

title: Xie Qianni
summary: Xie Qianni (谢倩霓) is a Chinese writer known for her children's literature. Born in 1968 in Xiushui County, Jiangxi province, China, she graduated from Nanjing University's Chinese Department in 1989. Xie Qianni has served as the editor-in-chief of the literary journal Shaonian wenyi and is a member of both the China Writers Association and the Shanghai Writers Association. She has received several major children's literature prizes in China, including the National Outstanding Children's Literature Award and the Chen Bochui Children's Literature Award.

title: Xie Qimei
summary: Xie Qimei was a Chinese diplomat born in 1923 in Wujin District, Changzhou, Jiangsu. He received a bachelor's degree in Mathematics from National Central University in 1947 and began his career as a teacher before joining the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Xie worked in various roles, including culture counselor at the Chinese liaison office in the United States from 1973. He was appointed Under-Secretary-General of the United Nations in June 1985, a position he held until 1991. After leaving the UN, Xie served as president of the UN Association of China from 1992 to 2002. He died in 2009.

title: Xing Shanping
summary:
Xing Shanping is a Chinese politician born in April 1968 in He County, Ma'anshan, Anhui, China. She joined the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) in July 1993 and has held various positions, including member of the Standing Committee of the Fujian Provincial Committee of the CCP and Head of its Organization Department. 

She has also served as Deputy Secretary of the Shaanxi Provincial Committee of the CCP, Party Secretary of Shandong Agricultural University, and chairwoman and party secretary of the Shandong Provincial Women's Federation. Xing has held multiple roles in Fujian Province, including Head of the Publicity Department and President of the Fujian Federation of Social Sciences. 

In May 2024, she was designated as Deputy Secretary of the Shaanxi Provincial Committee of the CCP. Xing serves as an alternate member of the 20th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party and a delegate to the 20th National Congress of the CCP.

title: Xinhua Daily
summary: Xinhua Daily is the first newspaper published in the People's Republic of China by the Chinese Communist Party (CCP). Founded on January 11, 1938, in Hankou, it continued to publish after the fall of Wuhan in October 1938 and moved to Chongqing. The Xinhua Daily served as a propaganda instrument during the Second Sino-Japanese War, consolidating public sentiment against Japan. It faced competition from Jiefang Daily, which began publishing in 1941 under Mao Zedong's direct control. The newspaper was controlled directly by Zhou Enlai until February 1947 and later won the Third National Top 100 Newspapers in China in 2018.

title: Xinjiekou, Nanjing
summary: Xinjiekou is the central business district of Nanjing, People's Republic of China. It has undergone significant development since 1929, with four main roads meeting at a traffic circle and numerous buildings constructed in the 1930s. These include notable establishments such as The Domestic Bank, Zhejiang Xingye Bank, and the Central Shopping Center. In the 1980s, Jinling Restaurant became the tallest building in Xinjiekou. Today, it is home to many economic institutions and corporate headquarters, including 80 businesses among the top 500 global corporations.

title: Xu Chengzhong
summary: Chengzhong Xu is a researcher at Wayne State University in Detroit, Michigan. He was named an IEEE Fellow in 2016 for his contributions to resource management in parallel and distributed systems.

title: Xu Chuanyin
summary: Xu Chuanyin, also known as Hsu Tsuan-ing, was a Chinese educator and administrator born on November 23, 1884. He obtained degrees in agriculture from Nanking University and economics from the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign. During World War II, Xu served as a member of the International Committee for the Nanjing Safety Zone and held various positions to aid refugees, including head of the Housing Committee and vice president of the Nanjing branch of the World Red Swastika Society. After the war, he provided testimony in the International Military Tribunal for the Far East and assisted in exhuming mass graves. Xu Chuanyin died on September 24, 1971.

title: Xu Garden
summary: Xu Garden, also known as the West Garden or Xuyuan, is a Chinese garden located in Nanjing's Xuanwu District. It was originally the private garden of Zhu Gaoxu, a Ming dynasty prince, and later served as the residence of the Viceroy of Liangjiang during the Qing dynasty. The garden was destroyed during the Taiping Rebellion but rebuilt in 1870 by Zeng Guofan. It has since been used as the office and residence of several notable figures, including Sun Yat-sen. The garden features various structures, including the Paulownia Melody House and rockeries with interconnected caves. It was designated a Major Historical and Cultural Site Protected at the National Level in 1982.

title: Xu Jianbin
summary: Jianbin Xu is a Choh-Ming Li Professor of Electronic Engineering and Director of the Material Science and Technology Research Center at The Chinese University of Hong Kong (CUHK). He is also Academic Vice President of the Shenzhen Institutes of Advanced Technology, one of the major research institutes under Chinese Academy of Sciences. Xu graduated from Nanjing University in 1983 and received his Doctor of Natural Science (Dr. rer. nat.) from the University of Konstanz in Germany in 1993, focusing on nanoscience and nanotechnology. He has received numerous awards for his research, including the Higher Education Outstanding Scientific Research Output Awards and the Chang Jiang Scholar award. His research interests include scanning probe microscopy, advanced electronic materials, and nanoscale thermal conduction.

title: Xu Ming (politician, born 1956)
summary: Xu Ming is a retired Chinese politician born in May 1956. He began his career as a sent-down youth in June 1973 and joined the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) in April 1977. Xu graduated from Nanjing University with a degree in Chinese language and literature, later earning a postgraduate degree from the Central Party School. Throughout his career, he held various positions including party secretary of Dantu County, deputy commander and deputy party secretary of the Nanjing New Airport Construction Headquarters, chairman and party secretary of Jiangsu State Farms Group Co., Ltd., and vice governor of Jiangsu. Xu served as vice chairman and deputy party secretary of the Jiangsu Provincial Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference from 2016 to 2018.

title: Xu Shoulan v. Peng Yu
summary: The Peng Yu case, also known as the Nanjing Peng Yu Incident, was a civil lawsuit in China's People's Republic. In 2006, Peng Yu helped Xu Shoulan after she fell and broke her femur. Xu accused Peng of causing the fall, but an eyewitness claimed that she had fallen inexplicably while transferring between buses. Peng initially denied the accusation, but later admitted to accidentally pushing Xu as he was getting off a bus. The court initially ruled in favor of Xu, but Peng later agreed to pay her 10,000 yuan compensation. The case drew widespread media attention and public outcry due to its implication that the Chinese public is vulnerable to civil liability for lending help in emergency situations.

title: Xu Xin (Judaic scholar)
summary:
Xu Xin is a professor at Nanjing University and China's leading Judaic scholar. Born on June 16, 1949, in Jinan, Shandong province, he graduated from Nanjing University in 1977 as an English major. Initially teaching English and American literature, Xu's interest in Judaism began after meeting a Jew for the first time in 1986. He then focused on studying Judaism, Jewish culture, and Chinese Jewish history.

Xu has founded the Diane and Guilford Glazer Institute for Jewish and Israel Studies at Nanjing University, introducing modern Hebrew literature to Chinese readers. He has edited several books on Jewish topics and established MA and PhD programs in Jewish history and culture at Nanjing University.

title: Xuanwu Lake
summary:
Xuanwu Lake (Chinese: 玄武湖; pinyin: Xuánwǔ Hú) is a lake located in Xuanwu District, central-northeast Nanjing, Jiangsu. It is near the Nanjing Railway Station and Jiming Temple. The lake was formed when tectonic plates shifted, creating Mount Yanshan, and is named after a black dragon from a Southern dynasty legend. The lake has five interconnected islands and a circumference of 15 kilometers, with a surface area of 3.78 square kilometers.

The lake was used for naval battle exercises during the Song dynasty and as an imperial garden in the Ming dynasty. It was made into a park in 1911, and later renamed Xuanwu Lake Park in 1935. The lake has undergone efforts to improve water quality, including sediment dredging and algal bloom control, resulting in improved conditions for various creatures. The park features temples, pagodas, gardens, teahouses, and other attractions, including a small zoo.

title: Xuanzang Temple (Nanjing)
summary: Xuanzang Temple is a Buddhist temple located in Xuanwu District, Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It was built by the Xuanwu District Government in 2003 to commemorate Tang dynasty monk Xuanzang. The temple was established near the site of Sanzang Pagoda, which was built in 1943 to honor Xuanzang's Śarīra. In 2004, the temple was designated as a National Patriotism Education Demonstration Base by the Nanjing Municipal People's Government. In 2022, memorial tablets of Imperial Japanese Army war criminals were discovered at the temple, leading to the dismissal of the abbot and punishment of local officials.

title: Yang Jiechi
summary: Yang Jiechi is a Chinese senior diplomat and retired politician. Born on May 1, 1950, in Shanghai, he joined the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in 1972 after working at a factory. Yang studied international relations and later received a Doctor of History in world history from Nanjing University through an on-the-job graduate program. He held various positions, including Chinese Ambassador to the United States from 2000 to 2004 and Minister of Foreign Affairs from 2007 to 2013. Yang served as director of the Chinese Communist Party's Central Foreign Affairs Commission from 2013 to 2022 and State Councilor from 2013 to 2018.

title: Yang Wanming (diplomat)
summary: Yang Wanming is a Chinese diplomat born in March 1964 in Beijing. He studied Spanish at Nanjing University and later earned a master's degree in economics and a Doctor of Laws degree from the Graduate School of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. Yang began his diplomatic career in 1989 and has held various ambassadorial posts, including to Chile, Argentina, and Brazil. He served as Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary to these countries from 2012 to 2022. Yang currently serves as chair and Party Secretary of the Chinese People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries, leading China's efforts in public diplomacy and international friendship exchanges.

title: Yang Xianjin
summary:
Yang Xianjin is a Chinese politician born in December 1962 in Gaochun, Jiangsu. He holds a Ph.D. in biomedical engineering from Tianjin University and has served as a professor and doctoral advisor since 2001. Yang's career spans higher education, local government, and party leadership roles. 

He has held various positions including Party Secretary of East China University of Science and Technology, Tongji University, and Tianjin University. Yang also served as vice governor of Fujian Province from 2017 to an unknown date and has been a member of the Standing Committee of the Fujian Provincial Committee of the Chinese Communist Party since 2019.

title: Yangshan Quarry
summary: Yangshan Quarry is an ancient stone quarry near Nanjing, China. It has been used for centuries as a source of stone for buildings and monuments in Nanjing, including the Ming Xiaoling Mausoleum. The quarry is famous for a gigantic unfinished stele, abandoned during the reign of the Yongle Emperor in the early 15th century. The stele project was ambitious, comparable to other public works projects of the Yongle era, such as the construction of the Forbidden City in Beijing. The quarry is located on Yangshan Mountain, 15-20 km east of the eastern part of Nanjing City Wall and the Ming Xiaoling Mausoleum. The site has been worked since the Six Dynasties period, with limestone used for construction in and around Nanjing.

title: Yangtse Evening Post
summary: Yangtze Evening Post, also known as Yangtze Evening News, is a Chinese language state newspaper published in Nanjing, China. It is one of the world's most circulated newspapers and affiliated with the Xinhua News Agency. The paper was launched on January 1, 1986, as an evening newspaper established by Xinhua Daily. It is affiliated with the Jiangsu Provincial Committee of the Chinese Communist Party. The newspaper is published in simplified and traditional Chinese characters using pinyin romanization.

title: Yao Xiaodong
summary: Yao Xiaodong is a Chinese politician and journalist born in April 1962 in Zhenjiang, Jiangsu Province. He studied journalism at Fudan University from 1978 to 1982 and joined the Chinese Communist Party in March 1986. Yao held various leadership positions at Xinhua Daily and the Jiangsu Provincial Publicity Department, including deputy director of the reporting department and deputy minister. He served as mayor of Changzhou from 2012 to an unknown date, Party secretary of Huai'an from 2013 to an unknown date, and chairman of the Huai'an Municipal People's Congress from 2014 to 2019. Yao is currently Vice Chairman of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC) Jiangsu Provincial Committee and a member of its Party Leadership Group.

title: Yao-Tzu Li
summary: Yao-Tzu Li, also known as Y.T. Li, was a Chinese-American engineer and inventor born on February 1, 1914, in Beijing. He graduated from Beiping University and National Central University with degrees in aeronautical engineering before moving to the United States, where he earned master and doctor's degrees from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. At MIT, Li co-founded the Man-Vehicle Laboratory and collaborated with Charles Stark Draper on optimal control. He was elected a member of the United States National Academy of Engineering in 1987 for his contributions to innovation and engineering education. Li held over 60 US patents and founded several companies, including Dynisco and Setra Systems. He died on August 14, 2011, at the age of 97.

title: Yasuji Kaneko
summary: Yasuji Kaneko (1920-2010) was a former Imperial Japanese Army soldier and detainee of the Soviet Union's Siberian Internment and China's Fushun War Criminals Management Centre. He was known for his extensive war crimes testimony, including alleged involvement in Unit 731 and the spread of cholera. Kaneko started giving public testimony at age 76 in 1996, stating he murdered and raped many Chinese people. His testimony appeared in several films, including Japanese Devils and Iris Chang: The Rape of Nanking. However, some historians question the accuracy of his testimony due to inconsistencies with known historical facts and potential communist influence during his detention.

title: Yaxi Subdistrict
summary: Yaxi Subdistrict is a subdistrict in Gaochun District, Nanjing, Jiangsu province, China. As of 2020, it administers ten residential neighborhoods and twelve villages. Yaxi Subdistrict is notable for being China's first member of the Cittaslow movement. The Cittaslow movement is an international network promoting slow living and sustainable development in urban areas. Yaxi Subdistrict is a location article that requires further expansion to provide more information.

title: Ye Zhaoyan
summary: Ye Zhaoyan is a Chinese author born in July 1957 and based in Nanjing. He comes from a notable family, with his paternal grandfather Ye Shengtao being one of China's most influential educators and his mother Yao Cheng being a famous Wuxi opera actress. Ye Zhaoyan's work has been translated into multiple languages, including English. His novel "A Flower's Shade" was adapted into the 1996 film "Temptress Moon," directed by Chen Kaige, although Ye was not credited in the film.

title: Yi Li Keng
summary: Yi-Li Keng was a Chinese botanist born in 1897 in Nanjing. He specialized in the study of grasses, particularly the tribe Triticeae of the Poaceae family. Keng graduated from Nanjing University in 1927 and later earned his A.M. (1932) and Ph.D. (1933) from George Washington University, with his thesis being "The Grasses of China" which covered 154 genera and 536 species. He became a professor at Nanjing University in 1934, where he worked for the remainder of his career. Keng's work on grasses in China was incorporated into the Chinese-language Flora Reipublicae Popularis Sinicae, with an English translation and update released in 2007.

title: Yongning Subdistrict, Nanjing
summary: Yongning Subdistrict is a subdistrict in Pukou District, Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It has administrative control over 8 residential communities and 3 villages as of 2018. The subdistrict is located in Jiangsu province, China. Yongning Subdistrict falls under the jurisdiction of Pukou District in Nanjing city. This article is a stub and requires further expansion for more information.

title: You Xiaozeng
summary: You Xiaozeng was a Chinese inorganic chemist. Born in January 1934, he served as an educator and academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. You Xiaozeng passed away on 19 November 2016 at the age of 83 in Nanjing. He is currently a subject of a stub article on Wikipedia, awaiting expansion for further information.

title: Yu Qingjiang
summary: Yu Qingjiang is a Chinese lieutenant general born in September 1963 in Nanjing, Jiangsu. He graduated from several institutions including the Air Force Political College and the PLA National Defence University. Yu Qingjiang has held various positions within the People's Liberation Army Air Force (PLAAF), including commander of the 30th Air Force Aviation Division and chief of staff. He served as president of the PLA Air Force Command College from 2015 to 2017 and became chief of staff of the PLAAF in December 2017. Yu Qingjiang was promoted to lieutenant general in June 2019 and is also a representative of the 19th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party.

title: Yuan-Cheng Fung
summary: Yuan-Cheng "Bert" Fung was a Chinese-American bioengineer and writer. Born in Jiangsu Province, China on September 15, 1919, he earned degrees from National Central University and the California Institute of Technology. Fung was a founding figure in bioengineering, tissue engineering, and biomechanics, and is known as the "Founder of Modern Biomechanics". He published prominent texts on biomechanics and was a principal founder of the Journal of Biomechanics. Fung held various academic positions, including Professor Emeritus at the University of California San Diego, and was elected to several prestigious academies, including the United States National Academy of Sciences. Fung died on December 15, 2019 at the age of 100.

title: Yuejiang Tower
summary: Yuejiang Tower is a building located on Lion Mountain in Nanjing, Jiangsu. It was built atop the mountain where Zhu Yuanzhang defeated Chen Youliang's forces in 1360, marking a significant event in the establishment of the Ming Dynasty. The tower was initially ordered by Zhu Yuanzhang but not built until 2001, when it was completed and opened to the public. It stands at a height of 52 meters with seven layers, featuring distinct Ming Dynasty style and classical royal markings. The building is considered one of the Four Major Famous Buildings in Jiangnan, along with Yellow Crane Tower, Tengwang Pavilion, and Yueyang Tower.

title: Yuejiang Tower
summary: Yuejiang Tower is a building located on Lion Mountain in Nanjing, Jiangsu. It was built atop the mountain where Zhu Yuanzhang defeated Chen Youliang's forces in 1360, marking a significant event in the establishment of the Ming Dynasty. The tower was initially ordered by Zhu Yuanzhang but not built until 2001, when it was completed and opened to the public. It stands at a height of 52 meters with seven layers, featuring distinct Ming Dynasty style and classical royal markings. The building is considered one of the Four Major Famous Buildings in Jiangnan, along with Yellow Crane Tower, Tengwang Pavilion, and Yueyang Tower.

title: Yuen Biao
summary: Yuen Biao is a Hong Kong actor, martial artist, and stuntman born Ha Lingchun on July 26, 1957. He trained at the Peking Opera School's China Drama Academy alongside Jackie Chan and Sammo Hung, where he was given the stage name Yuen Biao. He has worked on over 130 films, including starring roles in six Hong Kong films with Chan and Hung as part of the "Three Dragons." Yuen Biao has also appeared in eight television series for TVB and has played roles in various films, including "The Prodigal Son," "Dreadnaught," and "Project A." He has worked as a stuntman, doubling for actors in Hong Kong action films and taking on supporting actor roles.

title: Yueyahu Subdistrict
summary: Yueyahu Subdistrict is a subdistrict in Qinhuai District, Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. It has administrative control over 8 residential communities as of 2018. The subdistrict is located in Jiangsu province, China. Further information on Yueyahu Subdistrict is limited due to its status as a stub article, and expansion of this information would be beneficial.

title: Yuhua Stone
summary: Yuhua Stone, also known as Rain Flower Stone, is a type of sedimentary stone found in Nanjing, China. It consists of minerals such as quartz and silicates, polished smooth by the Yangtze River's water. The stone comes in various colors including red, rose, yellow, green, and white. According to legend, the stone originated from colorful flowers that rained down from the sky as a reward for a Chinese monk's sincerity. The stone is prized for its beautiful patterns, often resembling animals or flowers.

title: Zeng Zhaoyu
summary: Zeng Zhaoyu, also known as Tseng Chao-yu, was a Chinese archaeologist, museologist, and politician. Born on 27 January 1909 in Heye Town of Shuangfeng County, Hunan, she served as president of Nanjing Museum from 1955 until her death in 1964. Zeng was a member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference and the National People's Congress. She studied archaeology at various institutions, including the University of London and the National Central University. Zeng was a prominent figure in Chinese archaeology, but her career was marked by challenges and setbacks during the Chinese Civil War and the subsequent Communist rule. She died on 22 December 1964, reportedly by jumping from a pagoda at Linggu Temple.

title: Zhan Garden (Nanjing)
summary: Zhan Garden, also known as Zhān Yuán or "Garden of Forward Watching," is a Chinese garden located in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. The site was originally built as a garden during the early Ming dynasty by General Xu Da and later destroyed during the Taiping Rebellion. It was rebuilt and served as the main residence of Jiangsu Provincial Governor in the late Qing dynasty, visited by the Qianlong Emperor. The garden was restored after 1949 and features a southern 'mountain' added in 1960. The grounds also house the Taiping Heavenly Kingdom History Museum.

title: Zhang Aijun (politician, born 1964)
summary: Zhang Aijun is a Chinese politician born in February 1964. He began his career after completing studies at Changzhou Materials School, majoring in business management from 1982 to 1984. Zhang joined the Chinese Communist Party in July 1987 and has held various roles, including Mayor of Yangzhou, CCP Committee Secretary of Suqian, and head of the Publicity Department of the Jiangsu Provincial Committee of the Chinese Communist Party. He has also served as a member of the Standing Committee of the Jiangsu Provincial Committee of the Chinese Communist Party and Minister of the Publicity Department. In January 2024, Zhang was appointed Vice Chairman of the Standing Committee of the Jiangsu Provincial People's Congress.

title: Zhang Baojuan
summary:
Zhang Baojuan is a Chinese politician born in September 1967 in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province. She studied at Soochow University from 1986 to 1990 and began her career in the Jiangsu Provincial Department of Civil Affairs. Zhang rose through the ranks, holding various positions including Deputy Division Chief and Director of several divisions.

She served as Vice Mayor of Yangzhou from 2012 to 2015, and later held positions such as Deputy Party Secretary of Yangzhou and Director of the Jiangsu Provincial Department of Veterans Affairs. Zhang served as Mayor of Yangzhou from 2020 to 2021 and Party Secretary until January 2023.

In January 2023, Zhang was appointed Vice Chairwoman of the Standing Committee of the Jiangsu Provincial People's Congress and a member of its leading Party group.

title: Zhang Baosheng
summary: Zhang Baosheng was a Chinese Qigong practitioner who claimed supernatural abilities, including x-ray vision, pyrokinesis, spoon bending, healing, and telekinesis. Born in 1960 in Anhui to poor parents, he was adopted by a couple in Liaoning and later became a miner. Zhang's claims of supernatural abilities began after the popularity of Tang Yu, a Dazu schoolboy who allegedly possessed similar abilities. Zhang's claims were investigated and found to be unfounded, but he gained credibility through his connections with high-ranking officials in the Chinese Communist Party. He was invited to demonstrate his skills at the Zhongnanhai leadership compound and earned the trust of officials, including Ye Jianying.

title: Zhang Benren
summary: Zhang Benren was a Chinese geochemist born on May 28, 1929. He studied geology at Nanjing University and later earned a degree from the Beijing Institute of Geology in 1956. Zhang became a faculty member and was elected an academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 1999. He received the State Natural Science Award for his contributions to geochemistry. Zhang died on November 1, 2016, at the age of 87.
