title: Zhang Jiabao
summary: Zhang Jiabao is a Chinese soil scientist born in September 1957 in Gaoyou, Jiangsu. He received his bachelor's degree from Nanjing Agricultural University in 1982 and later earned a master's degree from the Institute of Soil Science, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Zhang then pursued his doctorate in soil physics at the University of the Philippines, graduating in 1990. He currently works as a researcher and professor at the Institute of Soil Science, Chinese Academy of Sciences, and the University of Chinese Academy of Sciences.

title: Zhang Jinghua
summary: Zhang Jinghua is a former Chinese politician born in July 1962 in Tai County, Jiangsu. He joined the Chinese Communist Party in June 1985 and graduated from Nanjing University with a major in economic management. Zhang held various positions, including director of Jiangsu Provincial Department of Environmental Protection, mayor of Xuzhou, party secretary of Zhenjiang, and vice governor of Jiangsu. He served as Party Secretary of Nanjing from 2017 to 2021 and held a seat on the Jiangsu provincial Standing Committee. Zhang was placed under investigation in December 2021 for "serious violations of party discipline and laws."

title: Zhang Kaiyuan
summary: Zhang Kaiyuan was a Chinese historian and educator born on July 8, 1926. He graduated from the University of Nanking in History and later pursued graduate studies at Central China University of Political Research. Zhang held various academic positions, including assistant professor and president of Huazhong Normal University. He also served as President of the Research Center for the History of Chinese Christian Colleges and Universities. Zhang Kaiyuan held Honorary Doctor of Laws degrees from Augustana College, Soka University, and Kansai University. He passed away on May 28, 2021.

title: Zhang Qianfan
summary: Zhang Qianfan is a constitutional law professor at Peking University Law School. Born in January 1964, he studied Solid State Physics as an undergraduate at Nanjing University and later earned PhD degrees in biophysics from Carnegie-Mellon University and governmental theory from the University of Texas at Austin. Zhang has taught law in China since 1999 and serves as senior deputy director of Peking University Administrative and Constitutional Law Center. He has authored hundreds of academic publications, including books on western constitutionalism and the Chinese constitution. His textbook "Study of Constitutional Law: Principles and Applications" was withdrawn from bookstores in China in 2019 due to a nationwide check on constitutional law textbooks.

title: Zhang Rong (physicist)
summary: Zhang Rong is a Chinese physicist born in February 1964 in Huai'an. He has worked on wide band-gap semiconductor materials and devices, and held various academic positions including professor at Nanjing University. Zhang was a visiting scientist at the University of Wisconsin–Madison and the University of Maryland from 1995 to 1999. He received a named professorship, "Cheung Kong Scholar's Program," in 2000 from the Ministry of Education. Zhang served as President of Shandong University, a position equivalent to vice-minister, from October 2013.

title: Zhang Tianfu
summary: Zhang Tianfu was a Chinese agronomist and tea expert born on 21 September 1910. He is known for promoting the processing of oolong tea and was a tea connoisseur. Zhang studied at various institutions, including Fukien Christian University and the Faculty of Agriculture, University of Nanking. He conducted research on tea cultivation and processing in Japan and Taiwan between 1934 and 1935, introducing Japanese tea processing machines to China in 1936. Zhang was targeted during the Anti-Rightist Movement and exiled multiple times, but continued his research and was rehabilitated in 1980. He finished a monograph on oolong tea by the 1990s and remarried in 2010.

title: Zhang Xiaoye
summary: Zhang Xiaoye is a Chinese meteorologist born in June 1963 in Beijing. He holds a Bachelor of Science degree from Northwest University (China), obtained in 1986, and a Doctor of Science degree from Nanjing University, earned in 1995. Zhang Xiaoye became a researcher at the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) in April 1995. He has held various positions, including deputy director of the Institute of Earth Environment and vice-president of the Chinese Academy of Meteorological Sciences.

title: Zhao Yongqing
summary: Zhao Yongqing is a Chinese politician born in April 1963 in Linqu County, Shandong. He entered Changwei Normal School in 1980 and graduated with a degree in Chinese language and literature. Zhao joined the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) in January 1989 and began his career in politics as a standing committee member of Changle County Federation of Trade Unions. He has held various positions, including deputy magistrate, vice mayor, executive vice chairman of Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region, and head of the Publicity Department of the CCP Ningxia Hui Autonomous Regional Committee. In January 2023, Zhao became chairman of the Guizhou Provincial Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference.

title: Zhao Zongyu
summary: Zhao Zongyu was a Chinese chemist and academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Born on November 28, 1904, in Rongchang County, Sichuan Province, he is known as the "father of man-made oil in China." Zhao graduated from National Central University (now Nanjing University) in 1928 and later studied in Germany at the Technische Hochschule in Berlin. After returning to China, he worked in various positions including factory manager and chief engineer of several chemical plants. He joined the Communist Party in 1984 and was a member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference. Zhao Zongyu died on October 10, 1989, in Beijing at the age of 84.

title: Zhe-Xi Luo
summary: Zhe-Xi Luo is an American paleontologist of Chinese origin. He specializes in vertebrate paleontology, particularly mammal evolution, morphology, and systematics. Luo earned his Bachelor's degree in 1982 from Nanjing University and his PhD in Paleontology from the University of California at Berkeley in 1989. He has published extensively on mammal evolution, particularly Mesozoic mammals, and is known for his work on the origins of mammal ear and jaw anatomy. Luo has discovered new mammal specimens from China, including Docofossor, Agilodocodon, Microdocodon, and Juramaia. He collaborates with researchers worldwide on specimens from around the globe.

title: Zhenan Bao
summary: Zhenan Bao is a Chinese-born American chemical engineer born in 1970 in Nanjing, China. She serves as the K.K. Lee Professor of Chemical Engineering at Stanford University with courtesy appointments in Chemistry and Material Science and Engineering. Bao is known for her work on organic field-effect transistors, organic semiconductors, and electronic skin. She received her Master of Science in chemistry from the University of Chicago in 1993 and a Doctor of Philosophy in chemistry in 1995. Bao developed the first all-plastic transistor at Bell Labs and has since focused on studying organic semiconductors, carbon nanotubes, and electronic skin at Stanford University. She is a co-founder of several Silicon Valley startup companies and serves as an advising Partner for Fusion Venture Capital.

title: Zheng Chunhua
summary: Zheng Chunhua is a Chinese writer born in 1959 in Chun'an County, Zhejiang. She is known for writing children's literature and her notable work "Big Head Son and Small Head Dad", which was a bestseller. The book was adapted into an animation in 1995, also achieving success. Zheng started publishing works in 1980 and won first prize at the Shanghai Youth Poetry Creation Contest that same year for her poem "Little Bed". She was assigned to Shanghai Adolescence and Children Press as an editor in 1981.

title: Zheng Ji (biochemist)
summary: Zheng Ji was a Chinese nutritionist and biochemist, often regarded as the founder of modern nutrition science in China. Born on May 6, 1900, in Nanxi County, Sichuan Province, China, he studied at the National Southeastern University and later in the United States, earning a PhD from Indiana University in 1934. Zheng Ji was elected to membership of the Sigma Xi Society and served as a professor, director, and head of various departments in Chinese universities. He established the first biochemistry research institute in China at National Central University and proposed a theory of metabolic imbalance related to old age. Zheng Ji lived to the age of 110 and was claimed to be the world's oldest professor, dying on July 29, 2010.

title: Zheng Zhegu
summary: Zheng Zhegu (1880-1925) was a Chinese actor and entrepreneur. Born in Nanjing, Qing China, as Zheng Lian, he was the son of a government official. He served in the military before joining the anti-Qing movement and later joined the Republic of China military after the 1911 revolution. Disillusioned with government service, he moved to Shanghai and became involved in the theatre, joining several troupes and gaining recognition as a stage performer. In 1922, he co-founded the Mingxing Film Company and made his film debut in The King of Comedy Visits Shanghai and Labourer's Love.

title: Zhihong Xia
summary: Zhihong "Jeff" Xia is a Chinese-American mathematician born on 20 September 1962 in Dongtai, Jiangsu, China. He received a bachelor's degree in astronomy from Nanjing University in 1982 and a PhD in mathematics from Northwestern University in 1988. Xia's research focuses on celestial mechanics, dynamical systems, Hamiltonian dynamics, and ergodic theory. He solved the Painlevé conjecture in his dissertation by proving the existence of singularities for N ≥ 5 in the N-body problem. Xia has received several awards, including the Blumenthal Award of the American Mathematical Society in 1993 and the National Young Investigator Award from the National Science Foundation from 1993 to 1998.

title: Zhonghe Zhou
summary: Zhonghe Zhou is a Chinese palaeontologist born on January 19, 1965, in Jiangdu, Jiangsu province. He graduated from Nanjing University and earned a Ph.D. in Biology from the University of Kansas in 1999. Zhou is the director of the Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology at the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing. He was elected to the U.S. National Academy of Sciences in 2010 and received the Future Science Prize in 2025. Zhou is notable for describing the ancient bird Confuciusornis.

title: Zhonghua Gate, Nanjing
summary:
Zhonghua Gate is a gate and defensive complex located on the city wall of Nanjing, China. It serves as the southern gate of Nanjing and is considered one of China's most renowned ancient city gates. Originally known as Jubao Gate, it was built on the site of the south gate of the Southern Tang dynasty capital city. The gate was renamed Zhonghua Gate in 1931 after the Republic of China government established Nanjing as its capital. It features a complex structure with three barbicans connected by four arched gates, each equipped with Qianjinzha and wooden doors. The gate has survived for 600 years, despite weathering wind and rain.

Key facts:

- Location: Nanjing city wall, China
- Original name: Jubao Gate
- Renamed in 1931: Zhonghua Gate
- Built on the site of: Southern Tang dynasty capital city south gate
- Structure features: Three barbicans, four arched gates, Qianjinzha, and wooden doors
- Age: 600 years old

title: Zhongshan Wharf
summary: Zhongshan Wharf is a wharf located in Xiaguan, along the Yangtze River. It is situated near Wharf No.7 of Port of Nanjing. The wharf was initially built as Dasheng Wharf in 1900 by the British company Jardine Matheson, and later moved to its current location in 1935. It was renamed Zhongshan Wharf after the completion of a new wharf at the beginning of Zhongshan Road. The waiting hall was expanded in 1949 and rebuilt again in 1990, increasing its area to 3,040 square meters.

title: Zhou Hongbo
summary: Zhou Hongbo is a Chinese politician born in October 1970 in Guilin, Guangxi. He holds a degree in agricultural entomology from Nanjing Agricultural University and a master's degree in public management from the Party School of the CCP Guangxi Committee. Zhou has held various positions, including member of the Standing Committee of the Jiangsu Provincial Committee of the Chinese Communist Party and Party Secretary of Nanjing. He has also served as Vice Mayor, Deputy Party Secretary, and Mayor of Nanning, as well as Vice Chairman of the People's Government of Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region. Zhou is a delegate to the 20th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party and has served as a deputy in several national and provincial people's congresses.

title: Zhu Chengliang
summary: Zhu Chengliang is a Chinese author and illustrator of children's books. He was born in Shanghai in 1948 and spent his childhood in Suzhou. Zhu studied at the Department of Fine Art, Nanjing University. He has worked as an author, illustrator, editor, and designer, and currently serves as Deputy Chief Editor of the Jiangsu Fine Arts Publishing House.

title: Zhu Jin (astronomer)
summary: Zhu Jin is a Chinese astronomer born on April 24, 1965, in Beijing. He graduated from Beijing Normal University and earned his Ph.D. from Nanjing University in 1991. Zhu Jin is the current curator of Beijing Planetarium and has been involved in various astronomy research projects, including the discovery of 2728 asteroids. His team also discovered a comet named Zhu-Balam in 1997. He is a member of the Small Bodies Nomenclature of the International Astronomical Union and has spoken on the plausibility of astrology, questioning its effects from an astronomical perspective.

title: Zhu Kejiang
summary: Zhu Kejiang is a retired Chinese politician and business executive born in September 1957 in Huai'an, Jiangsu Province. He joined the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) in June 1976 and began his career as a rural teacher, commune worker, and soldier. Zhu studied at Liaocheng Teachers College from 1978 to 1982 and later earned a Master of Business Administration degree at Maastricht School of Management in the Netherlands. He held various senior positions, including Mayor of Wuxi and Party Secretary of Yancheng, before serving as chairman and CCP Committee Secretary of Jiangsu Guoxin Asset Management Group from 2016 to 2017. Zhu was a delegate to the 12th National People's Congress and held multiple positions within the CCP and Jiangsu Provincial government.

title: Zhu Senyuan
summary: Zhu Senyuan was a Chinese rocket scientist and academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Born on 26 October 1930 in Liyang County, Jiangsu, Zhu attended several schools before being admitted to the Department of Aeronautics at Central University (now Nanjing University) in 1949. He later studied in the Soviet Union, graduating from Bauman Higher Institute of Technology in 1960. Zhu joined the Rocket Engine Design Department of the Fifth Academy of the Ministry of National Defense in 1961 and worked on various projects, including large launch vehicles and rocket engines. He was appointed leader of an expert group in 1993 and died on 14 May 2025 at the age of 94.

title: Zhuang Qiaosheng
summary: Zhuang Qiaosheng was a Chinese geneticist and breeder born on 5 August 1916 in Nanyu, Minhou County, Fujian. He was a member of the China Democratic League and served on the 7th National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference. Zhuang studied agronomy at the University of Nanking and later worked at various agricultural institutes in China, including the Central Agricultural Experimental Institute. He spent over 60 years working at the Beiping Agricultural Experimental Farm, where he bred more than 20 new winter wheat varieties with high yield and disease resistance. Zhuang Qiaosheng was an academician of the Chinese Academy of Sciences and died on 8 May 2022 at the age of 105.

title: Zifeng Tower
summary: Zifeng Tower is a 450-meter supertall skyscraper in Nanjing, Jiangsu. Completed in 2010, the 66-story building features retail and office spaces, with floors 49-71 housing a hotel, restaurants, and a public observatory. Designed by Skidmore, Owings and Merrill, led by Adrian Smith, the tower is currently the tallest in Nanjing and Jiangsu province. It ranks as the eleventh tallest building in China and the twentieth tallest globally. The tower occupies an area of 18,721 square meters and is home to the Nanjing Greenland InterContinental Hotel.

title: Zou Xuexiao
summary: Zou Xuexiao is a Chinese botanist and academician of the Chinese Academy of Engineering. Born on 24 July 1963 in Tongzi Township, Hengyang County, Hunan Province, he studied at Hengyang County No. 6 High School before enrolling in Hunan Agricultural University, where he received his bachelor's degree in 1983 and master's degree in 1986. Zou earned a doctorate in agronomy from Nanjing Agricultural University in 2005. He has held various positions at the Hunan Academy of Agricultural Sciences, including director and president, before being appointed president of Hunan Agricultural University in 2018.

title: Zuo Wei
summary: Zuo Wei is a Chinese academic and university administrator born in August 1961 in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. He joined the Chinese Communist Party in July 1983 and began his career that same month, studying computer science and engineering at Nanjing Institute of Technology from 1979 to 1983. Zuo holds a doctorate in Management Science and Engineering from Southeast University, where he has held various administrative and academic positions since 1983. He served as Deputy Secretary of the Party Committee, Vice President, and Executive Deputy Secretary at Southeast University from 2001 to 2017. Zuo later became Party Secretary of Nanjing Agricultural University from 2013 to 2017 and returned to Southeast University as Party Secretary in December 2017.

title: 中国共产党南京市委员会
summary:
The Communist Party of China in Nanjing is the local organization of the Communist Party of China in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province. It is elected by the Nanjing Municipal Congress and is responsible for implementing the decisions of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, the Jiangsu Provincial Committee, and the Municipal Congress. 

The party was initially formed in 1922 as a small group in Pukou, and underwent several reorganizations and setbacks before being officially established in 1927. The party was later disbanded, but re-established in 1937 after the Japanese invasion of Nanjing. 

During World War II, the party established a branch in Nanjing and later changed its name to the Communist Party of China's Nanjing Working Committee. After the founding of the People's Republic of China in 1949, a new Nanjing Municipal Committee was established. However, the party's leadership was briefly taken over by radical factions during the Cultural Revolution in 1967.

title: 中国共产党南京市委员会
summary:
The Communist Party of China in Nanjing is the local organization of the Communist Party of China in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province. It is elected by the Nanjing Municipal Congress and is responsible for implementing the decisions of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, the Jiangsu Provincial Committee, and the Municipal Congress. 

The party was initially formed in 1922 as a small group in Pukou, and underwent several reorganizations and setbacks before being officially established in 1927. The party was later disbanded, but re-established in 1937 after the Japanese invasion of Nanjing. 

During World War II, the party established a branch in Nanjing and later changed its name to the Communist Party of China's Nanjing Working Committee. After the founding of the People's Republic of China in 1949, a new Nanjing Municipal Committee was established. However, the party's leadership was briefly taken over by radical factions during the Cultural Revolution in 1967.

title: 侵华日军南京大屠杀遇难同胞纪念馆
summary:
The Memorial Hall of the Victims in Nanjing Massacre by Japanese Invaders is a museum located in the southwest of Nanjing City, near Jiangdong Gate. It was established to commemorate the victims of the Nanjing Massacre and is a specialized historical museum with a site area of approximately 74,000 square meters. The building covers an area of about 25,000 square meters and has an exhibition area of around 9,800 square meters. The museum houses over 10,000 historical documents and artifacts and is a national first-class museum as well as a national patriotic education demonstration base.

The memorial hall was opened in 1985 and has undergone two expansions in 1995 and 2005. The exhibition includes three parts: the square display, bone relics display, and historical materials display. There is also a cinema hall that mainly shows documentaries and films related to the Nanjing Massacre and the war of resistance against Japan.

The museum has over 10,000 artifacts, with more than 3,000 on display. These include historical photographs, documents, diaries and other items. The museum also has a bone relics display room that stores the remains of victims of the Nanjing Massacre. Every year on December 13th, a national memorial service for victims of the Nanjing Massacre is held at the museum.

title: 俞庆江
summary:
Yu Qingjiang was born in September 1963 in Nanjing, China. He graduated from a certain flight academy of the People's Liberation Army Air Force and later attended the Air Force Political Academy, Russian Air Force Military Academy, and Air Force Engineering University. Yu Qingjiang held various positions including commander of the 30th Aviation Division, commander of the Air Force Command in Dalian, deputy chief of staff and chief of staff of the Air Force in Jinan Military Region. 

In 2015, Yu Qingjiang became the president of the Air Force Command College and in 2017, he was promoted to chief of staff. In 2023, Yu Qingjiang became the deputy commander of the Air Force. He was promoted to major general in 2010 and to air force general in 2019. Yu Qingjiang is also an avid calligrapher, having studied for three years at the China Academy of Painting and Calligraphy under masters such as Ouyang Zhongshi and Li Du.

summary:

title: 傅怡
summary: Fu Yi was born in November 1953, with his ancestral home in Jinyuan County, Shanxi Province. In 1968, he went to Suqian County, Jiangsu Province for agricultural reassignment and joined the People's Liberation Army the following year. He became a member of the Communist Party in 1971 and rose through the ranks to become deputy commander, then commander of the Tank Tenth Division. In 2002, he served as chief of staff of the First Group Army and deputy commander of the North Sea Fleet's Dalian Base. He was promoted to major general in 2004 and became commander of the Zhejiang Provincial Military Region. He retired in 2013 but was investigated by the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection two years later.

title: 傅怡

In 1968, he went to Suqian County, Jiangsu Province for agricultural reassignment and joined the People's Liberation Army the following year. He was promoted to major general in 2004 and became commander of the Zhejiang Provincial Military Region. He retired in 2013 but was investigated by the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection two years later.

title: 六朝
summary:
The Six Dynasties refer to six southern Chinese kingdoms that ruled from the capital of Jiankang (also known as Jianye). These dynasties include the Eastern Wu, Eastern Jin, Liu Song, Southern Qi, Southern Liang, and Chen. The Six Dynasties period began with the Eastern Wu's expansion in southern China and ended with the Sui Dynasty's unification of north and south. This era overlaps with the Northern and Southern Dynasties period.

The Six Dynasties poetry is a significant era in Chinese literary history, characterized by an emphasis on formal beauty and laying the groundwork for the diversity of Tang poetry. The popularity of supernatural fiction during this time was influenced by social unrest and harsh realities, leading people to seek solace in stories about gods, demons, and religious myths.

The Six Dynasties saw the widespread development of the yin-yang five elements theory in the Book of Changes, which had a profound impact on Confucian orthodoxy. Buddhism also flourished during this period (as well as in the north), with its teachings being widely accepted by the general public through the practice of clear talk.

title: 南京历史
summary:
Nanjing has a history of city-building dating back over 2,500 years. It was the capital of China for twelve dynasties and has been known by various names throughout history. The city was named Nanjing during the Ming dynasty after the capital was moved from Beijing in 1403. In the early Qing period, it was renamed Jiangning Prefecture and later became Nanjing Prefecture in 1912. In 1927, it was officially designated as the capital of the Republic of China and renamed Nanjing Special Municipality.

Archaeological findings in Nanjing indicate that early human activity dates back around 60-100 million years. The city has a long history of cultural development, with the discovery of ancient villages dating back around 6,000 years. The North Yinqueshan site, discovered in the 1950s, dates back to around 4000-3000 BCE and is an example of the North Yinqueshan culture, a type of Neolithic culture found in the Yangtze River Delta region. Other notable early cultures in the area include the Potian and Hushu cultures.

Nanjing was originally part of the ancient state of Wu, which was located in the region known as "the nine provinces under heaven." In 570 BCE, the state of Wu established settlements in what is now Nanjing's Liyang and Qixia districts. In 495 BCE, King Fucha of Wu built a city in what is now the Xuanwu district and established a number of bronze workshops. In 472 BCE, King Goujian of Yue conquered Wu and built a city in what is now the Nanjing City Gate area. In 333 BCE, King Wu of Chu conquered Yue and built a city on Stone Hill (now known as Qingliangshan), which was said to be buried with gold to ward off evil spirits.

title: 南京同曦大圣篮球俱乐部
summary:
The Nanjing Monkey Kings, also known as the Jiangsu Monkey Kings, is a professional basketball team in China's top-tier league, the Chinese Basketball Association (CBA). The team was founded in October 2007 by Jiangsu Tongxi Investment Development Group. Initially, the team drew players from both Jiangsu's second team and nationwide recruitment. 

In 2008, the Monkey Kings began competing in the National Basketball League (NBL) and played their home games at the Jiangning Sports Center Gymnasium in Nanjing. To qualify for the CBA, they relocated to Hefei in 2013 and then returned to Nanjing in 2017 after signing a strategic cooperation agreement with the city's sports authorities.

title: 南京大屠杀死难者国家公祭日
summary: The National Memorial Day for Nanjing Massacre Victims is a national memorial day in the People's Republic of China to commemorate Chinese victims and martyrs who suffered during Japan's invasion of China. It is observed annually on December 13th, although it is named after the Nanjing Massacre. The memorial day honors seven categories of victims: those who died in the Nanjing Massacre, chemical warfare, biological warfare, forced labor, comfort women, indiscriminate bombing, and three-all campaign. The Nanjing Massacre occurred from December 13 to January 1938, resulting in the deaths of over 300,000 people. The Chinese government established the National Memorial Day for Nanjing Massacre Victims in 2014, with the first memorial ceremony held on December 13 of that year.

title: 南京日报
summary: The Nanjing Daily is the official newspaper of the Communist Party of China's Nanjing Municipal Committee. It was first published on March 15, 1956, as a four-page newspaper in A4 format. The newspaper was initially suspended on February 11, 1961, but resumed publication in various forms. In 1978, it was re-established and underwent several name changes before reverting to its original title in 1979. The newspaper was later converted into a broadsheet format in 1986 and expanded to include additional pages in 1992.

title: 卢沙野
summary:
Wang Yi, also known as Wang Xiaohong, was born in 1964 in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province. He is a Chinese diplomat who has served as the Ambassador to France and Monaco, and currently holds the position of Special Representative for European Affairs. Wang Yi is often regarded as a representative figure of China's "wolf warrior diplomacy," known for his provocative statements.

Wang Yi studied French at the Nanjing Foreign Language School and graduated from the Beijing Foreign Affairs College in 1982. He joined the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs and held various positions, including serving as a diplomat in Guinea, Africa Department staff member, and Consul General. In 2006, he became the first Ambassador to Senegal, followed by serving as Ambassador to Canada from 2017 to 2019. He then took up the position of Ambassador to France in July 2019.

Wang Yi has been involved in several controversies, including criticizing Western countries for treating China unfairly and accusing French nursing home staff of abandoning elderly residents to die from hunger and disease. The French Foreign Ministry responded with a statement criticizing some of Wang Yi's comments. In 2021, he sent a letter to the French Senate's Taiwan Friendship Group, calling for the cancellation of a visit to Taiwan. Wang Yi's letter was described as scathing and provoked French discontent.

In October 2021, Wang Yi published an article on the Chinese Embassy's website in France, titled "China Must and Will Be Reunified," criticizing a French newspaper article by Sebastian Falletti. Wang Yi emphasized that Taiwan has always been an integral part of China and that the issue is a domestic matter for China to resolve. The head of Reporters Without Borders, Christophe Deloire, responded with a commentary, calling on Chinese diplomats to stop making baseless attacks on the media.

title: 对南京大屠杀的否认
summary: 南京大屠杀否认是中日关系史上一个极具争议的事件。日本军队在抗日战争期间是否屠杀了数十万中国军民的真相一直存在争议。历史学家对东京法庭关于日军在南京战役后所犯暴行的范围和性质有不同的看法。日本的一些历史学家认为大屠杀的程度和性质存在争议，这导致了日本和中国之间的关系复杂化。

title: 左惟
summary: Luo Wei was born in August 1961 in Nanjing, Jiangsu Province. He is of Han ethnicity and currently serves as the secretary of the party committee at Southeast University, having previously held the same position at Nanjing Agricultural University. Luo Wei graduated from the Computer Science Department of Nanjing Institute of Technology and later worked at the university, rising through the ranks to become a department head, deputy secretary of the student union, and eventually secretary. He then moved to Southeast University, where he held positions including assistant to the president and deputy party secretary. Luo Wei also holds a doctoral degree in management from Southeast University's School of Economics and Management.

title: 明孝陵
summary:
The Ming Xiaoling Mausoleum is the joint tomb of Zhu Yuanzhang, the founding emperor of the Ming dynasty, and his empress Ma. It is named after the empress's posthumous title "Xiaoci" (孝慈), meaning filial and benevolent. The mausoleum is located at the foot of Zijin Mountain's Yundong Peak in Nanjing, with the Zhongshan Mausoleum to its east and Meihua Mountain to its south. It is the largest imperial tomb of the Ming dynasty and one of China's largest ancient imperial tombs.

The site selection for the mausoleum began in 1381 and was completed in 1383, with a total of 100,000 soldiers involved. The construction took 25 years to complete and was finished in 1405. The overall layout of the mausoleum is divided into two parts: the spirit way and the imperial palace, which includes the main buildings such as the hall of worship and the treasure city. The mausoleum's grounds stretch 2.62 kilometers long, with a surrounding wall of 45 li in circumference.

Most of the wooden structures on the ground were destroyed during the Taiping Rebellion in 1853. However, some brick and stone buildings remain, including the Down Horse Pavilion, the Forbidden Edict Stele, the Great Golden Gate, the Stone Statue of Life, the Stele Pavilion, the Text and Martial Arts Gates, the Hall of Worship Gate, the Inner Red Gate, the Square City Ming Tower, and the Treasure City wall. The layout of the mausoleum is grand and strict, influencing the design of imperial tombs in both the Ming and Qing dynasties.

title: 栖霞寺
summary:
Stacking Temple, also known as Xi Xia Si, is located in the western foothills of Xixia Mountain in Nanjing's Qixia District, Jiangsu Province. The temple was initially built during the Southern and Northern Dynasties period. A stupa within the temple, constructed during the Sui Dynasty, is an eight-sided five-story stone tower and a significant Buddhist structure. The temple's main buildings include the mountain gate, Maitreya Buddha Hall, Vairocana Buddha Hall, Law Hall, Recitation Hall, Scripture Library, and the Memorial Hall of Guanyin Bodhisattva. 

The temple has undergone multiple destructions and rebuildings, including damage during the war in Southern Song Dynasty, confiscation of temple assets in Ming Dynasty, and occupation by Taiping Rebels in Qing Dynasty. In 1920, a high-ranking monk from Jinshan Temple named Zongyue rebuilt the temple. Later, Abbot Ruoshun raised funds to rebuild and recreate the Buddha statues. In 1983, Xi Xia Temple was designated as a key temple in China's Han Chinese regions. 

The Thousand Buddha Cliff Caves, located within the temple, began excavation in 502 AD during the Southern Qi Dynasty. Currently, there are 515 Buddha statues within the caves. In 2000, archaeologists discovered a set of well-preserved murals in the Thousand Buddha Cliff Caves. During the 1937 Nanjing Massacre, approximately 20,000 refugees were evacuated to Xi Xia Temple.

title: 王春宁
summary: 王春宁出生于1963年，原籍江苏南京或山东牟平。王春宁曾是中国人民武装警察部队的上将级军官，担任过多个高级职务。王春宁是中共十九届中央候补委员和二十届中央委员，2025年10月被开除党籍军籍。王春宁曾任陆军第一集团军参谋长、副军长，海军东海舰队副参谋长，并曾担任陆军第十二集团军军长、北京卫戍区司令员和武警部队参谋长。2020年12月，王春宁升任武警部队司令员，并晋升上将警衔。

title: 辽南京
summary: Liaoning, also known as Nanjing of Liao, is a city developed during the Liao Dynasty and located in the southwestern part of modern Beijing's urban area. It served as a secondary capital of Liao Dynasty and was also the city of Xizhou Prefecture, Beijin County, and Weipeng County. In 938, Emperor Taizong of Liao renamed the city "Youzhou Prefecture" and in 1012, it was renamed to "Xizhou Prefecture". The name Xizhou is derived from the phrase "Yan divides the world, and Jin travels through it as a crossing point". Liaoning was not under Han Chinese rule from the Later Tang of Five Dynasties to the Ming Dynasty, except for a brief period between 1123 and 1125 when it was under the jurisdiction of Yan Mountain Prefecture of Northern Song Dynasty. During the Jin Dynasty, Liaoning was renovated and expanded to become Zhongdu.

title: 陆慷
summary: 陆慷出生于1968年5月，籍贯江苏泰兴。他是一名中国外交官，毕业于南京外国语学校和北京大学国际政治系。陆慷曾在多个外交系统单位工作，包括外交部国际司、常驻联合国代表团和外交部军控司。他还获得了新加坡国立大学公共政策硕士学位。陆慷曾担任外交部新闻司司长、外交部北美大洋洲司司长和中华人民共和国驻印度尼西亚共和国特命全权大使，现任中共中央对外联络部副部长。

title: 陽山碑材
summary:
The Yangshan Stele is located in Jiangsu Province, China, specifically in the Jiangning District of Nanjing City. It consists of three massive stone blocks carved out from a mountain, originally intended for the stele at Ming Xiaoling Mausoleum but abandoned due to their enormous size. The Yangshan Stele is divided into three parts: the base, the body, and the top. In 2005, it was recognized as the "world's largest stele" by Guinness World Records. It was designated a national key cultural relic in 2013.

The Yangshan Stele is situated on the southeastern slope of Mount Yangshan, with a total length of 49.40 meters and a width of 10.70 meters. The base, or "turtle pedestal," measures 30.35 meters in length and 13 meters in thickness, with a height of 16 meters. The base is hollow except for two rows of stone pillars at the bottom.
